column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

I graduated. I am finished university! It’s a crazy feeling. What the hell’s next? who knows…
column473:
>

Rumbo, if you dont know, I’m pretty sure means somthing in Spanish towards going towards somewhere. The part I love about it tho is when you said Rumbo you really get to roll that rrrrrrrrr. It sounds lovely.
column476:
>

So where did we leave off?…
column479:
>

Last time I posted I had was sleeping in Julia’s apparment, and played house husband for a day with Adam.
column482:
>

Julia had work early in the morning so when I woke up she was already gone. It was just me and Adam.
column485:
>

I took my time getting up and said my final goodbye to Adam. my FINAL GOODBYE (it really was this time… no more accidental bumping into each other like before). We had such a crazy adventure together in europe and now it was my time to say goodbye for the rest of the trip. Adam was off to Spain, and I was off to Paris to go fix issues with my flight home. On previous evenings I had spent HOUR and HOURS on hold with the Air France phone line, in the very end I found out the only way I could resolve my flight troubles was to go to Charles De Gaulle Airport in Paris and talk to Air France myself in person, mano a mano (more spanish, but this one is actualy an ENGLISH saying funny enough).
column488:
>

I left Julias appartment. Below is a picture of Julias shoe as I left the appartment. I wont explain why I took a picture of the shoe. Only both Julia and I know. Thanks again Julia for being such an amazing host. You made switzerland awesome :)
column489: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column497:
>

I then left for the train station in BASEL. YES a train. I was done biking at this point. I did not have enough time or energy to bike to Paris if I wanted to do all the important things I had planned in other countries (forshadowing epic adventures in Amsterdam).
column500:
>

When I arrived at the train station. I asked the people who work there to help me get to Paris. They told me that it was IMPOSSIBLE to get to Paris that day…. Whoopies, I didnt realize I had to actually plan my transportation. I was so use to going with the flow, independly with my bike (No one tells me what to do when I am using my bike to get around).
column503:
>

So… shit. It was impossible to get to Paris, which was what I wanted to do… And I already said goodbye to Julia so I couldnt GO BACK to her appartment (that would be akward). So I improvised. I hopped on a train to Strasbourg instead. A year prior when I was learning French. I did a language exchange with a guy who lives there (he taught me french in exchange for english). So I sent him a messages and we planned to meet up and he was gonna give me a tour or Strasbourg that very same day!
column506:
>

So I bought a train ticket to Strasbourg. On the boarder of Germany and France.
column509:
>

Here are some observations I made about the difference between trains I took in Italy and trains I took in Switzerland…
column512:
>

First of all, taking the train in Switzerland was 100 times easier than Italy… They were SO HELPFUL in the station and it was way less chaotic. I also had lots of time to board the train with my bike and didnt need to pay extra to bring my bike on the train. It was a CHILL expereince, much different than italy where I had to SPRINT to the correct car in order to make it on the train and i had to pay extra for a bike ticket.
column515:
>

When I arrived to Strasbourg my friend met me at the station and gave me a tour of the entire city in about 4 hours!
column518:
>

The strangest thing I saw was that french people here called burritos Tacos.
column519: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column526:
>

Strasbourg is a beautiful city with a rich history. One hidden tourist gem was a bomb shell that landed in a building from World War 2 that didnt explode. Its still just sitting their in the building for anyone to look at.
column527: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column535:
>

Above and below are two of my favourite things I saw. One an amazing and beautiful church. and below, a view form an old military barricade that french soldiers would look out from to protect the city from germans, or something like that.
column536: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column544:
>

In the evening my friend and I parted ways. After spending the day meandering around Strasbourg, I was feeling tired and found a nice quiet spot in the forest outside the city. It was a rainly night but I found a nice sheltered spot in deep bush with trees to protect me from the rain.
column547:
>

I remember falling asleep enjoying the rain drops falling on the forest floor and the roof of my tent.
column548: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column553:
>

A picture of the campsite in the morning.
column556:
>

Thats all for now folks.

column58: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column61:
>

Leave the airport early in the morning,
column64:
>

Biking along the river again…
column67:
>

Taking the nap in the park, making pasta coffee.
column70:
>

Getting in touch with my friend in Paris. I was able to stay with her and her Aunt in their apartment to the east side of Paris.
column73:
>

In the evening we walked around Paris I saw Le Louvre, the Effile Tour, some gardens and bridges.
column76:
>

I had some awesome baguettes at a Boulangerie.
column79:
>

The Parisian rudeness is not a myth lol. There are a lot of unhappy people here. The first cafe we sat down I wasn’t sure I wanted to drink anything yet but my friend did. The waiter told us he wouldn’t serve us unless I also ordered a drink too. And then he asked us to leave the table… They were not even busy and had many many empty seats. I thought this was funny.
column82:
>

Then, I had to go to the washroom and i was refused entry into a restaurant to use the washroom. This is fine, but this never happens in Vancouver. People will let you use the washroom if you ask nicely.
column85:
>

But I actually really like Paris. It’s a lovely city. It’s beautiful. It’s not as chaotic as other big cities I have visited this trip. It’s a nice feeling citing in the cafes, and Boulangeries in the streets and watching the people, seeing the diversity. People from all over the world come to Paris and on the streets you hear so many languages, French, Spanish, Italian, Chinese, German, and many more.
column88:
>

I expected to be disappointed with Paris. Many others I met on this trip told me Paris did not live up to their expectations. In reality, Paris is great.
column91:
>

What I like most about Paris is the buildings and construction. The Effile tour is very impressive… And of the buildings have a nice Parisian aesthetic to them… I dont know how to describe it.
column94:
>

We also took the metro, it felt like any other metro I had been on…
column97:
>

Getting around the city was not that difficult with buses and the metro.
column100:
>

We just spent the evening drinking and walking around the streets. My favourite moment was probably sitting by the river beside the Notre Dam watching the tourist boats go by as we drank cheap wine.

column63:
>

August 6th was one hell of a day.
column66:
>

After weeks of internal stress building up about how I was going to actually fly home from Europe. Today was the day I was going to get some answers.
column69:
>

First some background information…
column72:
>

A long time ago I bought tickets to fly home from Valencia in the South of Spain. The original plan was to bike through Spain and so I thought I would fly out from there.
column75:
>

Thus I had a plane ticket from Valencia to Vancouver, with ONE layover in Paris.
column78:
>

My plan changed as I met people and my trip developed to the point where… The odds were I was NEVER going to go to Valencia since it was way too far out of the way. It is a 2 day train event where I can’t even have my bike with me.
column81:
>

So now I was in an interesting position.
column92: > It was very easy to get to Paris
column95: > It was really hard to get to Valencia
column98: > I had a flight that stopped in Paris, maybe I could just skip the Valencia to Paris flight and fly directly from Paris???
column101:
>

So I tried to figure out a way to fly out of Paris instead of Valencia using my same flights by calling Air France to hash out the details. It was impossible to talk to anyone who could actually help me… They told me it was basically impossible to miss only one part of the flight and that if I didn'
column102: t show up for the first part of the flight the ENTIRE flight would be cancelled.
column105:
>

I decided that the only way for me to get any customer service was to talk to someone in person. So I was going to go to Air France in Paris! Storm the French and assure my victory. Victory of me getting my flight home.
column108:
>

Okay back to me waking up in the forest in Strasbourg….
column111:
>

I packed up my tent and biked back into Strasbourg to the train station. All I can remember about this experience is sitting outside eating several baguettes which I had bought from a bakery for breakfast.
column114:
>

It rained the entire time I was in Strasbourg that day except for when I packed up my tent in the morning (very fortunate).
column117:
>

Waiting in the Train station
column120:
>

I then waited for the train for a while in the station. Again it was fairly easy to find a train to take me to Paris. Since I was on a bike I had to take the slow trains rather than the bullet train.
column123:
>

Mission, deal with flight problems. Phone customer service is impossible. So I biked 35 km to the airport in Paris to deal with the issue in person.
column124: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column129:
>

Waiting in the Train station
column133: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column58: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column61:
>

I took my time getting up. After this I packed up my things and went to the Basel Train station.
column64:
>

I asked the people who work there to help me get to Paris and the said it was impossible today with the bike, But my best bet was to go to Strasbourg today by train then take another train the next day.
column67:
>

First of all, taking the train in Switzerland was 100 times easier than italy. They are so helpful in the station and it’s way less chaotic. I also had lots of time to board the train and I did not need to pay to bring the bike.
column70:
>

I got on the train and arrived after an hour in Strasbourg.
column73:
>

When I was learning French about a year ago I started doing a language exchange online with someone in French and English. I would teach English and be taught French. So I had a friend who lived in Strasbourg. I messaged him and when i arrived we met up and he showed me around the entire city in about 4 hours.
column76:
>

It’s a wonderful city, lots of cool buildings and rich history from world war 2.
column79:
>

After spending time in Strasbourg I went and found a forest to sleep in outside the city. I slept a lot and slept early. It was a peaceful night in the forest. It rained all night and I enjoyed the rain drops falling on the forest floors and on the roof of my tent.

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

Don’t worry, I am still writing these, albeit slowly.
column470:
>

Take a second to consider how crazy it is to meet somone in a cafe in Greece, cook pasta with them at the Gate of Hates, all in one afternoon, THEN bike to and stay in their appartment in Switzerland a month later.
column474: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column479:
>

so you see that its crazy.
column482:
>

We are coming up on 6 months since I got back from Europe. I’d say im back in the full swing of normal life. I finally stopped wearing my sandals everywhere (lots of people were calling me sandal man). And I havn’t cooked on my camping stove in a couple months. I’m working on fun interesting stuff and I am just as excited about each day as I was on my adventure in Europe. So far so good.
column485:
>

Back to talking about August 4th.
column488:
>

Here is my journal entry written August 6th about August 4th…
column491:
>

Adam and I spent the day enjoying being in an appartment once again. Julia has a wonderful appartment and great decorations all over. We really felt at home there.
column494:
>

It was a lazy day. We spend the day binge watching Diney Plus’s show Andor and Mandalorian (amazing show) when it was raining outside and Julia was out at work. We watched the Mandalorian all day long and cooked breakfast and lunch.
column495: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column500:
>

Adam and I enjoying lunch on julias balcony
column501: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column506:
>

Julia has an amazing large TV
column509:
>

After lots of Mandalorian, we went to the grocery store with a plan to suprise Julia with dinner when she came home. We bought a bunch of groceries, pasta sause, pasta, bread, various swiss cheeses and wine.
column512:
>

Once we got home, we got to work and cooked a grand feast for Julia. When she returned home we had all the food ready and had a great dinner. Julia was shocked that we made her food. During her workday, she was telling her coworkers about the two cyclist house husbands who were staying in her appartment and they couldnt believe it. I like to think they got jealous when Julia sent them pictures of her home cooked meal waiting for her for when she got home.
column513: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column521:
>

It was amazing that we actually go to see Julia again and we couldn’t believe we actually made it from Greece to there in Switzerland. Back in Greece, Julia was the one who told us to try to be in switzerland for August 1st switzerland day and SOMEHOW we made it happen.
column524:
>

After dinner we continued to binge watch Disney Plus, this time the show “Andor”… It’s a really good sci-fi show, based in the Star Wars universe if you are looking for anohter good show to watch I would recommend it.
column527:
>

I finished the ENITRE series that night lol.
column530:
>

That was a perfect day of relaxation, a day of binge watching and binge eating. It was a nice change from contantly biking. I got to be a hermit for a day.
column533:
>

Julia had work the next day and I was planning to leave the apartment to continue travelling solo to Paris. So we said goodbye that night.
column536:
>

I once again slept on the coach.
column537: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column545:
>

Thats all folks,

I will keep writing when I have motivation and time. There’s alot of exciting stuff left to cover you just won’t believe happened.

- Erik

column426: > #68 - Swiss watches marking time, As we&#39
column427: re floating down the Rhine
column434: > August 3rd
column435: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: ><div style=""height:1px
column461: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column462: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column465:
>

Hey, welcome back.

I woke up on the forest floor surprised to see about 50 slugs all over my tent. Even some had made it inside of the tent. It seemed like I slept in a nest of slugs if there exists such a thing.
column466: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: ><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""width:630px
column474:
>

I went over to my bike which was outside the tent, and it as well was covered in slugs. Probably the worst part is my brand new running shoe I bought for the trip was completly COVERED in slime.
column477:
>

The day before, I had lost this shoe’s brother in Zurich. I was holding on to this one incase a miracle happened and I found the lost shoe. Well, after seeing this shoe covered in slug slime I decided no miracle would happen any longer. I threw the shoe out as soon as I could. Bye bye brand new runners
column480:
>

One again I was biking on bike paths all day. Biking between towns in Switzerland is so dang easy. I followed a sign that said “bike to Basel” for around 80 kilometres to Basel.
column483:
>

Adam slept somewhere in Zurich the night before on the riverbank of the Rhine. He was aready on route to Basel when I woke up that morning. My plan was to see him there at the end of the day.
column486:
>

We went to Basel to visit our friend Julia we met in Greece months earlier.
column487: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column492:
>

Julia, our swiss friend we met in south greece.
column495:
>

If you don’t remember her, we met each other in Greece about a month ago in Mani, Peloponnese. (See the blog post named Coincidence Cafe (https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/19-coincidence-caf)).
column498:
>

to be honest, I didnt think I would ever make it to Basel, but it worked out not being difficult to get there and directly on the path I wanted to take.
column501:
>

Okay back to Switzerland…
column502: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column507:
>

On the road to Basel
column510:
>

I arrived in Basel and met up with Adam by the Rhine river (which runs through Basel too). We started to eat some food we bad bought from the grovery store.
column513:
>

We sat there and ate some food. Julia was busy so we were killing some time till the evening when she would be free and we could meet up.
column514: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column519:
>

Sitting by the river in basel
column525:
>

A friendly swiss girl around our age walked by with her bike and started talking to us.
column528:
>

She was around our age, from Basel, and was after a short conversation we became friends and decided we would all float down the Rhine together.
column531:
>

Here in Basel the Rhine is a long river that flows through the entire city. Many people start some point up the river and float down for a kilometre or so before getting out. We wanted to try it.
column534:
>

In order to do this we had to get a floaty sack to put our valuables. In so we didn’t leave them up the river unattended.
column537:
>

To solve this problems, Batina (our new friend) said we could go to her apartment close by to store ours stuff and grab the float sack for valuables and clothes.
column540:
>

We then biked with her through Basel to her apartment.
column541: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column549:
>

After this we went back to the Rhine and floated down the river.
column552:
>

I was in shock that after 15 minutes in Basel, Adam and I had once again met a stranger who took us on a little advetnure in their city. After 25 minutes, we were in somones appartment getting the river floaties. After 45 minutes, we were all fully submerged in the river floating down with the current through Basel.
column555:
>

They water was 20 degrees according to the sign so it was not that cold, but not as warm as the beaches I had last swam in in Italy.
column558:
>

We got a nice tour of Basel. Floating down the river you see it a little differently…
column561:
>

Maybe after 10 minutes floating we left the river and walked back to our bikes upstream… Then we grabbed our things from the apartment and invited Betina to dinner with us and Julia (our friend who lived in Basel that we met in Greece).
column564:
>

We all met up and spent an awesome evening together.
column565: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column573:
>

I said this yesterday but Switzerland is so expensive! I paid 30 Franks for a small burrito and they gave me a 7 frank bottle of water without asking me…. It was tasty but that was the most expensive burrito I have ever had.
column576:
>

Adam and I stayed in Julias appartment that night. She had a couch and blow up mattresses for Adam and I :). Had an early night since Julia is a nurse and worked the next morning.
column579:
>

First day in Basel was lovely :)
column580: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column591:
>

Erik

column426: > #67 - My phone is fixed - Leaving Zurich.
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

Hey I didnt forget about this dont worry. MORE chronicals are coming.
column468: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column473:
>

25Km, Zurich to some bush in the forest…
column476:
>

We left off the last post on August 1st, national swiss day, with a long 170km bike day in the rain, a broken iphone, and the 1 in a 100,000 chance of bumping into Adam in Zurich just after I had left him in the Alps a few days before due to his injury.
column479:
>

I woke up in house of my dear cycling/doctor friends, Lukas and his girlfriend. I enjoyed an amazing sleep in in a nice bed. A comfortable change from the nights in the mountains.
column482:
>

I remember Lukas’s girlfriend making me a coffee before I left for the day.
Lukas the night before had helped me write down detailed instructions for how to get to an iPhone repair store without google maps. I had written them all down in my journal and memorized them. “Go to the lake, 5 bridged up from the lake, to the left there are 6 iphone repair shops”

It was easy to find! Who needs GPS navigation anyway?
column485:
>

The service was great, it was an apple store. They said they cold change the phone with only a slight risk that the phone would be completley wiped.
column488:
>

In those four hours I biked around Zurich without my phone, I found a quiet place at the university of Zurich where I took a lovely nap on some grass. When I woke up from the nap I realized I lost one of my running shoes somewhere in town… It was extra disapointing because i had just bought them new for this trip. Oh well, no more shoes for me.
column491:
>

I only had one shoe left which I decided I would carry with me until I fully left Zurich just incase another miracle happened and I found the other.
column494:
>

I went back to the repair shop to find that they changed the screen out and gave it back to me fully repaired. Good as new… and I still had all my trip photos.
column497:
>

Once it was fixed I slowly started biking out of Zurich to Basel.
column500:
>

Leaving Zurich I biked along the river, the people who live in Zurich frequently swim in the river and float down it, jumping off the bridges. It looked like a very peaceful way to spend a summer day. I would have tried it but I felt a rush to get moving and leave the city.

I continued along the gravel of the river and felt very very tired and low energy. I thought I could make it at least half way to Basel (about 90 km to basel) but about 15 km into biking beside the river, I got tired and found a place to camp, cooked, watched an italian TV show on Netflix and slept.
column503:
>

In Switzerland wild camping is illegal… So I hid in a bush off the cycling path where no one could see me.
column504: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column509:
>

My smiling after my phone was fixed.
column510: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column516: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column522: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column528: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column533:
>

Hiding in a bush to sleep
column536:
>

That’s All for now folks.

-Erik

column426: > #66 - When everything goes wrong, what do you do? Life ain&#39
column434: > August 1st
column435: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: ><div style=""height:1px
column461: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column462: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column465:
>

Hey people,

August 1st was the hardest day of my whole trip.
column467: word-break:break-word
column468:
>

It pushed me to the edge in both mind and body…
column471:
>

The funny part was it was pretty much self inflicted and I chose to feel this pain today.
column474:
>

I mean I didnt have to do it, at any point I could have stopped and camped earlier.
column477:
>

I was ON A MISSION.
column480:
>

well lets get into it.
column481: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column489:
>

I woke up on top of the mountain pass.
column491: ><table align=""center"" width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none"" style=""max-width:520px
column495: ><table width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""width:100%
column506: >
column521: > I woke up on top of the mountain pass.
column524:
>

It wasn’t as cold as I thought sleeping at the top of the mountain. Even without cuddle buddies I was warm all night. I think it might have gotten down to 4 or 3 degrees at night. I was sleeping beside this rock that sheltered me from the wind.
column527:
>

I woke up early and saw there was some light rain, I waited and waited. When it stopped, I quickly packed up and I went down the mountain descent.
column530:
>

CRAZY decent. Here is the video, I think I finally figured out the descent filming angle.
column532: ><table align=""center"" width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none"" style=""max-width:520px
column536: ><table width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""width:100%
column547: >
column562: > Decending 7000 feet on a bike.
column565:
>

I biked and biked all day. It poured rain on me for most of the day.
column568:
>

Once I was in Switzerland, I noticed some things:
column579: > So many bike tourists! I went from never seeing them to spotting about 30 in one day. I talked to many of them, and they are all from Switzerland and all do mini bike tours around the country.
column582: > Most of the gas stations don’t sell food like in Canada. They sell cars! The gas stations are also car dealerships.
column585: > Switzerland is incredibly expensive. Prices of food items doubled compared to Italy. At restaurants, you pay at least 20 Swiss francs for cheap food. (1 franc is more a bit more than 1 euro)
column588: > Switzerland has amazing intercity bike routes. You can get around by bike so easily. I was biking on protected bike paths 80% of the time.
column594:
>

Hey remember my good old friend from Greece? Not Alex the chess master, not the Patras friends.
column597:
>

The bike tourist I met on the start of the trip! The guy with the dog stick who I met who I thought was Kai. The paper map guy…
column600:
>

The SAME guy that we saw 1 month into the trip AGAIN in Ioannina, Greece on the border of Albania.
column603:
>

WELL his name was Lukas and I messaged him on Whatsapp. He was from Zurich.
column606:
>

Around 30 km into the ride, messaged him to see if he was around.

Turns out he was! He invited me to stay with him and his girlfriend'
column607: s apartment for the night. The only problem was I needed to get to Zurich for that, which was another 137 km away.
column610:
>

I decided to go for it. I MADE it a mission to get to Zurich. I would ride ALL day.
column613:
>

PHOTO INTERMISSION (Before hell breaks loose):
column614: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column619:
>

gravel roads for kilometres and kilometers
column620: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column625:
>

Lake where I ate lunch
column626: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column631:
>

Little does he know how terrible it will become.
column632: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column637:
>

You know I was screaming happily in this tunnel. Amazing echos.
column640:
>

It was a mentally challenging ride since it rained the whole time.
column643:
>

At around the 130km mark out of 170 km, something tragic happened.
column646:
>

My cellphone fell out of my pocket, and I ran over it with my bike. I heard a loud crunch. yup….
column649:
>

I stopped, in the rain, picked up my phone to check the damage, and it was entirely broken. I couldn'
column650: t use the screen at all. Thankfully, I could use Siri and called my Swiss friend, Lukas, and told him. He gave me a spot to meet him in Zurich.
column653:
>

So now I had about 50 km left to bike without using GPS. It wasn'
column654: t that bad, actually. I just followed the massive lake beside Zurich the entire way and didn&#39
column655: t need maps at all. One time I remember to stop to talk to three swiss germans. I asked if which way was Zurich and they looked at me with the bike and thought I was crazy…
column658:
>

I stopped to ask for directions a few more times.
column661:
>

Every kilomiter hurt, I had given into the pain. I stopped to go to the washroom once and lost my warm blue snowboarder hat I had bought in the alps. That stung…
column664:
>

I got to Zurich.
column667:
>

Eventually, I arrived at the meeting spot.
column670:
>

It was a festival to celebrate Switzerland Day on August 1st!
column673:
>

At the start of the trip in Greece the swiss people I met TOLD me that it was a good day to be in Switzerland since it was their national holiday, I never believed I would make it but HERE I WAS. Damn.
column676:
>

I met up with Lukas, and we got some food at the festival, and I met his friends.
column679:
>

Then, THE UNBELIEVABLE happened....
column686: s bike there at the festival!
column689:
>

It turns out that completely by accident, Adam and I had found each other in Zurich. We SOMEHOW got to the same TINY (this was a small small festival in Zurich that only really locals knew about) and somehow we both met up there AGAIN.
column692:
>

We met up at the festival and were both shocked that after saying goodbye a day earlier, I had found him there in Zurich. He had taken the train to Zurich through the alps when I had biked over the two mountain passes.
column695:
>

Adam had found his own little magic in the city and didnt need a place to sleep…
column698:
>

After the festival, I went with Lukas to his apartment and met his girlfriend. They let me use the guest room. Both Lukas and his girlfriend were doctors, power couple.
column701:
>

With my phone completely broken, I was still able to take a couple of pictures using Siri.
column702: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column707:
>

He who smiles when everything went to shit. (Photo creds to Siri)
column713:
>

Tomorrow I will get my phone fixed in Zurich.
column714: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column719:
>

Appartment guest room (Broken phone + siri)

column426: > #65 - 2 ups and 2 downs - finally I have brakes that work.
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

Hey yall,
column470:
>

Its been a while since I wrote, I find it hard to sit down and write these now that I am back into the swing of things here in Vancouver (Yes I made it home)
column473:
>

I am going to keep posting tho. little by little. (Plug for my other newsletter here).
column476:
>

Lets get started.
column478: ><table align=""center"" width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none"" style=""max-width:520px
column482: ><table width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""width:100%
column493: >
column508: > Twist and turn: Passio di Stelvio (P1)
column511:
>

I woke up in the morning, at the bottom of the beautiful green valley beneath the passo di stelvio. You can see how we got there in the video above. I didnt edit it its just the raw footage. Email me back to tell me how far you get in the recording. Im curious haha.
column514:
>


Adam and Erik part ways once again…

We woke up nearby the lake in the park. This was the day that Adam and I would be saying goodbye to each other for good. His knee was hurting and he decided he must stop biking. He would continue to Spain in the next few days by train.
column517:
>

We said our goodbyes and continued on. He left the lake side lawn we were relaxing on before and I was left there… All alone. I felt weird in this moment again. I was back to making all the decision.
column520:
>

I stuck around for a while doing home housekeeping. Reorginizing the gear on my bike, throwing out garbage, I watched a youtube video and learnt for the first time how to change the breakpads on my bike. This took my hours and hours as I countly figure out how to tighten a key component. Eventually I figured it out and my brakes became SO MUCH BETTER. I had been strugging with break problems for the entire trip and having new pads made an incredible difference in my ability to stop my bike. I felt more confident again going downhill.
column523:
>

Another house keeping item I took care of was my inflatable sleeping pad. I had a few nights in a row that I would wake up and all the air would be gone. I suspected that there was a leak. Again I was watching youtube videos on how to find a leak. I tried spraying it with soapy water… no luck. I then reluctantly submerged the entire inflated pad in the dirty duck pond water.
column526:
>

I know, I know. I wasnt happy about that either…
column529:
>

Guess what. I was wrong there was no leak at all. I just didnt have the cap securely sealed for the last few nights of sleep. whoops. I washed off the dirty duck pond water the best I could, but I dont think my bed ever smelt the same…
column530: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column535:
>

The Lake where Adam and I seperated.
column538:
>

I biked up a mountain pass in the morning
column539: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column544:
>

Avoiding the highway by taking gravel trails
column547:
>

Incredible views of course. I’m loving the alps.
column550:
>

I entered Switzerland and it felt like the world all the sudden changed. First of all now everyone speaks german to me, I guess I look swiss or german. The other biggest change was the price of everything. I was out of camping fuel so I tried finding some. The only place I could find it was in a camping store.
column553:
>

In greece a can of gas was 4 euro. Here it was 20 euro! And it wasnt even the correct gas type for my stove. Its all I could find so I took it. I need to be able to cook somehow. I could cook with it so I was grateful for that.
column554: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column559:
>

Sitting and waitin for the camping store to open
column562:
>

Now we got into the hard part. Today I had one goal. Go 90 KM. If I made it to 90KM then I would have gotten over two mountain passes each of which reaching over 2200m of elevation
column565:
>

I biked up the first pass. It was hard lol. I can’t even remember what I was thinking this day. I just biked in silence for hours, I remember it being particularly brutal, and feeling slow on the bike.
column568:
>

When I reached the top of the first pass of the day I met a swiss history teacher who was bike backing in the alps for two weeks.

We biked down the first mountain pass together and had some good conversations. Lots of people in switzerland lovve bike touring and bike backing.
column571:
>

These downhills were incredible. The roads were wide and the descents were not too steep so I could go FAST. I loved every second of the downhill.
column574:
>

Its a thing with biking, on the way up you question why the hell you ever decided in the first place to start biking, then on the way down you remember just how awesome it is.
column575: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column583:
>

I ended my day on the top of the second pass. Sleeping at 2300 m of elevation. Tomorrow I will enjoy the decent
column584: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column589:
>

On the way up one of the climbs
column592:
>

I convinced myself I need to get to Paris and hurry up my trip. I only have about two weeks left. I am on a mission to bike to Paris in the next 4 days. For me it’s go go go mode. (its 800km to paris…)
column593: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column601:
>

I went down and said goodbye to my new swiss biker friend. It was nice riding with him for a little bit. I got to the base of the second mountain pass at 6pm. It would probably take me 4 hours to get to the top of this climb. AKA I would have to somehow sleep up on the top of this mountain, or go down a bit to find a place.
column604:
>

I just decided to go for it. I started climbing and climbing the mountain. This was a steep climb and long. About 16km and 1100 metres of climbing.
column607:
>

I kept climbing and sun kept going down and lower.
column608: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column613:
>

The valley below the pass.
column616:
>

It was beautiful.
column617: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column622:
>

The sun kept going down
column625:
>

Eventually I got the the point where it was cold and dark, and I still seemly had a ways to go till the top.
column628:
>

I made the choice to stop and cook on the side of the road in the dark. I made… what did I make? I think some quinia and some zuchinni. I was so hungry, cold, and tired. During the day I was fueled on bread and cheese, and I rad run out.
column631:
>

I finished and continued biking in the dark to the top of the mountain.
column634:
>

eventually I determined I had arrived at the top, and I was best off sleeping there and leaving early in the morning. Going down the mountain in the dark probably was not the best idea.
column637:
>

I set up my tent at the top of the pass and had one of my favourite bootleg camping spots, maybe 10m away from the road over a little ridge that protected me from lign of the site of the road.
column638: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column643:
>

Iphone’s night camera (pitch black at night sleeping at the top of the pass)
column646:
>

I set up my camp in the dark with my new headlamp (I forgot to mention I bought one in the camping store with the fuel).
column649:
>

That was awesome having a headlamp.
column650: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column655:
>

Where I put my tent during the night. The rock protected me from the wind.
column658:
>

Sleeping up here felt wild and beautiful. Afterwards I felt like I could do anything i set my mind to.
column661:
>

Thats all for now.

column426: > #64 - The highest mountain pass in Europe
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

Morning wake up sleeping on the park bench.
column465: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: >
column470:
>

Waking up at the park bench
column473:
>

It protected us from rain all night. I remember that Adam was complaining since the only hole in the roof happened to be right above where he was sleeping. He was slightly dripped on by the water all night long.
column476:
>

The beautiful think about camping in the alps is that there are no mosquitoes! Atleast here when it was raining. I got zero bug bites. I think I only would find them near the thick thick forests but this park and most places didnt have them.
column479:
>

When we woke up in the morning and were cleaning up our camp and an italian man appeared (as they usually did) and came to us and asked us if we slept there.
column482:
>

At first I wasnt sure if he would be angry or was just curious but before I could think what to say Adam blurted out a “yes we slept there” last night.
column485:
>

Turns out he was not angry at all. He was kind and curoius about our adventure. After a short conversation he invited us for coffee in his nearby horse stable… It turns out the man owned a stable right beside the public park.
column488:
>

Then we met his horse.
column489: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column497:
>

We enjoyed a nice conversation. He only spoke Italian so I did most of the talking, but Adam’s spanished seemed to help him undertsand atleast 70% of what we were saying. I would transalte when he looked really confused.

After a pleasent coffee conversation talking about the history of the town we were in and the park we stayed in (that he had seen being built since his family owned that land for multiple generations), he ended up giving us wine at the end and sparking water after the coffee.
column498: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column503:
>

The wine in the hut (we took it with us)
column506:
>

We have a picture of the hut below. He also offered for us to stay in the hut if we needed a place to stay that night. We politely declined since we were ready to climb the next mountain later this day.
column507: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column512:
>

his little hut beside the stable.
column513: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column518:
>

his horse roaming the park
column521:
>

After this we set off to the hotspring we were told about the other day. It was a decisous for us - rest another day in bormio and sit in a hotsprint all day, or just leave over the stelvio pass.
column524:
>

We did the third and worst option… Dehydrate ourselves for a few hours in the hotspring THEN go up the longest and highest road climb in europe (30km climb 1400m up the entire time).
column527:
>

We showed up at the hotspring and took the advice we got to bike the opposite side of the river and walk across. It turned out to be a great tip since the usual trail is not possible to ride your bike on. The water temperatue was about 40 degrees, powered by some thermal vents, and there was a nice cold river to the side of it so we cycled hot and cold submerssion for an hour and a bit.
column528: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column533:
>

Biking along the river to the hotspring( See next photo)
column534: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column541:
>

And of course we ate cake and the gifted sparking water in the hot springs, we did not open the sparkling wine we were given, we wanted to save that for when we got to the top of the mountain later in the day.
column542: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column547:
>

Eating cake in the hotspring
column551: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column559:
>

After this we started the biggest climb I have ever done. Stelvios pass. It’s the highest bike pass in Europe with an elevation of 2988 metres at the top of the pass.
column562:
>

It was a tough climb - especailly after hottubing. My legs were dead from the beginning hahaha. I was tired from the hiking two days before and we also had decided for some silly reason to go a pretty fast pace. Adam and I had a little competition for who can lead up the hill.
column563: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column568:
>

On the way up
column571:
>

We went up and up and it was absolutely stunning.
column572: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column579:
>

We didn’t take many breaks.
column580: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column585:
>

The million switchbacks we climbed
column586: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column591:
>

There were photogrophers who sell you the photo after. He didnt buy my photo of him.
column594:
>

When we got to the top we drank the wine and we were given and we cooked a nice meal. I took a nap in the sun in the peak. I was surprised how many stores they had at the top of the pass. I suppose since it is so famous for the Giro Di Italia and being so high up it attracts a lot of tourists and adventurers.
column595: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column600: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column605:
>

a cool building up there.
column606: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column611:
>

Us right before going down hill (about 3 or 4 degrees up there)
column614:
>

After that we descended the mountain. It was 45 minutes of riding downhill! Incredible. A windy decent for 35 kilomiters with an incredible view the entire time of the mountain valley below.
column617:
>

I filmed it all with the GoPro and it will one day be published. Its a long video I wont edit it since I dont have space on my computer to edit a video of such a size. I will just upload the raw footage to youtube soon :)
column620:
>

After the climb Adams knee started hurting really bad. He’s decided he needs a longer break from biking and will be taking the train from the nearest train station. We had 5 nights travelling together and this will probably be the last time I see him until I am back in Vancouver.
column623:
>

We then went to the train station to help Adam figure out where he needs to go.
column626:
>

After this we went for pizza :)
column629:
>

We looked in the map and found a park with a large forest area.
column632:
>

It was really easy to find a quiet camping spot.
column633: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column638:
>

We campled near hear in a bush lol.

column426: > #63 - A rest day in Bormio
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

A rest day!
column470:
>

Adam needs to rest his knee and finally my legs are sore. Hiking hits different. Then hiking with the bike hits even more.
column473:
>

I feel like I just trained legs in the gym for the first time with the classic pins and needles. Everything is sore.
column476:
>

I had a few errands to run around town aswell. I needed to buy an iPhone charger since the trail broke my 2 dollar one i bought in a dollar store.
column479:
>

In the morning we got hungry and went to a grocery store. After we bought some food we sat down on a bench we found to cook and eat.
column482:
>

Once we finished eating and were cleaning up an italian man came out of a building nearby and yelled at us for eating on his bench! It was a bench in an empy parking lot and he got mad that we used it… He was yelling in english first but when we said we are sorry in italian he seemed to calm down…
column485:
>

We didnt leave any kind of mess there but the funnies part was in frusteration the italian men picked up a pinecone and threw it in the bush as if we had left the pinecone there from our cooking.
column488:
>

It started to rain and we hung out in a restaruatn for a while…
column491:
>

Eventually we moved to the library. I borrowed the librarieans phone to call Air France to sort out a flight issue.
column494:
>

I had the worst time on the phone with them, hold for hours, they kept transfering me to talk to other people.
column497:
>

THis went on and on until the library closed and I was unable to resolve my problem. I did not use my own phone since it costs me 25 dollars to phone per day. I decided I had to deal with this problem in person in Paris.
column500:
>

breifly the problem I have a flight from Valencia, Spain to Paris, then to Vancouver. I ran out of time to bike down to Valencia so I want to just fly from Paris instead and skip the first leg of my flight. On the phone they think this is not possible and bounced me around for hours - hence i decided I will just go to paris to handle it.
column503:
>

In the evening we went back to the park from the day before.
column506:
>

In a conversation with a Italian/Spanish family we were told about another natural hotscript in Bormio! We decided the next day before we leave Bormio we would go and check it out.
column507: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column512:
>

Cooking dinner at the park
column515:
>

This time it was raining big time. Our solution… we slept under cover on some picnic tables.
column516: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column521:
>

Sleeping on picnic tables (morning after)

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

First of all….
column470:
>


Here is the link to my new youtube channel! I will slowly post all the videos of my trip and link them to remaining newsletters.

https://www.youtube.com/@ErikOnABike/videos

Stay tuned... The first video makes an apperence in the newsletter.

If you already forgot, we slept here last night at the top of some mountain in the Italian Alps ….
column471: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column479:
>

I woke up several times in the night, we slept with the door half open for the view. Each time I woke up, I took a glance through the half open door at the stars. All the coulds had decided to sleep for the night aswell and were nestled beside all the peaks and ridges. It felt like we slept above a planet, I say “a planet” since it felt like we had left earth at this point since the terrain looked so different.
column482:
>

The first thing we did in the morning was do the hike down the ridge. Going down was much more scary than going up. The ridge as you may have seen in the photos is not very wide and has cliffs on both sides. I was doing my best to follow the rule “don’t look down”.
column485:
>

The nice part was all the ground was frozen. So all the loose rocks on yersterdays climb were frozen together and we could walk down sections that were impossible the day before in the afternoon sun.
column488:
>

Below is a picture of the glacier that was to our left all night. I really liked this picture I took on the way down so I wanted to share it.
column489: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column495: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column500:
>

We stopped for lunch and made coffee with water from the glacier
column503:
>

When we woke in the morning we had drank all the water we brought. As a matter of fact, we didnt bring much water initially. In total for the 5 km (each way), 1000 metres elevation hour hike we brought 2 litres of water. This included for cooking and drinking on the hike. Kai only hiked with an empty coffee mug!
column506:
>

The reason for not bringing much water was because we suspected that we could drink the run off water from the glaciers we would be hiking beside.
column509:
>

So in the morning we made coffee and breakfast from the water flowing off the glacier :). All the water we drank tasted much better and more fresh than any tap water I have ever had.
column512:
>

Eventually we got down the trail and made it back to the bikes.
column513: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column518:
>

This is where we left our bikes overnight. It was hidden from sight. I dont think people could steal the bikes if they tried. I took alot of effort and pushing to get them there…
column521:
>

We then started on the trails.
column524:
>

The trails were insane…. Many parts were impossible to ride on the bike. Some parts were even difficult to WALK with my bike. I filmed this on the Gopro and I started the process of uploaded the vidoes.
column527:
>

About 30 minutes into riding the trails I was going over a difficult section and I was foced to put a lot of force onto the pedals to stay on the trail. I ran over this rock on the trail and suddly it became impossible to pedal my bike.
column530:
>

I had bent my brand new small the chainring on the bike. The chainring is the front gear that connects to the pedals.
column533:
>

I was no longer able to pedal. We managed to bend it enough to where I could pedal in the big gear only. This made all the hills I had to climb really difficult. I would have to get it fixed in the next town or I would probably end up being stuck in the Alps. It would be impossible to climb over mountain passes without the small front gear.
column536:
>

The the trails leaving proved to be challengeing… rocks, narrow trail, and my broken bike.
column539:
>

Heres a video of part of the trail.
column541: ><table align=""center"" width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none"" style=""max-width:520px
column545: ><table width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""width:100%
column556: >
column571: > Riding my gravel bike in Italian Alps Trails
column575: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column580: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column588:
>

And then we biked down a red mountain bike trail. I say we biked. but only Kai could ride it as it was too difficult for my bike. It was extremely steep and rocky. I gave Kai the go pro camera and he filmed it. This will be on the youtube channel soon.
column590: ><table align=""center"" width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none"" style=""max-width:520px
column594: ><table width=""100%"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""none""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""width:100%
column605: >
column620: > Part 1 - Passo Di Gavia - Kai on a red mountain bike trail in the Italian Alps
column623:
>

The way down was brutal. It took Adam and I few hours to go just that kilometre. We had to hike down with the bike for most of it and we were left very sore afterwards. There were small parts we could ride…
column626:
>

Eventually we got to the bottom and biked down the rest of the decent on the main road.
column629:
>

When we arrived in Bormio we went for icecream and beer. We used the 20 dollars the Romanian guy gave us the day before and send him a picture saying thanks.
column630: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column635:
>

icecream after surviving the trails
column638:
>

After icecream Adam and I said our final goodbye to Kai. He had to go visit some friends in the evening and he left us in Bormio. Adam and I needed some rest.
column641:
>

I then started on my quest to fix my bike. I went around to all 5 bike stores in Bormio. With each bike store I visited my hope for fixing the part diminished. They all took one look at the bike and told me they would not have this part.
column644:
>

Finally I went to the last bike store in the town. The bike mechanic did not have the part but he did not give up on my like others.
column647:
>

We went together put it on the bike stand and took off the broken part. The mechanic took a hammer and a clamp and bent the chainring back straight. Its aluminim and not ment to be bent back (this metal gets much weaker after a first initial failure), and it was not perfectly straight… But I went outside the bike shop to test it and it seemed to work… We will see if it holds.
column650:
>

I then met up with Adam for pizza. Bike seemed to be doing fine with the fix, thought I had lost confidence in my gears holding and was being very gentil with my bike.
column653:
>

The day ended with us eating in a pizza restaurant. The waiter gave us alot of sass. He got mad at us for drinking tap water. They said if we wanted water we had to BUY it.
column656:
>

We then went to find a place to sleep in the forest and found a lovely park off a trail a bit out from the city.
column659:
>

Bormio is beautiful and tomorrow we will rest here. Adam’s knee is really hurting him.
column662:
>

Below are some more pictures…
column663: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column669: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column674:
>

We found a bread vending machine!
column675: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column680:
>

The camp spot for the night.
column686:
>

Bye for now,
column689:
>

Erik

column426: > #61 - WTF. The hut at the top of the mountain.
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column462: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467:
>

The trails we will bike down the next day.
column470:
>

Holy smokes everyone,
column473:
>

This day was probaby the single best day of the trip… (I wouldnt say best daysss (plural) but single best day probably (probably…))
column476:
>

I was trying so hard to put to words what I felt up here and here is what I came up with.
column479:
>

Pure bliss and happiness. Like I was heaven. The ultimate dopamine rush from the view.
column482:
>

So what did we do?
column485:
>

We decided to hike up the mountain, leave our bikes, and sleep at 3600 metres of elevation between two glaciers in a hut we saw on the map.
column488:
>

We knew nothing about the hut, where it was or what it looked liked. So we packed light sleeping gear, sleeping bags, and a blow up bed just in case.
column491:
>

It would probably be well well below zero at this elevation but inside a hut will be much warmer than a tent…
column494:
>

We hiked up the mountain. We hiked along snow and the glacier…
column500:
>

Things that happen on the hike….
column511: > People looked at us like we were crazy when we said we were going to the hut
column514: > People saying the hut is REALLY hard to get to…
column517: > We saw the hut and it was at the top of a ridge that looked really hard to climb too (if you look at the photos carefully you will see…)
column520:
>

Take a look at the photos.
column522:
>

CLICK THIS LINK TO VIEW ALL THE PHOTOS

column532:
/>

July 27th

211 new items added to shared album
column535: >photos.app.goo.gl/BemMqRJiB7FRth2f9
column544:
>

If you follow this link you will see all the Photos and videos from this day. I loved them all so I couldnt select which ones to share here.
column547:
>

TO get a real understanding of where we went take a look at the videos that I took from the hut at the top of the mountain.
column550:
>

We slept the night above the clouds… wowza.
column557: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column562:
>

Thinking about life…

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

I am finally coming back to write about the rest of the trip. I took a long break from posting. Currently I am back at home, on a family vacation now just outside of Gambier Island just outside of Vancouver.
column470:
>

I have a computer now and and I have no excuse for not posting the rest of these. I have the pictures, the GPS ride data, and my quickly journal entries from the trip.
column473:
>

So lets get into it. Last time if you dont remember I had met up with Kai and Adam in the Alps. Ponte di Legno… I had survived sleeping in a house filled with unexploded bombs and reuinited with friends I was ready to explore some mountains.
column474: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column482:
>

We woke up in the park refreshed and ready to go. Today was going to be a big day. We planned on going to the top of the mountain pass and sleeping somehwere at the top. We saw some trails on the map. Of course, Adam and I’s bikes dont have much trail traversing capability - so we had no idea if we could do the trails on our bikes. We were going to try anyway…
column485:
>

First things first, it was going to be cold up there. The weather forcased said it would be 4 degrees in Ponto Di Legno. The top of the pass was another 1200 metres higher so we were expecting sub zero temperatures.
column488:
>

Fortunatly there was a market in town open and I was able to buy a nice puffy jacket to keep my warm if it got colder at night.
column489: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column497:
>

Next thing we did was go back to the bar for some coffee. I got the largest cappuchino of my life… I asked for a double and they brought me it in a giant bowl
column498: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column503:
>

Look at that large cappuchino!
column506:
>

After coffee and some partries we made breakfast number two, egg sandwiches.
column507: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column512:
>

the town of Ponto Di Legno…
column515:
>

We started our way up the climb and it was incredible. It was very difficult and steep, but I was well rested and felt fresh…
column518:
>

The views were amazing all the way up. This was the most spectacular riding in the Alps that I had done.
column519: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column524: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column532:
>

Half way up the ride we stopped for lunch with an incredible mountain view. Across the road there were some construction workers.
column535:
>

We heard them yell something at us in italian.
column542: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column547:
>

Drinking wine in our cups with our lunch view.
column550:
>

They were shouting wine at us and offereing us wine to drink. So we invited them over and they gave us wine as we ate lunch in the middle of our mountain climb.
column553:
>

Sitting there and eating lunch, we all felt like we were in heaven. We made some coffee and ate delicious bread, cheese, greek salad. The view, the food, and the wine was all so wonderful.
column554: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column559: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column564:
>

the lunch spot with coffee
column567:
>

We continued on the ride with more unreal views…
column568: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column574: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column579:
>

finding some gravel to bypass a tunnel
column582:
>

Eventually we got to the top and there were building refuges for travellers at the top of the pass. You could rent a room or buy a snack. We had no need for either since we had food and a tent so we didnt stay around.
column585:
>

However even at this point of the day it was very cold at the top. About 3 or 4 degrees. I wanted to buy some gloves from the people in the refuge.
column588:
>

I tried to negotiate the price of the gloves. 20 euroes! for some crappy gloves. I only wanted them to move down to $15 and they would not budge on their prices.
column591:
>

I left the refugee with cold hands…
column594:
>

We continued on, we had a couple more metres to ride before we got to the trail we were going to take to find a place to sleep.
column597:
>

Then I see another refuge house. I went in and asked if they had gloves…
column600:
>

They didnt think so but they went to check. Moments later they came back out saying they dont have it.
column603:
>

Then I told them why I wanted gloves - we were going to sleep up there.
column606:
>

They looked at me like I was crazy and warned us that it would be especially cold tonight. It was frozen solid up there the last few nights.
column609:
>

I think they felt bad and looked again for gloves for me. They did not want me to freeze.
column612:
>

The came back with a snowboarding toque and gloves.
column615:
>

I said, “how much? $15 for the gloves?”
column618:
>

They responded with. NO no no… 5 for the gloves and 5 for the hat….
column621:
>

So by going just 100 metres down the road to the other refuge, I got a hat and the exact same gloves for half the price!
column624:
>

I was very happy and warm when we started riding down the trails in the valley.
column625: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column633:
>

Riding in the trails was intenseeee. There were times where I COULD NOT FALL or I would probably die. Since to one side was a cliff. The trails were rough but possible for Adam and I. More mental focus is required. I always love getting off the roads with cars…
column636:
>

I have this all on go-pro footage and one day will figure out how to post it. Should I edit the footage or just post all the raw footage? What do you think?
column639:
>

After expereincing pure joy and happiness in incredible trails with amazing views in the valley we got to a place we decided to camp.
column640: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column648:
>

We cooked some food, pesto pasta and after tomato pasta. We then set up one tent. We were going to sleep all in Kai’s tent. We thought it would be cold and three people in one tent would help us all stay warmer. Again my sleeping bag is only rated for +7 degrees and it would reach below 0 degrees…
column651:
>

I put on all the clothes I brought with me. I had 3 shirts on, my sweaters and jackets, and all my pants and shorts.
column654:
>

We slept the night and it was nice and warm. In the midde of the night I looked out the tent to see everything was frozen and white. It got below zero for sure at some point. I still don’t know how cold it got.
column657:
>

This was a fantastic day and once again I said out loud. “This is the best day yet, I never want to leave the Alps, Okay I will spend the rest of my trip here”
column660:
>

As always stay tuned to see if I ever leave the Alps.
column663:
>

This time I wont make you wait a month for the next post.
column664: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column669:
>

The camp site (we pushed our bikes to the top of a cliff near the trail)
column670: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column678:
>

By for now!
column681:
>

Con amore,
Erik

column467: text-align:start
column474: >In the morning I got breakfast with the bomber guy. As i said, despite the strange hobby, he is a nice guy.
column482: >I paid for this breakfast but the barman gave it to us all for free.
column490: >Then I went to a park nearby and watched Netflix on a park chair. I sat in the sun, cooked food and slept with an incredible views. I felt like I needed a rest day, but also if I waited in Ponte di Legno, a special surprise was coming…
column498: >I waited and waited for hours in the park.
column514: >Adam and Kai showed up at the park (yes we planned this)
column515: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column527: >I had beers and pastries ready for their arrival.
column532: >We sat by the river with an incredible view of the mountains. Kai and Adam went for a swim in the cold cold river while we still had sun.
column540: >We drank beers, talked about all our stories of travels.
column548: >Kai spending a month in the mountains, the Dolomites.
column556: >Adam biked through Albania, Montenegro, Kosovo, and Croatia.
column564: >There were so many crazy stories and we talk for hours. We all thought back to the beautiful luck it took to first meet Kai and Alex in Greece.
column572: >Once again we reminded ourselves of the beauty of travelling by bicycle.
column580: >We went for pizza at the same restaurant I went to do the deforme to hide from the rain, and at 10 or 11 pm we left to find a place to sleep, back at the park where I had relaxed all day. It was Slightly raining but and we easily found a camping spot in the park nearby. The trees protected us from the rain.
