column467: text-align:start
column477: >I woke up in the morning and I wasn’t too cold in the night. The temperature went down to about 7°C. And with all my clothes on and sleeping bag, I was warm all night.
column485: >I’m curious to see what’s the coldest temperature I can withstand before gets really uncomfortable.
column493: >It’s getting colder up here in the alps in the next couple days. It’s gonna reach down to 3° even at lower elevation.
column501: >Let’s see how I do with my tent .
column509: >After a lot of climbing out of the day before I just took it easy. I rode on the top of the mountain all morning. It was raining on and off.
column517: >For a while, I sat in the mountains .
column525: >I had a beautiful Campspot last night, but if I just biked another kilometre I would’ve had an incredible view of the mountains even better than the one I had.
column533: >When I was wet and it was windy, it got pretty cold. There was no sun and at this elevation 2000 m. It was about 10°C at the warmest part of the day.
column541: >I feel just like at home in Vancouver . Wet, rainy, and cold biking.
column549: >The ride is actually so beautiful. The mountains in insanely impressive to see.
column557: >This was probably one of the coolest routes to bike down just because I was high up it is. The great part is there so many more opportunities for rides like this. Rides even better than this.
column565: >I took a few pretty photos.
column573: >I felt as if I was in a very remote area and then I stumbled across this little house. They sold cheese. They had this tiny little church on the edge of the cliff. It made for epic photo.
column581: >I think this is probably one of the best photos of ever taken at least one of my favourite photos.
column582: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column594: >When I passed by, I ask if they also sell coffee.
column602: >They said they don’t they just sell cheese. But, since it was raining and freezing cold, they invited me in for coffee anyway.
column610: >I accepted the offer. I went into their small mountain home and we talked about my trip and where I should go in the alps and I got to see what it’s like in a little mountain home in northern Italy.
column618: >Once it stopped raining, I left their house. And of course, another 20 minutes in fog and rain came again to block my view.
column626: >I quickly got to the descent, which I did in the rain. I arrived at little village called Monno. Once again to avoid the rain I went to a bar. And I sat in this bar for maybe five hours I kept ordering food and coffee and chatting with the staff. There was no one else there.
column634: >Finally, I left the bar and continued down the descent and recorded a beautiful GoPro video of the decent. I will one day upload if I have Internet.
column642: >Then, and I arrived at my destination Ponte di lengo.
column650: >A small village in between two mountain passes. the Tonale pass and the Gavia pass.
column658: >Both are huge mountain climbs. One to 2600 metres high, the other 2200.
column666: >The next day I would go one of these mountain passes.
column674: >When I got to Ponte di legno it was raining hard, and there was thunder and lightning.
column682: >I went to a pizzeria for three or four hours until 10 o’clock I ate two pizzas. The sun had set. It was still raining., and I had no idea where I was going to sleep.
column690: >These are always the moments that are most fun for me. Everything seems to happen when it’s late at night dark and you still don’t know where you’re going to sleep.
column698: >The guy at the pizza shop asked me where I’m going to sleep. I told him I don’t know yet. Then I asked if he knew a place that maybe was protected from the heavy rain. He recommended I go to the bus station.
column706: >I thought that’s probably not gonna work…
column714: >But I told him thank you and after I left the pizzeria, I decided to give it a try anyway.
column722: >I biked in the dark down the road to the bus station.
column730: >I couldn’t find it. I’d like to pass it three times.
column738: >Finally I arrived, and there wasn’t really much. Just a coffee shop/bar.
column746: >I walked in and asked the guy at the bar, if you knew a place where I could sleep that was covered because it was raining and there was thunder, and about 7° or 8° outside.
column754: >He really had no idea. It was clear that I couldn’t sleep in the station. It wasn’t set up like this.
column762: >Then incomes this guy… now how do I describe him?
column770: >He was missing a tooth, he was missing a finger, and he seemed a little crazy at first. Maybe he had a bit to drink already.
column778: >I’m pretty open minded guy, but his appearance initially startled me a bit. And also the reaction of the barman, and how the barren behaved regarding him.
column786: >But the man said I could sleep in his home on the couch. He was with his other friend.
column794: >This seems like a good option, but I need to find out more about this guy because his appearance actually made me think this would not be a good idea.
column802: >We talked about his family what he does all the stuff casually. I didn’t hear any red flags.
column810: >He wanted to stay at the bar and keep drinking - then he said he could show me where he lives and I could stay there while he goes back to the bar.
column818: >So we walk together and kept talking. After our conversations, I came conclusion that this was probably a low risk. He had other family members living in the house. The barman knew him his friend seem like a nice guy.
column826: >His house was very close to the bar.
column842: >Turns out he lives in the basement. To get in the house you go around the back. So we carried my bike down the stairs.
column850: >Then, when we open the door and go to his house, I was once again worried.
column858: >The first thing I see, is loads and loads of weapons on the walls, knives, guns, grenades. I’m thinking what the hell am I doing? But of course I ask about them
column863: >. I’m ready to get out of here fast.
column871: >But it turns out all these weapons are actually first world war relics. Antique weapons from World War I.
column879: >This calms me a bit. Then he shows me the real collection. Holly smokes it’s like 100 bombs and grenades on the wall.
column887: >I was shocked to say the least.
column895: >Then he told me HE found these all himself.
column903: >His hobby is he takes a metal detector, hikes in the Alps for weeks and finds old war weapons and equipment. When he finds grenades and bombs he HIMSELF defuses them…. And he taught himself how to defuse these bombs.
column911: >He explained to me how he defuses them and I almost lost it. I was actually equally impressed as I was startled.
column919: >I decided to stay, which only a 2/10 chance I get murdered in the night. Figuring that murdering me didn’t make much sense with all the witnesses.
column927: >My then only real danger was one of these many hand grenades or bombshell blows up…. But he said he had been doing this for 16 years and he’s only lost one finger (unrelated to exploding bombs)
column935: >Anyway. I was careful not to knock anything over.
column940: >I had two options… sleep next to a bomb or sleep in 7 degrees and pouring rain…
column956: >I write it like this but the guy was actually very sweet as I got to know him. He was a little bit crazy, but aren’t we all.
column964: >So just so you know, I survive the night. We actually went for breakfast in the morning. He was super helpful. Help me find a store to buy some pants for when it gets cold again. And we chatted for a while about life.
column969: >That’s all for now,

column467: text-align:start
column474: >Hey I’m skipping ahead. The past week I am not going to write about :) if you want to know what happened you will have to come ask me in person or on the phone one day hehe.
column482: >But briefly there was
column503: >My birthday (wooo). It was fun.
column508: >A week of epic adventures in Genova and two nights at Lake Como.
column516: >I just entered the alps biking from Lake Como.
column521: >I woke up early in lake Como. I was staying in a spare room that a couple had in their apartment building. I bought them wine for letting me stay there. How I found this room is another story. The short story is I met more nice people.
column526: >I woke up at 5:40 AM then biked around lake como. It was a really pleasant ride the whole time.
column531: >After I got 30 km in I took the option to take a small ferry to speed up my journey on the lake. It was 5 euros and I got a boat ride on the lake which was awesome.
column536: >Then I finally entered the Italian Switzerland Alps. It’s soooo pretty.
column544: >I just biked and biked. There is a trail that follows the river that is 100 km long without cars!
column554: >In the evening i got some pizza and relaxed. I quickly went back to the trail and found a place to sleep off the trail.
column559: >That’s all for the 22nd (and the little parts of the time skip)
column567: >Below are some photos from the 14th to 22nd. I have too many to put here but here are a few.

column467: text-align:start
column474: >The highly unpredictable adventure continues….
column485: >I woke up in the ravine beside the creek and I right away noticed I left the tent open. Of course there were about 20 mosquitoes flying around. Some how I only had about 10 new big bites and only on my legs and arms. I got lucky that there were only a few bites.
column493: >I then left the ravine and went into town to meet up with Egita.
column501: >We only had one goal today, that was see the naked man David. Yesterday there was a 3 hour line in the heat midday. So we went early.
column509: >I had left my bike with a guy in laundry mat and I gave him 5 euros to watch the bike for 4 hours.
column517: >Then we got to the art gallery where the the famous statue of David is, there was still a 3 hour wait in the line up….
column525: >That was terrible, but at least there was no heat. Everyone was complaining about the line up 😂
column533: >We then went inside after waiting forever in the line up and saw the famous statues.
column541: >Wow it’s incredible. I have never seen statue like it before.
column549: >We checkout out the other art pieces and left after about 30 mins.
column557: >I went to take a nap - I found a spot in a plaza. Egita went to return the rented bike and check out of her hostel.
column565: >Egita and I decided we want to keep travelling together. Since she has already booked and paid for hostels in Genova, a different city, we had to go there next.
column573: >After my nap we met up at the train station.
column581: >I hate the trains in Europe. It’s always complete chaos.
column589: >The first train we wanted to take was full, so we missed it.
column597: >The next train was delayed for 30 mins, then it was cancelled.
column605: >Finally we got a train but not direct. We had to go to Pisa first.
column621: >I always really wanted to see the leaning tower of pisa. And now fate had given me the opportunity.
column629: >We took the train, this time it came on time, and it was backed full and uncomfortable to ride on with the bike…
column637: >The train was packed full for over an hour shoulder to shoulder. It was so fully I couldn’t move at all. And some the Italians were frustrated by the bike (they didn’t know I understood what they were saying hehe).
column645: >We got to Pisa and had an hour before the next train so I made the decision to see all of Pisa by bike in 30 minutes.
column653: >I raced around the streets of Pisa and saw the leaning tower!
column661: >Wow it was really cool. It was a lighter color than I expected and also it was smaller than I expected. It was still really cool it see in person.
column669: >I biked back to the train station and we got the next train to Genova.
column677: >We arrived, I cooked us both pasta with the camping gear, and we parted ways for the night. Egita to her hostel, and me…
column685: >I had no idea where I was going.
column693: >I saw on the map a forest 2km away. It looked like it could be a potential camp spot. I thought that it would be easy to get to since it was so close.
column701: >I didn’t realize it was up on the mountain….
column709: >It was 2km but 2km up and very steep. I was quickly covered in sweat again. Some of the steepest roads I have biked on.
column717: >I finally got to the top to find out that all the entrances to the forest were locked with a gate and had a massive wall.
column733: >Then I saw this broken part of the wall but it was a few meters up and I would have to lift my bike and climb a little to get there.
column741: >I saws guy who looked about my age nearby and asked him if he would help me lift up the bike up the wall.
column749: >He looked at me like I was crazy. He said he knew a spot much easier to camp and to follow him. I said all the gates up there I saw were closed and locked. Then he said he knows how to get inside and open them for me…
column757: >I followed him to the door, and I was like. Where am I going hahaha. I just went with it.
column765: >The gate said private property no trespassing. I figured I would go in and quickly go into the forest to stay out of site.
column773: >he came around to let me in but couldn’t get the door open. Then he said to go around the back to another entrance.
column781: >I met him at the back and I had to carry my bike down some stairs but eventually we arrived.
column789: >It was in front of this massive building that looked like some type of housing.
column797: >I asked him where I was and he explained that his was a house for youth refugees. He said he was one of them.
column805: >He said I could just camp there. I did not want to camp right there in front of the building since it was so obvious and visible. I looked around the forest nearby for a spot more hidden from sight.
column813: >I had no luck finding a spot. Everything was too steep for camping with a tent.
column821: >I said screw it. I started to set up my tent in the spot he had showed me, if anyone asked I would just say I someone told me to camp there.
column829: >only about 1 minutes later a car pulled up and asked me what the hell I was doing there. That it was private property and he was the custodian of the land.
column837: >I told him in Italian everything that had happened and that someone told me to camp there and he was like…
column845: >No you can its dangerous here - there are the life’s and wild boars etc.
column853: >We talked for a while and eventually we told me to come with him,
column861: >Then he offered me spare bedroom in the ground floor of his house. He lived above and uses the ground floor as storage, but he offered me the bed and let me use the shower and bathroom. I took a nice and much needed shower after that sweaty climb and slept amazing.
column869: >Reflection on the day.
column885: >Cancellation of trains allowed me to see Pisa. I was disappointed earlier in the trip when I realized Pisa was out of the way and I would get to see it. Fate brought me there.
column890: >Climbing a steep mountain, to a camp spot turns into a bed with a shower. How does this happen 😂
column896:
>

That’s all for today. Enjoy the pictures :)

column467: text-align:start
column474: >Life has been like a movie for the past 6 days. How do I even begin to write about it. If you want to know about these these posts in the next week you will have to ask me in person and I will decide how much I will tell you :).
column482: >We saw Florence in one day, we walked around…
column490: >We walked together through the city. Again lines to get into the naked man. We will see him tomorrow we decided instead.
column498: >We waited in the line to enter the duomo. The Duomo from the outside is incredible I can’t believe it.
column514: >We walked together through the city streets, every corner had a little surprise that was interesting to see.
column522: >We walked to a fortress that happened to have an amazing view of the city. We walked through a garden.
column527: >There was a massive mansion in the garden. I wonder what it would be like to live in a house that large…
column532: >She rented a bike and we biked to park in the city at night time.
column537: >I cooked us dinner and we drank wine in the park with the bikes.
column542: >We sat and talked for a long time.
column547: >After this I biked back with her to the hostel, helped her lock up the bike.
column552: >Finally I biked out of the city looking for a place to camp for the night.
column557: >It was really hard to find a place. It looked like nothing would work on the map. Then I found this creek that looked like it would work and pushed my bike into the forest.
column565: >It was really creepy in the creek and at first I thought the spot was horrible since it was so obviously visible from the road.
column573: >Then I moved further down into the creek and I was happier with the spot I had chosen.
column578: >I was a little scared.
column583: >That’s all for tonight.

column426: > #53 - Rome in one day (it’s impossible)
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467: text-align:start
column474: >Rome in a day.
column482: >Both Egita and I wanted to keep travelling together for a bit.
column490: >She had reservations in other hostels in other sites. So together we had to see Rome in a day.
column498: >Which would be possible except for the extremely terrible and stupid awful lines outside of everything that usually is about 1-2 hours.
column506: >For the colosseum it was a 2 hour wait even thought we got there before it opened. And it was a wait in the blazing sun without shade. Pure torture. And the best part is you have guided tour salesmen offering line skips for a more expensive price. They target the most uncomfortable looking people at the back of the line
column514: >We held strong and did not pay.
column522: >We finally got in and the colosseum is very interesting. I liked it.
column530: >Then we went to the Vatican by bus.
column538: >We got a ticket from the Roman police for not paying the 1 euro bus ticket. You have to buy them in separate stores and we did not know this. We got a 54 Euro fine. He was nice and only gave us one ticket or pay instead of two.
column546: >We finally ended up ubering to the Vatican.
column554: >Waiting in another terrible line for the main church. 1.5 hours to get in. Most incredible church I have ever seen.
column562: >The Vatican puts every other church I have seen to shame. I couldn’t believe how luxurious it was - lots and lots of money went into its construction I am sure.
column570: >The next stop was the Sistine Chapel. I really wanted to see the artwork on the roof.
column584: >Unfortunately we missed the last entrance time to the Sistine chapel by 5 minutes. I was disappointed but this gives me another excuse to come back to Rome. I will have to visit the Vatican museum another time.
column592: >Finally we enjoyed the walk back to the hostel, we grabbed our things and took the train together out of Rome to Florence.
column600: >It was my first time taking a train in Europe and it felt chaotic. We had 5 mines to get the train and I had no idea how to do it with the bike. Then we got lucky and the train was delayed so we had an extra 20 mins to figure it out.
column608: >Finally when the train arrived I had only 3 minutes to get on. And find my train car all the way down at the end of the train. The furthest away. Then of course as I put my bike on the train the door closed and smashed on my with the bike. I had to battle the door to make sure me, the bike, and Egita made it on.
column616: >But once in the train it was relaxingggggg wow. So much easier than biking 😂
column618: >. Dangourously easy, and inexpensive.
column626: >We went to Florence, arrived and it was way nicer than Rome. Just because it was so much less busy. It felt calmer.
column634: >We went to her hostel. And I once again went in. They had an awesome room balcony on the building. This time I asked the receptionist if I could sleep on the balcony.
column642: >He was from Argentina, so we connected over Spanish and talking about Argentina. I have never been to Argentina it love the people I meet from their and I want to go.
column650: >We talked for a while about various things, until he just offered me to stay in the hostel for free since the bed was not being used anyway.
column658: >So I stayed in the hostel in a bed again without needing to pay :) I could use a shower and everything. Very very nice.
column666: >I slept like a babyyyy in the hostel bed that night.
column674: >I went out that night before sleeping to walk around Florence with Egita. Again much cooler at night.
column682: >That’s all for now (pictures below)

column426: > #52 - All roads lead to Rome.
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

Spark notes version
column470:
>

1. Biked all morning trying to get to Rome
column473:
>

2. It’s hot hot now. 38C in Rome.
column476:
>

3. I took a nice long shower with a garden hose facet for about 3 hours
column479:
>

4. I went really fast on the bike, I was pushing hard
column482:
>

5. I met my friend Egita 🇱🇻. And I got my towel back. She was surprised that I made it to Rome so fast.
column485:
>

6. Egita and I walked around Rome. Enjoyed walking by foot better than biking around. You see things better.
column488:
>

7. Enjoyed good conversation and the many beautiful things to look at in Rome.
column494:
>

I biked all morning. All roads leading to Rome (finally i can say this and it’s factually true)
column497:
>

Took all morning but after another 100km i arrived outside of Rome.
column500:
>

I was feeling gooood but once I got to Rome it got hot hot - 40C.
column503:
>

I sat under a cold water fountain for a few hours and washed up. Rome has many water fountains. What was interesting to me is that they are always on. They just constantly drip fresh cold water without any ability to turn off. Seems like a waste of water to me.
column506:
>

I then went to Rome and explored around saw the colosseum from the outside and everything from the outside.
column509:
>

It’s an impressive city.
column512:
>

Rome is different than I imagined. I only got to see a small sections of the city, but it was more spacious than I thought.
column515:
>

I loved the large plazas and historical areas.
column518:
>

It’s annoying how many people there are. I disliked the chaos of big cities. And when there are too many tourists like in Rome I think locals become less friendly.
column521:
>

Italian food is good but I came to the conclusion that Greek food is way better. More variety, more flavour, and less expensive.
column524:
>

I met up with my friend Egita for dinner and I got my towel back!
column527:
>

I left my bike at her hostel, they didn’t seem to mind it.
column530:
>

We had a great dinner and walked around the city by foot until late in the night.
column533:
>

It’s way way better walking around while it’s cool at night time.
column536:
>

Eventually we got back to the hostel I was gonna drop her off then go find a place to sleep. But when I got to the hostel I just passed out right away in a chair in the common area, at once point I moved to the floor with my sleeping pad, and finally I took a couch. Free night in a hostel.
column539:
>

No one said anything to me about sleeping there.
column542:
>

It was satisfying going from Napoli to Rome in two days. Good to know I can cover lots of ground when the road is flat.
column545:
>

Here is a foto of the hostel basement where I slept on the couch… (all the way down)
column548:
>

Bye for now,

column467:
>

Favorite photo of the day
column483: >Woke up in the forest.
column491: >Then I went to the nearest place I could buy coffee.
column499: >I drank 4 coffees and then went to a super market.
column507: >On of the workers there happened to be a cyclist and told me a better way up the mountain I was going to.
column515: >I listened and had a big 900m climb for about 10 kilometres.
column523: >On the climb I met another cyclist from Milan who had a vacation home in the alps.
column531: >He told me a route he loves over another mountain.
column539: >I said I would give it a look.
column547: >I went to a town called Aprica.
column555: >There I sat for a while and ate pizza.
column563: >I thought long and hard about climbing the hill.
column571: >I would have to sleep up at 2000metres if I did that.
column579: >My sleeping bag is rated for 7 degrees Celsius. I couldn’t find any information on the weather other than about 500 metres below it gets to 10C at night.
column587: >I decided I would try and if it was really bad I would not sleep at such a high elevation again in the future.
column595: >I went to an outdoor store and bought some long underwear to help me stay warm at night.
column603: >I went up the climb slow and steady.
column611: >It was difficult of course. By the time I leave the alps I will be either destroyed or really fit.
column619: >I made it to the top of the hill and was too tired to keep biking so I just cooked dinner and found a pretty spot to camp for the night and watch the sun set over the mountains.
column627: >I’m about to go to sleep now and it’s already getting chillier. Let’s see how it goes. Hopefully I’m not tooo cold tonight :)
column643: >It definitely got colder last night. It’s hard to say now cold it got. Maybe 8 or 9 degrees.
column651: >With long pants, socks. A hoodie, rain coat and a towel on. I slept the entire night very warm. I think even if it went a few degrees colder I would have been fine.
column659: >oh this really loud animal was screaming all night. I put earplugs on and that solved the issue for me lol.
column667: >The alps are sooooo pretty. I’m loving it.

column692:
>

Where I slept at 2000 metres

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

July nine was a huge day on the bike. I biked 150km.
column470:
>

I woke up in the morning even more please that I had left the beach due to Pirates and camped in the forest.
column473:
>

The beach was crowded by people riding back and forth along the beach in chariots with their horses. If I had been camping on the beach I probably would have been trampled or abruptly awoken by horses and chariots.
column476:
>

Looks like even the pirate attack was a little bit of good luck.
column479:
>

I then biked and biked. I wasn’t doing much thinking, the biking was nice.
column482:
>

I had a mission to set myself up today to get to Rome the next day. I would need to bike as much as I could in the day, the farther I got the higher chance I had of getting to Rome in time to get my towel back.
column485:
>

I rode all day being careful with my biking stops. I made sure I never stayed in one place too long.
column488:
>

The riding here isn’t as nice there’s more traffic .
column491:
>

But eventually, I got to a really cool coastline ride.
column494:
>

I saw a lot. When you bike all day. You just zone out. I remember going through scary tunnels where I couldn’t see anything I had to rely on the cars lights to see.
column497:
>

I remember beautiful coastal towns, with a very nice beaches. All the beaches were packed with people.
column500:
>

When I was biking long, I heard a pop noise. My rear rack at fallen off. This is the thing I used to carry my bags on the back.
column503:
>

Fortunately, it was just a screw had fallen off. Unfortunately, I didn’t have another screw.
column506:
>

Fortunately, yet again it had happened right beside a boat mechanics workshop. I ask the owner if he had a screw and he did.
column509:
>

I was back on the road good as new!
column512:
>

At one point I stopped at a grocery store to stock up on snacks.
column515:
>

When I left the store an Italian man and I chatted. He saw that I had bought a Gatorade drink, At the end of the conversation he went inside to the store and bought me another one! That was very nice of him.
column518:
>

I passed so many lovely beaches. I kept telling myself I really want to stop in one of these beaches and stay for a week. It looks so relaxing and the water is the perfect temperature. You can stay in the water all day if you want.
column521:
>

I also saw an ancient aqueduct. And in one city, it had the water channels that make me think of pictures I have seen of Venice.
column524:
>

And finally, I got to a Beach that was 50 km long. One side a beach one side a lagoon.
column527:
>

There were so many cars, and it’s really just kept going on and on and on.
column530:
>

When I finally got to the end, I settled down for the evening and set up my tent.
column533:
>

After the scary pirate story from the day before I was more careful where I put my tent. But unfortunately, the beach had no shelter and I was sort of in the open.
column536:
>

No more pirates came from the sea or horses to stomp on my tent. Just a peaceful night on the beach.
column539:
>

The one thing I remember, very clearly is how hard it was to push my bike through the sand.
column542:
>

Here’s where I slept.( at the end of the pictures)

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

July 8th - I’m in Napoli at the hostel.
column467:
>

I once again slept in as much as humanly possible. I had went out the night before and not gotten back until 5 or 6 am.
column470:
>

Eventually I got out of bed and went for coffee and my cornetto for breakfast as I do everyday in Italy.
column473:
>

I took the morning easyyy my plan was to sit and do some writing, then leave midday north. My next location was Rome.
column476:
>

I only wrote down one sentence before the Latvian girl Egita walked into to the room. She was one of the people I met on the first night on the hostel. I couldnt help but say hi.
column479:
>

So much for writing…
column482:
>

Our conversation turned into us going for lunch and spending the afternoon together.
column485:
>

She knew a place where they give you free snacks if you order food, and it was like 2 euros for a pizza.
column488:
>

So we went and talked and talked. It was interesting learning about her and life in Latvia. I had never met someone from there before.
column491:
>

While we ate lunch a pigeon joined us. No matter how hard we tried it would not leave the table. It was so used to humans that no amount of shooing away the pigeon would get it to leave.
column494:
>

Eventually lunch ended and I had to go. She was also going to Rome but by train, and she would only spend 2 days there so there was a small chance I would see her again in Rome but I doubted it.
column497:
>

We said goodbye and I continued biking out of Napoli.
column500:
>

I eventually got to the other side of Napoli that I had not seen yet. It was a very large city and I had only seen the historical center and the port.
column503:
>

The other side of the city was way nicer. Clean streets, interesting plazas. I really liked it. I guess the hostel was in the cheaper area of the city.
column506:
>

The roofs out of the city on the coast was great too. More of the beach side roads with the classic Italian buildings to the side.
column509:
>

On these sea side roads a strange feeling came to mind that I had forgotten something at the hostel.
column512:
>

I stopped and looked through all my bags.
column518:
>

I had forgotten my sisters towel that I took without asking (hopefully she is not reading these).
column521:
>

It was around 7 o’clock now and I had already gone about 30km away from the hostel.
column524:
>

If I went back I would not be able to find a place to camp…..
column527:
>

I thought about it and the only person I knew who would be at the hostel was Egita.
column530:
>

Problem was that she had already checked out of the hostel too and went to a different place to sleep before heading out to Rome tomorrow morning.
column533:
>

I sent her a message and asked if she could go back somehow and bring it to Rome. Turned out that she had also forgotten something at the hostel and had to go back anyway. She agreed to grab my towel for me!
column539:
>

I guess now I have to do the 300km to Rome as fast as possible so I can see her before she leaves Rome.
column542:
>

I looked at the map and I would have to do back to back long days, riding all day.
column545:
>

I kept going on the road until the evening, feeling much better now that I have a chance to get my sisters towel back.
column548:
>

I saw a beach on the map that looked very isolated so I went there.
column551:
>

When I got there I had to go around a closed gate that said I should not go there at this time of day.
column554:
>

Then another gate that was closed shut with a stick.
column557:
>

I easily opened that one and proceeded to the beach.
column560:
>

It was a pretty beach expect for them fact that it was covered in garbage.
column563:
>

I payed on the sand and called friends and family and watched the sunset.
column566:
>

Then the bugs came out and I set up my tent.
column569:
>

I started to fall asleep after the sun went down.
column572:
>

It was all peaceful and quite until…
column575:
>

A flashlight shone directly onto my tent from 50 metres out on the water.
column578:
>

What the hell….
column581:
>

I peeked my head our of the tent and all I could see was the small outline of a boat,
column584:
>

They had been shining their light on me and my tent.
column587:
>

The light went out…..
column590:
>

At this point I was confused. Why were they shining a light at me? Why is the light gone now? Maybe it’s just someone looking where the shore is while they travel in the small boat.
column593:
>

I sat and waited. I was on alert.
column596:
>

5 minutes past and nothing. I could no longer see the boats outline or hear any noises, or see any lights. I was a little concerned.
column599:
>

I checked my phone to see the time and I realizes my phone was dead. I tried plug-in it in and the charger cable had broken.
column602:
>

Great so now I have no phone either…
column605:
>

I laid back down assume it was harmless.
column608:
>

Then it came again. This time they were blinking their light at my tent, one for 1 second, off for another second.
column611:
>

Okay this is now weird.
column614:
>

Again I looked, again the lights were off and the small boats outline was visible. I saw the boats outline continue down the beach and around the corner out of sight…
column617:
>

Looks like they were leaving.
column620:
>

I laid back down but was having trouble peacefully falling asleep.
column623:
>

More minutes passed and this time large bright lights shone out at me from the tent. And a large banging noise. I could hear something banging about the hull of the boat.
column626:
>

I look up to see three people on the small boat, with now two really bright spotlights on the back of the boat illuminated my tent and the beach, the guy at the front of the beach had a white apron on and it looked like it was covered in something red….
column629:
>

He had a machete or something in his hand and was banging it again the hull of the boat. The boat was maybe 10 metres away from the beach and 40 metres away from me.
column632:
>

Okay what the f*ck.
column635:
>

I jumped out of the tent in my underwear, grabbed my tent which had all my stuff in it, and grabbed my bike in the other hand and sprinted as fast as I could barefoot into the nearby forest. Again I have no phone or anything - it’s out of battery.
column638:
>

Once I felt out of sight I peaked my head back to see what was happening on the beach. The men did not land on the beach and the guy kept banging the machete on the boat. I sat in the forest for a while watching. I could hear the sounds of the crickets, the boat banging, and some animals breathing in the forest behind me.
column641:
>

I sat and sat for a long time.
column644:
>

Eventually it appeared as thought they left and I went to sleep.
column647:
>

What the hell was that. I still don’t know.
column650:
>

My thoughts in my head were they were fishing and the banging was to make fish jump or something. I have no idea, but their weird ritual freaked me out in the moment.
column653:
>

I don’t have a picture of the tent set up but I have many of the beach so you can see. Considering the pirate attack and the dead phone and broken charger I think I have at least one excuse.
column656:
>

Well thats all for this day,
column659:
>

Pictures below as usual,

column464:
>

Ciao a tutti.
column467:
>

todays my birthday wow. I’m 23 years old. It feels so old to me. 🥹. this last week has been a bike tour break, I’ve been driving around Genova with a motorcycle. I traded the bicicleta out for a real bike. I’ll eventually get to sharing some stuff with you about it.
column470:
>

on to the 7th..
column486: >Awwww the beauty of hostels. I slept in yet again, and in a bed too. I love it!
column494: >I left my bed to go to the common area to write and catch up on these posts.
column502: >That’s the thing with hostels that I love so much… it’s so easy to talk to people and meet new people. Within the first 5 minutes of writing I had talked with a group of Belgians and one French guy and we were all going to breakfast together.
column510: >This breakfast turned into a full day walking around Napoli. We got some pizza for lunch, I helped them moved their suitcases from the Hostel to an Airbnb since they had to check out of the hostel. After this I suggested we go to the subterranean underground of Napoli which was recommended to me by an Italian guy in a small village. So we went on a two hour tour of the underground of Napoli together.
column518: >Underneath Napoli was sooo cool. Literally the temperature was 18 C which was perfect since outside was 35 C.
column526: >Also we had an amazing tour guide. Usually I hate guided tours but the tour guide was super excited about the tour, she was very easy to listen to and you could tell that she loved giving these tours.
column534: >I learned so much about the underground of Napoli.
column550: >It was first used to bring water from nearby sources to the city so people could drink water
column555: >Then the water got polluted by a sewage system built on top and the city shut down the water system
column560: >After this it was used a garbage dump for the city. The city put thousands and thousands of tons of garbage down. Metres high piles of garbage in the whole cave system
column565: >Then World War Two Italy needed bomb shelters, since Napoli was the most bombed city in Italy in the war. SO they dumped concrete over the garbage so everyone could stand down there.
column570: >During the war up to 5000 to 10000 people crammed into the subterranean area to avoid bomb attacks
column578: >After the tour we started to chat with the tour guide. She was our age and we told her how amazing she was at giving tours.
column586: >We ended up inviting her to come with us for drinks. We all went and chatting it was fun.
column594: >Other memories of the day are
column607: >Waking around Napoli and feeling the pleasant energy of the city
column612: >Eating pizza and getting overcharged 10 euros…. I asked the waitress to pick me a pizza off the menu, and she picks the most expensive one then adds 5 extra things without telling me…
column617: >Drinking lots of coffee all the time. I love espresso.
column625: >Fast forward to the evening.
column633: >I got back to the hostel and got ready to go out. It was me my Argentino friend, The French guy and the Belgian girls, One more French girl joined us as well.
column641: >We all went out for drinks at some bar.
column649: >It was so packed!! Everyone was in the street. One of my favourite nights out. I loved the energy of the people on the street. I think I had too much to drink. My Argentinian friend and I would take turns buying each other round after round of drinks.
column657: >I was switching often between Italian, French, Spanish, and English. I had to act as a translator many times. I loved how international it was and also how I got to speak in all these language. This is extremely fun for me. It’s like a game switching between them and you never get bored.
column665: >I got back at around 5 am and went to bed.
column673: >This was my last night in Napoli tomorrow I was going to leave and continue north to Roma.
column694: >I spent way to much money compared to while I was biking and camping. I need to spent less.
column699: >When we went out for drinks I only drank water. It was 5 euros for a simple beer and I was not going to pay that.
column704: >The cab ride home was a disaster and we ended up not being able to pay. He had a card machine but would not accept our cards and demanded cash. He even wanted to drive us to many ATMs but they were closed.
column709: >I used Italian to haggle down cab prices. They don’t make it easy lol.
column717: >That’s all for now,

column426: > #48 - A city preserved by a volcano - Pompei.

column462: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467:
>

Leaving my bike with my parking friends
column480: >I woke up at the campsite. I slept in! It had been the first time in a long while that I was somewhere where I had no rush in the morning. My plan for the day was to visit Pompei, then go right to Napoli, which was a short 40km flat ride. So I just needed the afternoon.
column488: >I really thought hard about going over the top of the volcano to see the giant hole at the top of the volcano. I thought so hard about it in fact that I created a plan and a route that would take me there, it was 50km and 1000 metres climbing. So it would be much tougher than biking the seaside flat way.
column496: >I told my self I would decide based on how I felt after visiting the ruins.
column504: >I left the campite and went to the ruins.
column512: >The guys who I talked to yesterday at the parking booth were still their as they promised and I was able to lock my bike as I went to the ruins.
column520: >I entered the short line up to go into the ruins and I was standing beside two British people who looked about my age.
column528: >In the 10 minutes we were in line be became friends and decided to walk around the ruins together.
column536: >Seeing Pompei was really interesting. I have never seen such a large ruins. It was an entire city and you can kind of image how life was when you walk through the streets.
column544: >Many of the 2000 year old artwork was still with color on the walls of the ruins.
column552: >I will let the pictures I took tell you some stuff.
column560: >If you don’t know Pompei, you can google it for more information. But basically in 79 AD, a volcano erupted nearby ( the one I want to bike up) and the ash from the volcano killed everyone and buried the city of Pompei completely.
column568: >Many years later they discovered this buried city and the ash had well preserved everything.
column576: >Then I left the ruins, grabbed lunch with my friends, and they left back to Napoli.
column584: >I laid in a park for 4 hours napping. When I woke up I realized I would have no time to climb the volcano after all. I would have to rush the 40 Km flat route in order to make to the hostel in Napoli for checkin.
column592: >Oh yeah, I booked a hostel in Napoli. I felt like talking to people again and maybe going out for drinks. Taking it easy and rejoin the regular world loool.
column600: >So I biked and biked fast. I was feeling antsy. I biked as fast as I could just to test myself a little bit.
column608: >I arrived in Napoli and its a massive city yet again. It took me forever to find where I was going.
column616: >I happen to stop at once point since something fell out of my bag. And This lead to a conversation that almost ended up in me sailing a sailboat from Sicily to Napoli…
column624: >Now I am on standby as a crew for sailboat chartering.
column632: >I got to the hostel and it was soooo nice. I could shower, there was a bed, a kitchen. Luxuryyyyy. It’s funny since this is the nicest hostel I have ever been in. But many of the people staying in the hostel think that it is terrible, and the worst one they have stayed in. It’s all about perspective I guess. I have been sleeping in lemon trees…
column640: >I felt so out of place with the bike. Many people I met had just started traveling or only take trains. They all usually visit the same places as well. They all have the same shocked reaction most of the time when they ask me and I tell them how my trip has been so far lol.
column648: >Even on day one I met some amazing people in the hostel, and Argentinian friend, two girls, on from Latvia and one from France. We all had amazing conversations and probably will go explore Napoli together in the coming days.
column656: >I forgot to take a photo of the room of the hostel. Ill help you image it instead. It was a hostel bunk bed and I had the top bunk. There were about 4 other bunk beds in the room. Everyone was from Australia in my room.
column664: >That’s all for now,

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

I woke up at 5 am soooo tired. I slept horrible in the lemon trees.
column470:
>

So I packed up and went down to the beach right away.
column473:
>

Sorrento only has one beach and it’s only for locals… it is about 10 metres wide too.
column476:
>

I went there early so no one cared about locals only.
column479:
>

I slept on the beach for a few hours in the morning and went for a nice swim around.
column482:
>

It was relaxing. Sorrento is a town built above cliff. No one goes down to the water were I was until atleast 9 am when the elevator turns on so I had peace and quite. It was beautiful.
column485:
>

Remember when I said yesterday that I wrote down I need to visit Sorrento?
column488:
>

I still have no idea why. I was left rather unimpressed by Sorrento. I went through the old center of the town really fast. It was nice don’t get me wrong. But it was not even half as pretty and the ride the day before with the small cliff side towns. It felt like there was not a lot to see.
column491:
>

I left Sorrento and continued on the coast, I got a nice view of the city as I left and took a picture. I followed the coast out and rode to Pompie. I was going to camp there and see the Anceint ruins in Pompie in the morning.
column494:
>

I talked with some guys who worked for the parking and made friends with them. They said I could leave my bike by then parking booth tomorrow while I explore the ruins - and they helped me find cheap camping.
column497:
>

I showed up at the camping grounds and only had to pay 10 euros which was totally reasonable :)
column500:
>

I cooked dinner in the common area, once I finished the owners came by with their Argentinian friend. They offered my pizza chicken and wine and I had a second dinner!
column503:
>

We enjoyed a conversation in a strange mix of Italian and Spanish. the Argentinian would talk in Italian then half way through every sentence speak Spanish, It was amazing that everyone understood each other.
column506:
>

I slept in the campsite and enjoyed the comfort. It was a small campsite with only a few vans there at the time and owners did a great job of making me feel at home there.
column509:
>

All for now.

column467: text-align:start
column474: >Woke up and the beach I was camping on was becoming full of people. I suppose I slept in.
column482: >No one seemed to mind. Many people wanted to chat and thought it was interesting that I had a bike.
column490: >I biked back to Salerno for a coffee. And went for coffee with another Italian man that was biking with me for a bit. we chatted about life.
column498: >Then I biked north along the coast again.
column506: >I met another Italian cyclist who I followed for a little while. He was 83! It was actually hard to keep up with him. I wanted to stop to put sunscreen on and eat so he left me behind.
column514: >When I stopped I had a Methana like view and I sat with some old Italians while I made my Greek salad for lunch. I just melted away into chair with the view Methana vibes. It was really nice. I absolutely love staring out at the ocean.
column522: >Then I biked the Amalfi coast. Holy shit… I wish I had that GoPro. It was unreal to bike on.
column530: >I just went nice and slow stopping in towns that I was recommended to visit. I met some argentines. I got lunch with them and they bought me coffee!!! So nice of them.
column538: >I went for swims in the ocean, and enjoyed my time with the beautiful beaches and scenery. I could spend a month here on the beach.
column546: >Good place for a future, different type of vacation.
column554: >I’ll let the pictures speak for themselves. I’m a broken record but yet again everything has been topped. This was the very best costal road I have biked on yet….
column562: >Then I got to Serrento. I had written in my notes a long time ago
column578: >But I forgot why I wrote that. Well I decided to go there to see it.
column586: >Here I am now, I made pasta and watched the sunset.
column594: >Now I am looking for a place to sleep.
column599: >I will write the rest of this after I find the place. Let’s see what happens!
column602: class=""dd""><table class=""j"" role=""none"" width=""50%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td> &nbsp
column608: >Okay here i am. I am writing the rest of this way after but I remember really well what happened the rest of the night. I started biking around Sorrento in the dark. It was really hard to find a place to camp in the city. At one point I saw this dark area that looked like no one was there. I left my bike there to go look for spots in the trees on foot. It was in Hilton parking lot and behind the parking lot that I found a flat hidden spot forest!
column613: >Jackpot. I thought I had found the spot. I had went away to brush my teeth and grab my bike. Taking my time thinking I was a genius for finding such a great camping spot. Then I went back with my bike and…. The gate to the parking lot is closed. I was locked out of the parking lot and my nice spot was now not available. At this point it was 11:30PM… oops. I kept trying to find a spot. I biked around aimlessly until I found by luck some lemon trees outside a parking garage. I camped there stealthy. I did not feel very hidden here so I planned on leaving early in the morning and I only set up my tent in a way so it would be less visible and block out the mosquitoes. The sleeping pad protected me from the sharp pokey thorns I had laid my tent on.
column618: >I notice that I keep getting bolder and bolder with my camping situations at night. Just you wait for the future posts. It’s just hard to find spots in bigger cities. 🤣
column623: >-Bye for now, (Photos below)

Erik Dahl | Strava Cyclist Profile

Erik Dahl is a cyclist from North Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. Join Strava to track your activities, analyze your performance, and follow friends. Strava members can plan routes, participate in motivating challenges, and join clubs. Get started by signing up for free.
column488: >www.strava.com/athletes/78831211
column497:
>

Great! I need to reduce friction if I want to keep posting. If you are interested in bike routes. Check it out there for now :)
column500:
>

Today is the text first… let me know which order you like better.
column505: >Woke up in their appartment floor. Very comfortable with my mats. I can sleep anywhere now.
column513: >I hung out with them all morning. It was their last day. They had a train to catch at 5 then a flight at 10 pm back to London. We all just relaxed on the beach in the sun all day long.
column521: >They left and I walked around the city with an an Italian girl I met on the beach. I wanted to see a special garden but it was closed for rennovations unfortunately.
column537: >Afterwards I was alone again, the girl went to a train to go to a village. And I was at a bar where I had left my bike.
column545: >I sat for a minute at a small bar in a plaza .
column561: >Three guys from Napoli told kids they couldnt play in the empty plaza. The workers of the bar were mom and and went ape shit on the three Napoli men.
column569: >The bag of the Napoli men was thrown in the tree.
column574: >Watching the Italians argue was insane. They talk very animated like in movies. The use of hands and gestures. they spoke in Napolitan dialect and I understood nothing.
column582: >Amazing to watch. It yet again felt like a movie.
column590: >Then I found the famous pizza chain Pizza di Michele. I ate a great pizza.
column598: >Tried to find a place to sleep which was not easy. I biked along the coast looking for a beach with some privacy. Apparently that’s what everyone looks for at night since the beach I found was full of Italians hooking up. I tied to sneak by with the bike to the corner where there was no one to sleep. I slept with a beautiful nighttime view of Salerno and the mountains of Amalfi coast.

column467: text-align:start
column469:
>

Dear loyal campanions.
column472:
>

I have failed to post every day. I’m still currently in Italy and I’m having less and less time to write. The writing is the easy past but making these posts with images in the phone takes a long time.
column475:
>

to speed things up I will upload photos first of the day and texts as separate parts. And the writing might be more rough and brief.
column478:
>

Pictures first for today then a write up of the events 🙂 Enjoyyy.

>

Waking up in the morning at the river

We went out to eat dinner . Gnocchi!!

column538:
>

They let me sleep on the floor of the Airbnb. Thank you!! ❤️
column541:
>

Great now for the write up :)
column546: >I had a very flat roads and hot biking into Salerno on busier roads. It was much cooler in the mountains.
column554: >But then I got to the city and it’s beautiful.
column562: >Again I always need time for the small town to big city transition. Im always uncomfortable at first in the big cities for how many people there are and the traffic.
column570: >It takes me at least a day to get used it again.
column578: >I did not know what to do. I wanted to chill so I found a bar and had espresso and recharged. I create a little plan for what I would do.
column586: >Then I biked to the beat and a soccer game was on. A beach league.
column594: >I met two British women from London.
column602: >We all talked together for a while. We decided we would go out for dinner together later and drinks. They left to get ready and I stayed at the beach where all my stuff was.
column610: >There was a beach shower which was awesome to use and get clean with.
column618: >Then I talked with the Italians beside me. They told me about the history of the beach soccer. It was a 40 year old tradition in the city.
column626: >They then bought me beers and we talked for a long while while the game was going on.
column634: >After the game we parted ways and I met the girls to go for dinner. We found a place and ate gnocchi. Great conversation and lots of drinks.
column642: >They paid for my dinner! (Thank you so much ❤️❤️❤️❤️)
column650: >We kept drinking till 5 am. Then they felt bad for me and let me sleep on the floor of their AirBNB instead of sleeping on the beach. I mean at 5 am when we finish the sun was already up and rising. So really it was an all nighter.
column666: >They can really drink! It was impressive to seee. The English.
column674: >It was a fun night in Salerno!
column682: >Night accommodations ( you day’s it above)
column690: >This was more brief. Did it still do the job? I think this style is more sustainable for me right now.
column698: >Let me know what you think.

column467: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column476: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column486: >Woke up and went down the hill. The mission was to find a bike store to get new brakes installed on the front. I started really early. Like 5:30am.
column487: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column493: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column503: >I took some trails to avoid busy roads. It quickly turned into a really rough muddy trail with surprisingly mini lobsters in the trail. One pond had 100 of them.
column508: >When the pedals get wet my feet slip all over the place. Since I had crappy plastic pedals without grips. The mud from this trail once again made it almost impossible to keep my shoes on the pedals.
column513: >The mud from the trail was enough that my front wheel would no longer move. I had to clear out the mud by removing the wheels to fix it.
column521: >When I looked at the map the only bike store nearby was in this little town called Polla up the road. But it didn’t open until 9 and it was 7. I would have to wait before taking the big mountain road.
column529: >I think this trail would suck if it rains, Of course it starts to rain.
column537: >I found a bar in Polla and sat down had coffe and waited for the bike shop to open.
column538: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column548: >I started a convo with two German/ Italians. Afterwards he payed for my breakfast!
column556: >Another Italian man comes in and asks about the bike, he was a big cyclist. He loved racing and all things about biking. We talked for a while right after
column564: >After our conversation he tries to pay for my breakfast too!
column572: >But it’s already paid for by the other.
column588: >Then I go to bike store it’s open.
column596: >He is helpful, he find me good pedals for a good deal. The mechanic was the sun of the owner of the shop. The dad comes in who is the owner.
column604: >We chat about the bike tour I’m doing as his son worked on my bike.
column612: >Then out of nowhere he walks in with something in his hands. He then processed to give me the cycling Jerry and padded shorts worth probably about 300 euros. I was in shock.
column613: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column618:
>

Me and the bike store owner
column623: >They change the breaks and I bought new pedals that have better grip in wet conditions.
column631: >Right as I leave it stops raining and once again I return to the cafe. He closes for lunch and I go to super market.
column636: >It starts to rain again… I wait it out at the super market.
column641: >Finally I went back to the same bar as before one last time. He gives me a free coffee and I speed like a rocket ship over the final mountain before I arrive on the other side of Italy.
column649: >WOWOW again crazy down hill, and fun fast and easy uphill. In the racing cycling kit I felt so fast up the hill. I felt like the tiny twin of Polla had given me wings to fly over this mountain.
column650: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column655:
>

Powered by coffe and the jersey
column660: >Take a look at some of the pictures I took. It only can capture a fraction of the beauty.
column661: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column673: >I got to the other side. Another moments where I look back at the mountains behind me and wonder how I did it.
column681: > As always the answer is just little by little, pedalling.
column689: >I then found a little gravel trail that let me dodge a highway on the map by accident.
column690: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column699: >It quickly become unridable from deep sand. At one point the trail complete disappeared and I was lost.
column707: >But at the end I found a river by accident.
column715: >I made the decision to stop early there and camp by the river instead of the ocean.
column723: >Enjoyed the river bank and cooked more pasta in the middle of nowhere. I didnt have service so I missed a day of posting these blogs.
column731: >here is the picture of where I camped.

column467: text-align:start
column474: >Bike bike bike all day.
column475: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column487: >Up one big mountain, then down, then up another mountain. Again and again.
column488: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column497: >Wild horses in a pack on the road.
column498: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column510: >I feel like I am getting in better shape here. The mountain climbing is getting easier finally. I am getting faster uphill aswell.
column511: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column516: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column521: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column530: >near the end of the day I stopped to fill up water.
column538: >An Italian family offered me coffee, chocolates, and a bottle of bubble water! I was happy to except and their coffee got me over the next mountains.
column539: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column544: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column556: >At the end of the day when the sun was going down I took a wrong turn and ended up being on a road where i had to bike on the highway to get where I wanted to go. The only detour was if I biked back up the hill I biked down for a few kilometers.
column557: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column566: >I did it since the highway is dangourous.
column574: >The alternative route I found was very steep downhill and I noticed my brakes were terrible again. I could not stop very well downhill. Looking at it more it turns out my front break pad was fully worn out.
column575: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column584: >Then I saw an olive tree field with my name on it. I tools myself I would deal with it tomorrow and just camp here, instead of biking down the steep hill with my bad breaks in the dark.
column592: >I found a beautiful campspot with a view of the sunset glow on the mountains.
column593: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column605: >Just across from me there was a hotel and they were having some kind of wedding party. They played loud music that I could hear from maybe 700 metres away.
column613: >Good think I had earplugs.
column621: >I cooked a nice pasta, talked with friends on the phone, and enjoyed the frizzy water I was gifted by the kind Italians earlier in the day.
column629: >The coffee they gave me really helped me get over the final mountain.
column637: >Here is where I slept.

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""padding: 20px 15px 20px
column462: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: text-align:left
column479: >I woke up early, made a Greek salad. For the FIRST time in Italy i was able to find cucumbers. I really miss Greek salad. I think that the food in Italy is amazing. BUT the food in Greece is much more healthy.
column480: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column492: >In Greece i was eating so healthy. Italy is good but pizza and pasta only is not the healthiest. Im gonna start searching some variety.
column508: >Early morning was tough. I was super super tired. I thought I might fall asleep riding. But i wanted to keep going since I had a big day ahead and I did not want to bike in the heat midday. Every morning kilometre is much easier than a midday kilometres.
column509: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column518: >I then stopped at a bar and the espresso revived me. I felt great.
column526: >I was still feeling a bit of a low from the previous high of Matera.
column534: >When I was biking along a bridge, as two baby kittens came out onto the road in front of me while I was climbing a hill.
column535: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column547: >I stopped and gave them food and attention.
column555: >After this they climbed all over my bike. So adorable.
column559: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column568: >I continued on and they wouldn’t let me. The kittens were running behind my bike whining. My heart melted as I left the kittens and moved on. I was so close to emptying one of my pannier bags to take them with me. I thought really hard about it and almost convinced myself I could do the bike tour with the two kittens.
column580: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column585: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column594: >Then I took a lunch break with another incredible view.
column602: >While I was eating I noticed a beautiful beautiful mountain village on the top of the hill.
column603: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column613: >I sat there eating Nutella and break for a long time contemplating if I should go and visit.
column621: >The only problem… it was way out of the way. This route was twice as long and double the positive elevation.
column629: >I said screw it I’ll do it since there is a lake on the other side that looked like it might be good to camp on that night.
column637: >WOW biking down the hill into the valley than back up was incredible.
column645: >If someone sponsored me for a GoPro I will take videos and share them. It would amazing to have for the Alps. Unless you have biked down a mountain you wouldn’t believe how crazy it is.
column653: >How can I describe it other than sheer adrenaline, when you look your sides you feel like you are top of the world. I am so excited for the Alps and or Dolomites. I might take a train from some point in Italy to get to the mountains faster.
column661: >At home I bike down local mountains, Seymour, cypress, grouse. I have biked to whistler as-well.
column669: >This riding here, in these mountains in the central south of Italy completely blow all of these local rides out of the water.
column670: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column675:
>

From the village in the evening
column683: >So i arrived in the village and everything was closed of course.
column688: >Just one bar was open….
column696: >Remembers bars in Italy are coffee shops. So I sat in there for hours, just chatting and relaxing waiting for a restaurant to open at 7 pm.
column704: >Then others came into the bar. Two guys around my age speaking Italian. One was Italian and one was Argentinian. We spoke in Spanish. Then another man came in and ask for something. He was a backpacker with a big backpack. At some point he relieved that he was Mexican! Another Spanish speaker. So we talked in a strange mix of Italian and Spanish.
column712: >Many times I found myself talking in Spanish and then switching to Italian. I was having a lot of trouble keeping to speaking only Spanish.
column720: >We all went to dinner together afterwards. It was great fun chatting about our travels together.
column721: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column733: >Finally I left down the mountain village just before dark. Another wicked wicked downhill ride.
column734: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column746: >I arrived at the lake to find it was not even a lake. But a man made water reservoir. I thought it would be easy to get to but all the trails down were really steep and all locked up with fences and chains.
column754: >So I just walked in the forest a little till I found a nice spot and set up my tent.
column762: >As I slept around my tent were dozens of fireflies. I had never seen them before but there are so many here in central Italy. They flew all around my tent and littered the forest with little lights.
column771: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""padding: 20px 15px 20px
column462: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: text-align:left
column471: >Ciao ciao. Today was the first day my brain stopped wanting to say hello in Greek to people as I rode on my bike. Now it’s Ciao all the way.
column479: >Currently writing this one in a coffee shop in a mountain village on the 29th of June. I saw this while I was biking through central Italy from the top of a mountain, and I changed my plans to go visit. It is a little little town on the top of a hill. The town would be a perfect place to play a huge game of king of the hill.
column487: >I have never seen a village like this before.
column495: >On the the 28th. A day in Matera.
column503: >I woke up with the incredible view of the city. This time by day instead of by night.
column511: >I biked to the city early in the morning.
column519: >I was so confused. The crazy rock city I saw just looked completely normal when I biked through the streets. I was completely unimpressed.
column523: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column533: >I was pretty tired too so I just went and sat down at a coffee shop to relax, read, and wrote for all the morning.
column541: >I then decided to play tourist and did something unbelievable.
column549: >I paid for a guided walking tour.
column557: >While I waited for the tour to start I walked around and got ice cream.
column565: >I was too tired to find all the cool spots on my own and all the locals recommended that I do a tour.
column569: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column579: >Once the tour started I pretty much instantly regretted it haha. I was unable to understand much of the Italian guide. I enjoyed listing to Italian for two hours but I probably would have enjoyed the English version of the tour more.
column587: >I just pretended to understand the whole time and laughed when everyone else laughed. Then I would do the classic si si (yes yes), Or when I finally understood something I would repeat it back so it sounded like I understood what was going on.
column588: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column600: >When I tour ended I saw a lot of cool things in Matera. It’s a beautiful city. I should have just walked around aimlessly all day in the old part of the town. Lesson learned. No more paid guides.
column608: >I have realizes on this trip so far that my three favourite things are meeting people, eating food, and great views. Im not a big fan of just seeing things that are historically important. It just doesn’t seem to excite me.
column609: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column621: >After this I left the city of Matera. Wow it was incredible riding down from the hilltop town. At this point it was 9 pm and the sun had set. So I went down the hill fast when I had light. Then I biked on the highway in the darks till I found a trail off the road, and set up my tend in a large open field and slept the night.
column637: >Beautiful unique city, but i think the fact that I had, for the first time, really high expectations (especially after the view) that I was let down a little bit. I was also coming down on this high point from the day before so it was hard to top it.
column638: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column426: > #39 - The piano, the watch, and the farm
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
