column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""padding: 20px 15px 20px
column462: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467:
>

Not so much biking - but a BIG day
column472: >On the third day in Italia - Italia gives me three amazing separate all crazy events…
column480: >Strap yourselves in, this is a longer one.
column488: >What a beautiful beautiful day. June 27th was my third day in Italy - and it felt like it went from zero to one hundred very fast. The interesting part about bike tours is that they are so unpredictable. June 27th is no different. I could have NEVER imaged this would happen, soon we will get to this.
column496: >I am writing this on the 28th, in the morning in a coffee shop. I have eaten some kind of cheese pie with mozzarella cheese, a cappuccino, Cornetto and espresso. Food is delicious in Italy! And the espresso is the best I have drunk. I am not sure how I am going to go back to regular coffee in Vancouver after this…
column504: >The traditional breakfast italiano is
column520: >Some espresso coffee variation.
column525: >Cornetto thats stuff with chocolate, crème, or jam. It’s very tasty and is sweet. It goes great with the coffee.
column533: >Okay now into yet another unpredictable day. The journey to Matera.
column541: >Matera is a city that I have heard SO MUCH about. I met Italians in Greece… they say go to matera. I met Greeks in Greece… they say to to Matera. I meet Italians in Puglia… they say go to Matera.
column549: >So I had no choice but to plan it into the route as I cross the lower section of the Italian boot.
column554: >I have no idea WHY I need to go there, but I assumed that I would find out why everyone thinks it’s a “must see”.
column562: >I woke up on the beach where I camped, at 5 am. This is when the sun is starting to rise, I find it hard to keep sleeping when the sun starts to come out.
column563: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column568:
>

Only one in the beach at 5 am
column573: >This was a massive beach, I could see for kilometres down one way, and giant windmills to my left beside the beach. In this moment, staring out at the ocean and the beach - was the first time that I actually felt alone. There was nobody. It wasn’t bad, it wasn’t good, I was just alone and it didn’t bother me at all. It was just a passing thought I had.
column581: >“Oh shit, I am all alone here.”
column589: >I packed up my stuff and took my time leaving the beach.
column590: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column603: >As I mentioned, the goal today was to get to Matera. So I looked on the map, a route to the first small town - I thought I might stop for lunch and avoid the heat.
column611: >I now have this golden rule. I will do anything to avoid busy highways. Yesterday when I accidentally took a highway it sucked big time. It’s too stressful I cant relax and ride tranquilo. I don’t care if I have to bike way steeper roads or trails, or longer distance. Quiet roads are the best way to go.
column619: >Thus I started biking on the quiet roads.
column627: >I biked through a small city called Palagiano. it was cool. Every town looks a little different I really like it.
column635: >After Palagiano I entered some farm roads, Only wide enough for one car going one direction at a time. No room for bikes on the side. The nice part was there were almost no cars.
column643: >I saw in the rear view mirror a car approaching. So I pulled over to the side to let it pass, and gave my usual friendly car wave.
column651: >I said “ciao” and continued biking behind the car. Then the car stopped maybe 10 metres ahead of me and he pulled over to the side. It looked like to let me pass. I biked by and he rolled down the window.
column659: >We started to chat and he was so surprised to see a biker on this road, we talked for a while. He had a farm, he had his fields to the side where I was biking and his house was up the road.
column667: >Then he told me to follow him behind his car, he was inviting me for something but I only understand like 85% of what people say here lol and I missed what I was being invited for. I went anyway…
column675: >He pulled over at one point and grabbed two watermelons from his field.
column683: >“Aww great he wanted me to try fruit”. I thought.
column691: >Then we continued, eventually we got to his farm house. it was stunning. I really liked the colours. It reminded me of the building I really liked the day before in Taranto.
column692: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column705: >Then I met his wife, she came out from the house to say hi. We all talked for a while, they brought out fruit for me to eat, all produced from their fields.
column713: >His wife noticed that I had a plastic disposable water bottle on my bike and only one reusable one. I mentioned I lost my water bottle in Lecce.
column721: >Then they gave me a new water bottle! Wow. I was very grateful.
column729: >We sat and ate fruit, he cut the watermelon with a knife and asked me if I had a knife. I said no - then he gave me the knife too! Again I was very grateful. Then their other friend came up to the house. We were all talking and she had a Pizzaria in the city I biked from, unfortunately it was closed that day, but she gave me a recommendation for where to eat dinner in Matera the next day. She knew everything about pizza. Slowly I am learning :).
column730: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column735:
>

The fresh fruit and water bottle
column740: >They left since they had to run errands and I sat there alone for a while eating the fruit in the shade. When I finished I left a little thank you note saying if they came to Vancouver, I would be their guide.
column741: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column751: >I got the instagram of Raffillia, who as the friend who owned the pizzeria - and then all the others through her.
column759: >The original man I met left a really nice comment no my last instagram post in Italian. That made me happy :). Wow Italians are such nice people. They love to chat with anyone, and seem to really enjoy helping people. (If you guys read this thank you again. Una cosa bella che abbiate fatto per me ❤️)
column767: >I kept biking, feeling fresh from the fruit and water.
column771: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column781: >Amazing quite farm roads and gravel. I called my friend Colton and we talked for a while while I biked with the trails. We hadn’t talked for a while and it was nice. Let’s see if he reads this haha. (A little Easter egg)
column782: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column787:
>

Gravel trails over a bridge
column795: >At one point I crossed this bridge just for bikers and it had a nice view. I love when I stumble upon on a road that is made for bikers :)
column803: >I also love the fact that I can read the signs again. In Greece I could read them, but instantly forget them since I wasn’t able to remember Greek names at all.
column811: >This took me to the next town called Castellaneta. I got to the town around 11:30 and I was tempted to bike to one more town and skip this one. Mainly since I had another 35 km to Matera and I wanted to get as far as possible before stopping for the afternoon.
column819: >But I learned from yesterdays mistakes. I did NOT want to miss lunch again having everything closed at 2 or 3 pm. So I stopped.
column827: >I biked up a hill and completely at random stopped to ask an Italian guy if he knew a good Trattoria to eat at. At this point i still had not been able to find an open one to eat at!
column835: >I was happy to hear that he knew a place. AND he said I could follow him in his car, me with the bike behind.
column843: >So I did. He took me down the hill I had just painfully climbed to a Trattaria he said was the best one in the city!
column851: >Of course it was closed…. Damnit. Turns out Tuesday is a day of closure for this place.
column859: >But it did not end there. We chatted for a while and he had another recommendation farther away and he. showed me on the map how to get there.
column867: >We talked more and eventually he said he was going to cook lunch for his wife and her friend at his apartment just where I met him getting into the car. His wife was from Korea. She did not speak Italian, and he did not Korean, but they communicated in English. I thought this was very cool!
column875: >Next he invited me for coffee with all of them after I finished eating lunch in the afternoon.
column883: >I accepted and went to the food place he recommended to eat.
column891: >I got there and it was ALMOST closed. The coffee part was open but lunch wasn’t open for another hour and a half. Is anything every open in Italy?
column899: >I sat and got coffee, then as I was sitting there for a while an older Italian man and I started talking. He joined me at my table and we talked for a long time about his life as a singer travelling around Italy.
column907: >At the end of our conversation when he had to go and I was going to start eating lunch, I noticed he had a nice watch.
column915: >“I like your watch, it’s nice”, I said something like this.
column923: >“You like it?” He replied.
column931: >Then he took the watch off and put it on my wrist.
column939: >He said. “It’s yours now”
column947: >He just gave me his watch! I was so shocked yet again. I refused to take it first but he WOULD NOT take it back.
column955: >He was very adamant that I take it.
column956: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column969: >Well we parted ways and I ate some nice pasta in the restaurant. It was good - It did not blow me away, I need to try more pasta here to compare. I thought it was a little undercooked (Italians who read this please don’t get offended). I like pasta Al Dante but this was a little TOO Al Dante.
column977: >The plate looked pretty.
column981: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column991: >I left the restaurant and I went to the house of Antonio, the man who had given me the recommendations for where to eat.
column999: >I got there and I went into the apartment, the first thing I see is a massive grand piano in the apartment.
column1007: >I met his wife and her friends. They were two more Koreans living in Italy, friends of Antonio’s Wife.
column1015: >They invited me to sit and we chatted, they gave me beer, pizza, and tiramisu.
column1023: >Turns out Antonino is not just a regular guy.
column1031: >He is a professional Piano player.
column1039: >We gathered around the piano and Antonio played. He didnt just play. he PLAYED. Oh my God I have never seen someone play like that.
column1047: >He was played songs that he composed. I was completely in shock. I guess this is how a professional pianist plays - it’s a whole other level.
column1055: >If you want to hear how he plays. Here is a link to his Spotify, where he had songs he has composed. Check them out! If you like them add them to liked songs since that helps other people find his music.
column1063: >He played “The Rain” for us live and it was incredible.
column1065: target=""_blank""><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" class=""o"" style=""padding:12px 12px
column1066: ><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" width=""100%""><tr><!--[if mso]><td width=""0""><table cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" border=""0"" role=""presentation"" style=""display:none
column1073:
/>

The Rain

Antonio Di Fonzo · Song · 2019
column1076: >open.spotify.com/track/2bhmbAKMplEbNjLYTZAo1d?si=PZDiMtF0RjqGTtliWuD2Jg
column1085:
>

This song above is one he played lived in his apartment for us.
column1090: >Later we played some classic hits and I sang as he played it was very fun.
column1106: >The two Korean friends live in Matera! They invited me to go with them in their car so I did not have to bike the whole way in the heat.
column1114: >I said no thank you. I explained that I love biking and I like the challenge. It looked like a fun ride.
column1122: >Then I drank with them, Antonio’s wife was extremely kind to me and kept pouring me more and more beer, eventually came the brandy, then the wine. THE WINE. It was red wine and red wine made by Antonio’s father. It was some of the best red I ever had as well.
column1126: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column1136: >After this point it was already 5 or 6 PM and let’s say I was a little tipsy.
column1144: >I reconsidered the ride offer to Matera…
column1152: >I asked if it was still on the table and they said yes.
column1160: >Eventually we left and said goodbye and I put my bike in the back of the car. We drove to Matera together. Cars are way faster.
column1164: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column1169:
>

we fit in the bike
column1174: >Hold up. This is a bike tour. Am I cheating? I thought so at first, then I said, no this is fine. Im just having fun. I don’t need to be so strict with always biking. It would have been more dangerous to bike in the dark hammered. I was happy with the decision. I am still having to bike another 6000 kilometres or so, I’ll cut myself some slack.
column1182: >I still had no idea where I was going to sleep. I think they felt bad for me and Yunmi (On of the Korean friends) offered me a spot in their home. I said even outside would be fine since i had the tent. I went to her home and met her husband. It was fun trying to explain why I was in her car with my bike in Italian haha, everything’s always in Italian in Italy. It’s obvious but I love it. But he was very kind as well and super helpful, we had beer and Yunmi cooked dinner for everyone.
column1190: >They had a little multi-poodle dog that reminded me a lot of Shamrock, my dog who passed away last year. Just like Shamrock, their dog would not stop barking at me hahaha.
column1198: >After dinner, Giovanni (Yunmi’s husband) had an amazing idea. He told me everything I need to do the next day in the city since we was born and raised there. And he told me that I was welcome to camp in their home but if I did that it would be hard to get to Matera the next day (Since they lived in the outskirts of the city) and he said the view from this spot was incredible.
column1206: >After dinner we drove together to the spot he said was a great view.
column1215: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column1220:
>

Matera from the camp spot
column1228: >Here were the nights accommodations

column467:
>

The ride along the coast
column491: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column503: >At one point I was biking past an older italian man. He said
column511: >“Mi stai umiliando” (You are humiliating me)
column515: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column525: >After that we started riding together and had a conversation. He told me all about his bike racing days.He was 75 and it was hard for me to keep up with him on the hills. We maybe rid together for an hour before he turned around and went home.
column533: >Then there is midday stop where I went to a random cafe that I found on google maps.
column540: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column553: >I biked around the city of Taranto. The cities are have a different feel that Greece. It feels slightly less chaotic.
column554: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column563: >The drivers in Italy are OKAY. Everyone tells me all the drivers here are crazy, but i think every place has crazy drivers, and some that respect other bikes. Jury is still out on driver quality in Italy. I will get back to this soon.
column564: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column569:
>

I found this building I really loved the colours.
column577: >I got to Taranto and I saw a cool castle! I went into the castle it was free which was awesome since most things are pay to enter here.
column581: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column591: >My favourite part was the cannon they had in the fortress wall. I had not seen a bike cannon like this before (at least that I remember).
column592: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column597: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column609: >At this point it was 3pm and I had kept telling myself that I would eat lunch in Taranto at the place I got recorded, but I kept pushing it back since I thought there was no rush. At this point I was so hungry that my stomach was hurting.
column617: >I showed up at the restaurant (they call this actually a Pizzeria and Trattaria).
column625: >It was closed……. The guy i talked too said they wouldn’t open again till 8pm. OOF that sucked. I asked them if he knew somewhere else I could pranzare (eat lunch).
column633: >“(In Italian) Everything is closed right now.”
column641: >here was a colture shock for me. EVERY SINGLE lunch place closes from 3pm to like 8pm.
column649: >I was disappointed since I still have not eaten pizza or pasta in Italia!
column657: >I went to a coffee shop and got premade sandwich. It was too expensive and not very good but there was nothing else at this time of day.
column665: >I learned my lesson. From now on I will not delay lunch midday. I will stop in towns at like 11 or 12 so I can make sure I get food (tho some don’t open till 1, but they close at 3 so thats crazy to me). I guess since all the Italians know this its no big deal for them. They just got to get their butts to lunch. In the piccolo food window.
column673: >After this I biked to a grocery store. My mission now was to create my own pasta for dinner. Which I would eat my when I found a place to sleep.
column681: >I biked to a beach. Unfortunately the only way there was on a terrible highway. That wasn’t very fun lol.
column682: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column694: >But the beach at the end was worth it. And the pasta I made was delicious.
column702: >All alone on the beach at night felt nice :)
column703: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column1: 5e454754-1781-43cd-a2f4-cfd6fd5fe4f7,#37 - First day in Italia.,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/37-first-day-italia,June 25th,#36 - First day in Italia.,June 25th,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column466: >Yesterday I said, I would answer the question. Why am I now travelling alone?
column467: text-align:start
column471: >If you haven’t travelled alone before, It may sound scary. About exactly one year ago - I did my first solo backpacking trip in the south of Mexico.
column472: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column477:
>

My favourite place in the mexico trip. A mountain village in Oaxaca
column482: >Before this trip, travelling alone sounded terrifying to me as well . That’s partly why did it. I wanted to do something to get out of my comfort zone.
column487: >That trip was fantastic - I absolutely love the freedom of being alone and making all the decisions. If I wasn’t having a good time, it was my fault. And I had the power to change anything I was doing in the trip. It was also a way for me to develop more independence and immerse myself in another culture. For two weeks I pretty much only spoke Spanish with Mexicans (and one Belgian).
column492: >Now for me, bike touring solo was a whole other level. I was so sure about bike touring in Europe before this trip, that I convince myself if Adam bailed on me pre-trip, I would just do the whole thing solo. But deep down, I was afraid because I had no idea how to bike tour. I’m glad Adam did not bail on the idea (tho he almost did haha (
column500: >As I mentioned before, I didn’t even know how to camp. Now, as I write this, I’m currently the only person on a beach in Italy, at 11pm. I only found this place to sleep at 6 PM. I never know where I’m going to sleep until about 6 PM, 90% of the days.
column501: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column506:
>

All alone on the beach
column511: >Adam and I get along great while travelling, but after a month of travelling around Greece, we both felt like we wanted this control again. I would want to visit one place, or I would want to go - he wants to stop, or opposites. Basically we each were feeling we wanted to have more control.
column516: >Now the prospect of going alone doesn’t scare me (still a little bit but a lot less than before) because I figured out how bike touring works (thanks kai). I have a lot more confidence in myself. I know I will be fine all alone, even in the worst situation’s.
column521: >So that brings me to the other big reason - I want to pose myself a little challenge. How will I be a full month or two fully alone? I’ve been biking at least 6 or 7 hours a day. And it will just be me with me on the bike (maybe with a song in my headphones or random people like today when I biked with a 74 year old Italian man for an hour)
column526: >And finally, since I picked Italy as my solo adventure - I pretty get to talk Italian nonstop for one month. Molto molto bene.
column531: >For the last two days I’ve only spoken in Italian - I’m even talking to myself in Italian. In fact, the most English I have done is writing this post by far.
column536: >I want to see how fluent I can become an Italian after one month of full immersion. I’m already able to have amazing conversations with the locals here.
column539:
>

They all are so surprised to see a Canadian speaking Italian. They always ask why do I speak Italian and I never know what to say. “Cause I like it” I often reply. I don’t have a reason to be able to speak Italian other than I thought it was a cool idea to learn the language for this trip. Maybe i will just say that from now on…
column544: >So that’s why I’m travelling solo now :)
column550: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column559: >I woke up in the morning on the ferry. It was an amazing sleep. I was the only one except for a family in a tent to sleep the entire night on top of the ferry. I used on of the lay down deck chairs. In the sky I saw the stars, and for the first night I was able to use my sleeping bag - the sea breeze kept me cool. Normally it’s too hot.
column560: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column565:
>

waking up one the ferry
column570: >Next… my first impressions off the boat were that this part of Italy is very flat. I didn’t see a single mountain. Also, the port had many cargo ships which I didn’t like that much. I think this is the name of the game with port cities.
column575: >I got off the ferry and ventured into the town of Brindisi.
column576: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column586: >My first interaction with someone Italian was a shop owner. I asked him where I can get some breakfast since it was 8 AM. I found it funny that he told me. “Oh yes, there’s a magnificent bar to eat at down the road. They have the best breakfast.” He was gesticulating with his hands a lot which I love - them using their hands a lot is 100% true and its amazing to watch. I now am using my hands a lot too.
column591: >I was confused because in Italy “bars”, are places that give you coffee and breakfast and sweets kind of like a coffee shop or a bakery in Canada.
column596: >Another thing was I came and arrived on Sunday- and almost every store was closed. I guess it was early in the morning, but it sort of felt like a ghost town. This made it even harder to find food. In Greece they close on Sunday too but normally it’s in the really small villages. Brindisi is a big port town. I was very surprised to see many things closed.
column601: >I continued to the bar, where I asked for recommendations, and had my first meal in Italy. Cornetto and cappuccino. Both were amazing and better than what I’ve had in Canada.
column602: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column612: >But Brindisi was stunning. The people who told me Corfu looks like Italy were correct. They have the same style of buildings.
column613: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column623: >Already I’m noticing so many things about Italians, every stereotype is true that I’ve heard. They love to use their hands, they get so emotional and the stores and yell, they all dress well, and they’re all super super kind. When I talk to them Italian, they’re super helpful. If I don’t know where something is, they’ll do everything in their power to help me find what I’m looking for.
column628: >I left Brindisi and headed south to a city called Lecce. An Italian man I met in Mani, Greece - told me I had to go there. Since it was so close to Brindisi. I thought I would go check it out.
column629: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column634:
>

flat roads the whole way.
column639: >The ride to Lecce was completely flat - just old farm roads. Not very exciting riding - but easy riding. When I’m on the flats, I missed the hills. When I’m on the hills I beg for the flats. Funny how that works.
column644: >At one point on my way, I saw a bunch of smoke on the road ahead. One of the fields in front of me was on fire. Obviously, I didn’t go down this road. I backtracked and went to go talk to somebody who live in a nearby house. I was telling an elderly woman that there’s a fire there and ask her if we should call someone and if it’s an emergency.
column649: >I was so surprised by her calm, nonchalant reaction. She said it’s nothing. It was not an emergency. It’s only bad if the fire reaches the wheat fields. And finally that we don’t need to do anything and there’s nothing we can do except just let the fire burn. She said it gets really dry and this is super common. This very much surprised me. I continue it on a different road that was not smoking.
column654: >Eventually, I got to Lecce. It’s definitely an extremely beautiful city.
column655: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column660:
>

First thing I see in Lecce (Also where I think I left my water bottle ☹️ )
column665: >When I got there, I was a little confused on what the hell I should do lol. I am aimlessly biked around the town. I didn’t really want to pay to enter the big monuments. And I definitely didn’t wanna pay for hostel. At this point, I prefer my tent.
column670: >My slogan is… Pay for food, not for accommodations.
column671: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column677: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column687: >So I spent the afternoon and Lecce biking around. Then I left again for a different beach.
column692: >It’s always nice to camp on the beaches
column697: >I went to Porto Cesareo.
column702: >Again, the writing was easy flat, and not very exciting.
column707: >I arrived in Porto Cesareo stopped and filled my water at a pizzeria. Then some locals who worked at the pizzeria recommended a beach I should go to to sleep with a tent and not be bothered by anyone.
column708: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column718: >I realized here that I left one of my water bottles in Lecce… Darn.
column723: >I went to the beach, it was very full of people, but very nice.
column728: >I cook dinner, talked to Italians who were all so curious about the bike, and watch the sunset.
column729: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column739: >Once the beach emptied, I found a hidden spot for my tent.
column744: >It was just me, and two Italian teenagers were fishing. We chatted for a while while they fished. They taught me some Italian words in their local dialect of Italian called Salentino.
column749: >I learned that between friends, they all speak this Italian dialect which is not comprehensible to people who speak Italian. And proper public places in with strangers - they will speak Italian.
column754: >It was fun - they gave me some recommendations for food to eat and now my list is growing.
column760: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column776: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column796: 2024 Erik’s European Bike Journey - Greece to Somewhere

column1: ead11691-6e94-4d4d-a7cd-4758c9b27a1f,#36 - Ciao Bello - The Worst and Best Goodbye,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/36-ciao-bello-worst-best-goodbye,June 24th,#36 - Ciao Bello - The Worst and Best Goodbye,June 24th,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column412: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top"" style=""border:0px solid #FFFFFF

column426: > #36 - Ciao Bello - The Worst and Best Goodbye
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

This morning I woke up in the comfort of Alex’s childhood bed in his mothers apartment.
column467: >
column469: >And now, It’s 1:30AM and I am writing this post on the outside top deck of a night Ferry heading to Brindisi, Italy from Igoumenitisa, Greece.
column474: >It’s nice. I smell and feel the sea breeze of the Aegean Sea. And soon I will take a long sleep on the deckchair of the top floor.
column479: >A big pro of having my camping gear is I have my sleeping mats and sleeping bag with me for a cozy outdoor sleep on the top level of this boat.
column484: >Oh yeah… and I am all alone. From the next while I will be solo travelling through all of Italy.
column489: >I have left Alex, Adam, and Kai in Igoumenitsa, and they will probably all leave their own separate ways in the coming days.
column494: >Let the adventure begin… Again.
column497: class=""dd""><table class=""j"" role=""none"" width=""50%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td> &nbsp
column501:
>

How did I get on this ferry?
column506: >The day started in slow motion. Yesterday nights trek through the canyon river was exhausting. So we all slept like logs.
column507: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column512:
>

Reminiscing in my ferry tickets from the islands.
column517: >We basically did nothing all day. We just talked and talked about everything as we usually do when we are together. We cooked more pasta, and relaxed in the apartment.
column522: >All four of us have this thing where we can talk and talk for hours about the stories of our trips, the little moments, and all the crazy coincidences that seem to keep happening to us. Lots of conversations about life too - you know how it goes.
column527: >Everything feels so special and perfect - even the worst moments seem to have this serendipity to them. Like they were always meant to be that way.
column532: >During these deep chats we had together I realized something…
column537: >I want to go to Italy now.
column542: >I have been learning Italian for 6 months and it feels like Italy is calling me. Every morning this week from the balcony of Alex’s apartment I see the ferries coming and going from the port to Italy. Each time I thought… what if I just went there now - saying goodbye to the Albania plans.
column547: >And I did it.
column552: >I bought the night ferry to Italy and told everyone I would be leaving to Italy now. They were excited for me of course. I don’t think they were surprised at all.
column557: >Adam and I had long ago talked about some point splitting up since we want to see slightly different things. I want a deep dive of Italy and Adam wants to hike up mountains for weeks in the Alps.
column562: >I spent the afternoon preparing myself for the journey, cleaning my bike up, packing my things, leaving behind some things I never used on my bike so far and no longer needed.
column567: >Once I was all packed up, Kai, Adam and I went for a short bike ride to get some beers and go to the beach. Alex went out to see a friend and we were going to meet him later.
column568: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column573:
>

Biking around Igoumenitsa with some beers
column578: >We just biked randomly in one direction until we found the first beach.
column579: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column589: >Once we got on the beach we found two other bike tourists, a young German married couple!
column594: >When bike tourists see each other on the road its always so exciting. You can relate so easily. You know what they experience and they know what you experience. The stories are always great.
column599: >We had the best conversation with them. Our conversation lasted about 5 hours. There were many many things talking to them that I thought were funny coincidences.
column612: >It was their first day in Greece, it was my last.
column617: >They came from Brindisi Italy, I was going to Brinidisi Italy.
column622: >I said earlier in the day that it would be nice to meet someone who had camped in Italy, they had camped all over Italy and told me so many great places to go.
column627: >They alway love sitting in remote places were no one can find them, and people always seem to find them - this time it was us that found them.
column632: >We told them everything we learned about biking in Greece, useful phrases and locations - everything we wish we knew when we started there.
column633: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column638:
>

Talking till the sun went down
column643: >After our conversation we all left together and I bought them beers. It was my name day today (A Greek Christian celebration for the name Erikos) - and tradition says I have to buy beers for everyone on these occasions.
column644: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column654: >Then Alex arrived with his friend, they met and we all went together for a final pizza meal before I left.
column655: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column665: >The pizza was good and I ate until my stomach hurt. Now I have as baseline to compare with Italian pizza. Let’s see who wins haha.
column670: >At this point it was 11PM and my ferry to Italy left at 1 AM in the morning. I had to get there about 1 hour before since it’s such a big ship and there is security and a checkin. It’s much more serious than the ferries that stay within Greece.
column675: >So I left everyone at the pizza place to go back to the apartment alone to gather my things and shower. All with only 1 hour before I needed to be on the boat.
column680: >I said a goodbye, but only a quick and superficial one since we planned to meet at the ferry terminal before I left in an hour.
column685: >I rushed back and packed all my things, I said goodbye and thank you to Alex’s Mom who was at the apartment.
column690: >And I rushed full speed with 5 minutes left to the ferry check in.
column695: >But wait… my friends were no where to be seen to say goodbye at the terminal. I was being rushed by the staff and they kept telling me I need to get on the boat NOW and that it will leave soon.
column700: >So I had to get on the ferry without saying goodbye……
column705: >The distance between the entrance to the terminal and the actual ferry docking station was about 800 metres. As I biked, to my right, there was a big fence where you could see the road. I looked along the fence to see if I they would show up to say goodbye while I rushed to the ship.
column710: >I was hoping to see them again once more before boarding the ship.
column715: >I got to the boat without seeing any of them.
column720: >I was a little disappointed as they scanned my ticket and usher me to the boat….
column725: >Guess I don’t get to say goodbye.
column730: >In this moment I thought
column735: >“oh well, That’s too bad I didn’t get a proper goodbye.”
column745: >“Goodbyes are overrated anyway” (my inner self talk, i was actually disappointed, but quickly accepted it for what it was)
column750: >Then Kai called me.
column755: >He said they were all there and trying to find me. I said I was already on the boat and it was too late…Giant steel gates, far away from the boat, would prevent them from entering without a ticket. I did not think I would be able to get off the ship.
column760: >I walked to the back, where I entered the boat, and all the staff were very focussed and busy ushering the last trucks on the ferry.
column765: >I said to Kai on the phone I will try and get them to let me to run off the ship to the fence and back to say goodbye just before they leave.
column770: >Problem 1 - I cant explain that in Greek to the staff at all.
column775: >So I got Alex on the phone call and was about to give the phone to the guy who got me on the ferry.
column780: >I asked him in Greek if he speaks Greek and he looked very offended and said I only speak Italian, in Italian.
column785: >I was like in my head “shit okay, Italian time”
column790: >So i just explained that my friends, were over there on the distance behind the fence and if it was okay if I ran over to say goodbye. Somehow they understood my horrible italian haha.
column800: >he said, “NO we are leaving now.”
column805: >I was persistent and he slightly gave in and said.
column810: >“Go talk to Maria”
column815: >then I ran to a girl name Maria and I did the whole thing over again in Italian
column825: >“no you cannot go there now we are leaving.”
column830: >I said just 5 minutes and I run over really fast to say goodbye.
column835: >Another miracle happened - she understood my Italian again.
column840: >And she let me run over to everyone at the fence to say goodbye.
column845: >I ran with my sleeping pad and bag in my hands the 400 metres to the fence with my shoes half on and my shorts falling down (For some reason my shorts were on loosely… My hands were full of things I was carrying so I could not pull them up as I embarrassingly ran across the port).
column850: >Then I made it to the fence out of breath and we got to all say goodbye to everyone through the steel fence.
column855: >I said goodbye to Adam, Alex, Kai, Isabel, and Isabel, and Daniel (Alex’s friend and the two Germans we have the 6 hours of conversations with).
column860: >Kai gave me my underwear that I had forgotten on his bike and Alex gave me an Ice tea to drink.
column865: >What a way to say goodbye. I wouldn’t have expected a goodbye to be any different for us. It was completely in character for us and our trip - every day feels like we are in some kind of movie LOL.
column870: >I went back to the boat with the biggest smile on my face.
column875: >Now everyone on this boat seems to think I am Italian, and when I am walking around the boat or asking for information from people I do not know when to speak to people on the ship in English, Greek, or Italian.
column876: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column881:
>

The fence and port from the top of the ferry.
column886: >So here I am, back on the ship in route to Italia - all alone :)
column896: >So, today I decided on a whim to go to Italy all alone. My time in Greece has come to an end.
column901: >I think I need to sit and process it for a while. So much has happened.
column906: >Two questions you might have that I am asking myself right now.
column919: >So 1 month in Greece, what are the takeaways?
column924: >Why have you left Adam and decided to travel solo?
column929: >As I mentioned before I am too lazy to keep both a hand written diary AND write these long blog posts about the days. So this is a two in one. I like to type with a keyboard rather than hand write. It’s just easier.
column934: >You get to see everything and see what I am thinking, and I get to look back at this in 10 years and have a good laugh.
column939: >To answer the first question.
column944: >Greece is amazing. It was an unknown country to me completely, and I now I feel like I understand what it means (at least a little bit) to live in Greece. I have seen the way of life of many people here and have a deeper appreciation of the culture, people, and the country as a whole.
column949: >I have written many things in this blog about things I noticed about the Greeks crazy parking habits, the pride they have for their national hard liquor drinks Ouzo and Tsipuro (Both spelt wrong for sure), the strong interest in politics held my many students, or the many other things I have noticed about Greek tendencies that are not coming to mind right now.
column954: >Most of all, I have met amazing people in Greece. Alex felt like a main Character in the biking across Greece adventure. We kept meeting him at checkpoints like an adventure video game. If we did not meet Alex I think we would have been in Greece for only 5 days, but I was in Greece for 40 days! Absolutely crazy. Meeting him was a complete fluke. Destino.
column959: >Lastly, I have learned that people are capable of incredible kindness to people they don’t know at all. I never held any pessimistic views about people, but this trip has even further given me hope for humanity.
column964: >Question 2 I will answer another day. It’s time for me to sleep as it’s getting cold on the ferry. I will go into my sleeping bag now and go to bed. I pray it doesn’t rain on me.
column969: >Stay tuned for next time where I answer why I am now travelling alone.
column974: >Nights accommodations (taken the morning after).

column426: > #35 - The river that takes souls to the underworld.
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

Im loosing track of how many days I have been in Igoumenitisa. Yet again, keep reading to see if I every leave, or go back for another lap of Greece.
column467: >
column469: >We relaxed and did nothing all morning.
column474: >With Kai, Alex, Adam and I all sitting on the porch chatting and looking at the ocean I cant help but feel like I am back on Methana. So much has happened since then. I feel like Adam and I have changed and learned a lot of things already - especially from Kai.
column477:
>

Alex mom made us a delicious spinach + feta pie.
column478: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column483:
>

Nina cooking the yummy pie
column484: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column493: >In the evening we decide to do a hike.
column498: >It was not an ordinary hike.
column503: >It was walking down a river nestled in a mountain valley for 5km to a small village.
column508: >It was a special river in Greek mythology. This is the river that the dead travelled down to go to Hates, the underworld. A boat man would carry the souls of the dead down the river.
column513: >We drove 45 minutes to the hike. It’s hard to get there. The start of the hike is over a narrow mountain road with winds and twists, and the end of the hike is in the village. Since we had only one car, and the start and end of the hike are at different places, it maked things complicated.
column514: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column519:
>

Mountain roads to the river head
column524: >Our idea was this, Alex drops us at the start of the hike, in the mountains in the middle of nowhere, he drives back to the village (very far away) to park. And Alex then finds some way to get to us by hitch hiking to us. Once we would arrive we would start the hike.
column529: >Here were the problems with the idea.
column542: >It was 5:30PM and the sun sets at 9PM, and the sun is lost even earlier in the giant valley we were in. It was at least a 3 hour hike.
column547: >It might take him potentially hours to get someone to drive him to the middle of nowhere, back to us.
column552: >We had no cell service at the start of the trail so we just had to trust Alex would find his way. (The saving grace was that if he never came there were a few people camping in the valley with cars we could rely on in an emergency)
column557: >We tried it anyway.
column562: >Alex dropped us off and we started to wait. I relaxed in the afternoon sun by the river.
column563: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column568:
>

River left. And the old house.
column573: >There was an abandoned house across the river.
column578: >I climbed up and took a nap on the roof in the sun for a while.
column579: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column589: >We waited an hour and a half and eventually Alex arrived back to us.
column590: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column599: >He told us the story for how we got to us.
column604: >After about 10 minutes waiting he found a truck driver who would ride the route for him. This guys name was George Winter (epic name) and drove really slow through the winding mountain roads in his large truck, then dropped off Alex close enough to walk down into the valley where we were waiting.
column609: >George Winter had epic stories for Alex about his bike touring days (I think Alex mentioned he was with bike touring people).
column614: >We started the hike and it was great. We just walked and walked through the river.
column619: >We all had sandals on which was perfect for this hike since since we had to do a lot of walking in the river, it would have been terrible in shoes.
column620: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column625:
>

Walking down the river
column630: >Another side point about shoes. Is I have brought shoes on my bike tour but I have almost never worn them, one 2 times at the beginning of the tour, but since then, never. I think I have only worn sandals for the past 26 days or something. A part of me wants to send them home. I’ll keep them just in case, but it is an interesting tangent. Sandals are just the perfect shoe for everything the biggest advantage is no smelly feet from socks all day and your feet keep really cool temperature wise.
column635: >Okay back to the river hike.
column640: >The river got harder and harder to walk down. We had to do some easy rock climbing and step down small water falls.
column641: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column646:
>

river got slightly more techn
column651: >Eventually we came to a part that was completely impassible. It was a 3 meter waterfall and it looked very dangerous to jump in.
column656: >Before the hike we heard stories that you at some point need to jump off a waterfall to make it further down the river, but this looked way way too sketchy to be the spot. So we were left very confused about how to continue.
column661: >Then we started to follow what looked like a trail. But it quickly turned into us getting lost in the bushes he’s high above the river canyon. We climbed and climbed very steep tracks. It appeared as if we were following a trail made by wild boars.
column666: >It starts to get dark and we maybe had 20 minutes left. We used offline maps to see where we were in the bush and made our way down to a trail through thick thick bushes and very steep upward and downward hiking.
column671: >We had to climb down a tree for one section.
column676: >Somehow right before dark we found the trail again right beside the river. That felt good since we all had accepted the fact that we might be bush whacking for a while in the dark.
column681: >Once we got to the path we back tracked to the the thing we most wanted to see. The intersection of the hot and cold rivers together, this was the famous river that takes souls to the underworld.
column686: >Now it was our turn…
column691: >The best way was just to float down the river, so we all did. For the next two hours we floated down the river in the dark. Through a canon and small waterfalls. If it got too fast in the water we stood up and walked around, if it got too shallow we did the same.
column696: >One point we stopped and took photos. I love these photos.
column697: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column703: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column708:
>

Why is Adam petting Alex like a dog 😂😂
column713: >Floating down the river in the pitch black, with nothing but the moonlight was amazing, I felt at peace (except when we had to stand up for the rapid sections and waterfalls that looked to sketchy). These cannons and rivers remind me of the ones near my house, the only difference was the water here was not ICE cold, so we did not die of hypothermia like we would probably have done if we did the same thing at home.
column718: >We finally got to the end of the river and made it back to the car. That was the craziest hike I had ever done - probably. Mainly since we floated down a river in the dark and got lost in the bushes.
column723: >It felt amazing to get back to the apartment. I fell asleep right as i hit the bed.

column1: d85a56b8-5649-44a5-bf60-0a69eed2fe2a,#34 - Kai’s grand return.,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/33-kais-grand-return,June 22nd,#33 - Kai’s grand return.,June 22nd,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column466: >I missed the post yesterday due to being a little busy with some stuff all day. Anyhow here is the 22nd. Ill keep posting things as fast as I can :)
column467: text-align:start
column482: >June 22nd was a day trip by car around 150 kilometres into the mountains to a larger city Ioannina in Greece (Around 100,000 people).
column490: >Alex had to write his last exam to finish off the year at the University in Ioannina.
column498: >The plan for the day was to see the city after he finished his exam. So early in the morning we drove through the mountains to Ioannina. I slept almost the whole way in the car.
column499: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column504:
>

Car ride in the mountains
column509: >When we got to the University, I continued sleeping while he took his exam.
column514: >Once his exam was over, we then went around the city.
column515: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column520:
>

The streets and part of the castle.
column525: >Ioannina is beautiful. The city centre is built around one large Ottoman castle from when the Turcs occupied Greece and at the side of this castle is a 30km wide lake. To top it all off the city is completely surrounded by large mountains.
column526: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column541: >First thing we see when got to the city was another bike tourists bike.
column546: >But wait a second. We knew this bike! It was another cycle tourist from Switzerland that we met in Methana almost exactly one month before!
column551: >We soon stopped the car and got out to chat with him. He was equally surprised to see us. Yet another Methana person in Ioannina.
column556: >This was the famous bike tourist that carried the giant stick for protecting himself from dogs and was the first person we met who told us to go to the south of the Peloponnese.
column561: >We exchanged stories for a while over Giros (Greek pita and meat). We all thought it was amazing that we ended up at the same city with two extremely different paths to get there. When we met him in Methana he was catching a ferry to Athens.
column566: >After that we went back to the car and Alex took us to see a missive cave. We thought it was a god idea to dodge the heat and explore it.
column571: >We payed 3 euros and got a 45 minutes walking tour of a 2 km network of caves.
column576: >Here are some pictures. This cave was a walking cave compared to the last one on Mani, when they took us through a cave by boat.
column577: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column587: >This cave felt much much larger and to me, more impressive.
column588: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column597: >It was a nice 18 C in the cave which was great since outside it was 35 C.
column602: >We then went to the castle.
column607: >Outside of the castle spaced about its perimeter, were 35 art exhibitions. I took some photos of my favourite which I will share.
column608: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column613:
>

Not an exhibit but I loved the photo
column618: >One was a digital rhino on a big that moved and interacted with its environment. It was life size on the screen which loud speakers playing its rhino noises which made it feel like it was alive.
column619: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column629: >Another I liked was a digital screen of a flag on fire. I thought it contrasted well with the lake water behind it in the background.
column630: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column640: >After this we saw the castle and some cool view points of the city and lake from the top. Then we later in the shade and napped nearby. One of my favourite activities.
column645: >Eventually yet another thunderstorm came in and we fled the rest spot and went to the car.
column650: >We drove to the bus station and waited for a while.
column655: >Kai spent the last day on a bus from Patras to Ioaninna to come meet us all again.
column656: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column661:
>

Kai comes to meet us
column666: >We waited there until his bus arrived and had another epic reunion.
column671: >We somehow fit Kai’s bike in Alex’s tiny car. We had to keep taking apart his bike till it finally fit inside.
column672: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column677:
>

Somehow we fit it all in the car.
column682: >After dinner, we went to a good viewpoint of the city - there happened to be a rap concert going on. So we watched Greek community bands and wrappers play music with lots of other people around.
column683: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column698: >Eventually we went back to Igoumenitsa late at night and we all slept in the next day.
column703: >Now we are all back together.
column716: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td height=""10"" style=""line-height:1px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column466: >A day trip to Corfu.
column467: text-align:start
column470: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column479: >I am writing this on the ferry returning from Corfu to Igoumenitsa, where Adam and I have spent the day biking. I have a view of the sunset to my left, and Adam and I are sneakily drinking our beers on the front of the ship. We made a fantastic dinner with limited things, it cost us 7 euro, i’d say it’s pretty healthy. I’ll get to that at the end of the post.
column486: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column499: >If I did not already mention it, Alex is currently studying for and finishing off his last exams. He is studying mathematics in Greece and has two exams left. One was today (at the time of writing this he has finished one of the two, so he has one only left).
column519: >Since we planned to return to Igoumentisa in the evening, we did not need to bring most of our gear, so we just ran with one light bag that had electronics and room for food and drinks when we biked around Corfu.
column532: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column545: >We enjoyed the ferry over on the sea I listened to music sung some songs and stared out at the close by Greek islands. It’s always amazing to be on the sea.
column546: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column555: >I took pictures of the Giant yachts I saw, thinking one day it would be nice to own one - really just cause. I know I dont need a big yacht but if I could have one…. Why not?
column556: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column561: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column573: >So many tourists on the ferry. And I dont know why exactly but I feel so far removed from the traditional tourist. I feel like I connect more with the Greeks here now than the passer-biers from other European countries.
column574: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column586: >Adam and I say hi to everyone here in Greek, we even talk in between ourselves in a mix of Spanish and Greek. But here in Corfu, none of the tourist reply to use when we say hi in Greek ONLY THE Greeks. (And one Chinese family we saw said that to us and we were so happy).
column594: >We got off the ferry and cycled aimlessly around Corfu. I asked Adam to tell me a random number between 1 and 10, he said 8.
column595: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column608: >“Okay, so that means we stop for coffee at the 8th coffee shop we see.” I said.
column616: >We wanted coffee so thats how I decided where we would go.
column624: >We biked around the city counting coffee shops.
column625: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column637: >Corfu is beautiful, It looks way different that anything we have seen in Greece. In the past is was an island conquered by the Venetians (people from Venice Italy) so it has this Italian style too it.
column638: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column650: >This felt like the most touristy place we had visited. There were so many French people. Every second street I was hearing French.
column658: >One interesting thing is in the residential areas of Corfu we say that everyone hung their very colourful clothing in the street, above the small alleyways. This was crazy to me. Every Greek home I have been in has a washing machine, but NEVER a dryer. Very interesting…
column659: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column668: >When we finally arrived at a coffee shop we got doulble cappuccinos and sat in the shade in the afternoon heat. Once we finished we talked with the two students who were working at the coffee shop and asked them what we should see in Corfu while we are here for the day.
column676: >We left the conversation with a bunch of waypoints on our map for things to see.
column684: >One of which was the Old Fort. Ill throw a picture of the old fort that I took from the ferry below.
column685: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column690:
>

The fort from the sea
column698: >Normally tourist pay 6 euro to enter to see it.
column718: >“When you go to the old fortress. Go to the ticket booth and say this in Greek “Πάμε για μπάνιο (Pame ya banio)” and you might be able to just go in or free”
column732: >Turns out the fortress is right beside a beach where you can swim, which only locals do and know this.
column746: >I said in Greek, hello how are you. The ticket man said he was. good, Then I said “Pame ya banio”
column760: >I replied with the classic “ne” or yes in English and we walked by to the fortress without paying at all HAHA. We were shocked the trick from the coffee people worked.
column774: >We walked around the old Corfu fortress. It was cool, but we were not that impressed. At this point it’s pretty hard to impress us hahaha.
column775: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column787: >But we enjoyed the fortress and especially the fact that we did not need to pay, since we are on a tight budget here.
column795: >Yes I know that it’s dishonest - but we are students on a tight budget, we usually decided where to eat a restaurant depended on the priced of the food being too high by 1 euro. Each euro counts! Plus if they asked us to pay we would have. Or if the magic words didnt work we would have. I just wanted to try he local hack haha.
column796: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column801:
>

View from the top of fortress
column809: >Ethics aside let’s continue.
column817: >We left the fortress and biked to the next point, it was a cool part just south of the main city.
column818: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column831: >We hit some amazing trails! With the new gearing and no gear on the bike, we climbed some really technical rocks and roots on our bikes. It was really fun!
column832: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column844: >At one points I biked up this gravel trail and two Greek men stopped me. One with a Camera.
column845: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column857: >He asked me some questions, he was impressed by the bike - I think he thought I was a lunatic.
column865: >But he and the other man started to interview me with the camera. I answered some questions and afterwards it was all over he said that it was for local television.
column873: >I guess I am on local Greek television. Yippyyyyy, I am famous now.
column881: >He took my email and said he would send the clip when it goes on air. Let’s see if that actually happens lol. It was probably the worst interview ever. He asked me how I got here. I said I biked here. He asked me what I thought of the garden. I said it was nice. That was pretty much the interview. I’ll be surprised if they actually airs it haha.
column889: >We left the trails, biked some more around Corfu, and we took some pictures when we found a good spot.
column897: >Next big goal of the day was to bike to the other side of the island to go to one of the best beaches (According to trip advisor) in Corfu. We just needed to bike 20 measly kilometers to arrrive there. (It was called Gyflada beach)
column905: >So we biked and biked up and up till we got the the beach.
column913: >Here are some pictures
column914: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column926: >My only comment about the ride to the beach were we took a route with a lot of up hill, but biking up hill without all the bags and gears was easy - I hardly broke a sweat with the easy gearing and no bags.
column934: >When we arrived at the beach we were surprised that the trip adviser “Nicest beach” was only okay….. if you compare it to the beaches we have been spoiled with each night in Greece lol. It was very crowded.
column935: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column947: >Anyhow, we sat in the sand and drank our 1.5L bottle of wine we bought for 2 euros in Corfu old town and relaxed in the sand.
column955: >I knew Adam pretty well before the trip, but spending this much time with someone you start to learn even more. I enjoyed chatting over 2 euro beach wine with Adam.
column971: >Maybe 20 feet from where we were sitting two people pulled an unconscious old man out of the ocean.
column979: >I won’t go into too much detail, but it appeared as if an old man had had a heart attack while swimming, very close to where Adam and I were sitting. Someone pulled the man out of the water and he was laying motionless on the sand.
column987: >Quickly people swarmed, a lifeguard came, and CPR was performed.
column995: >I wont go through all the details, but the CPR did not help, and IED came about 10 minutes later and that did not work either.
column1003: >At the very end an ambulance took away the body.
column1011: >Adam and I watched the man die, assuming he was not dead before he left the water.
column1019: >It was hard to watch but we were okay. I had never seen a man die before and I don’t want to again.
column1027: >I was hoping he would make it but unfortunately he did not…..
column1035: >It was a sobering experience, this old man didn’t have any family with him at the beach, no body know who who he was.
column1043: >People crowded around, I even saw people taking photos…
column1051: >So…. Now I have seen Corfu, and had an unforgettable experience on Corfu.
column1059: >Soon we will arrive back in Igoumentisa, and sleep in Alex’s moms apartment another night.
column1060: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column1065:
>

7 euro dinner and I am very satisfied on ferry back
column1073: >I am very grateful to have met Alex, and Adam is too. It feels like we have a Greek cousin and are his family visiting Greece for the first time. We are getting a true Greek experience. Both Adam and I think that it’s unique and beautiful. We never could have planned something like this…
column1081: >I wish you all a great day, take care and enjoy the time we have.
column1087: class=""dd""><table class=""j"" role=""none"" width=""50%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td> &nbsp
column1093: >As it turns out when we got back from Corfu, Alex mom had mis is traditional cheese pie.
column1098: >It was delicious, and we were very happy :)
column1099: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

It was great sleeping in a bed again, beds are nicer than couches, and couches are better than the floor.
column467:
>

We woke up and made breakfast and just relaxed in the apartment. I spent more time learning Greek. I really enjoy reading greek aloud, it’s such a pretty language.
column470:
>

Adam then cooked everyone pasta and it was delicious.
column471: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column476:
>

Leaving for the beach by car
column479:
>

After that we left for the beach and drove with Alex in his car. In the car ride I found out from Alex that the highway I biked on yesterday was very dangerous and illegal for bikes to be on. I thought that also but it was unavoidable at that point, there was a large shoulder in the highway at the side so I was far away from the fast moving trucks.
column482:
>

Whoops. No more major highways for me.
column485:
>

It’s been a little while since I have been in a car it always feels like cheating - the hills are so much easier.
column486: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column493:
>

We got to the quiet beach and I took a nap in the sand and wrote a bunch of these posts.
column494: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column501:
>

Alex shows us a secret beach we had to swim too - it had this awesome arching cave. (I wish I had a picture)
column502: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column509:
>

We stayed here till the sun went down.
column510: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column517:
>

And returned to Igoumenitsa and went to bed early.
column520:
>

Tomorrow Adam and I would be taking a day trip to the island of Corfu while Alex writes his exams for school. Greek students are just now finishing up their school exam period.
column523:
>

Bye for now,
column526:
>

Erik
