column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

I think I am going to start writing these by saying where I am while I am writing it and at what time.
column467:
>

Instead of a the perfect mistake free careful posts I have been doing, I am just going to type about the day, at the end of the day before going to bed (Unles I am unable to write from too much Greek Tsipuro)
column468: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column476:
>

If you don’t remember or know who Alex is you should check back to one of the earlier posts called “The Chess Master” or something like this. He is the friend Adam, Kai, and I made on Methana.
column479:
>

I am currently writing this from Igoumenitsa, in the appartment of Alex’s mother. I just got the full tour of all the baby photos of Alex. He pretty much looks the same as he did when he was 10, just add a beard and long hair and voila!
column480: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column488:
>

Many moons ago when we met Alex and he showed us his hometown Greece on the map, I found it hard to believe that we would ever arrive there. Everything between Methana and Igoumenitsa was a giant fog.
column491:
>

After spending several weeks biking from there to Igoumenitsa, about 1000km later, I feel like the fog has lifted and I now have a much much better understanding of what Greece is like.
column494:
>

The big scary Peloponnese Mountains are no longer big and scary :)
column497:
>

Now how did we get to Igoumenitsa? It was a long day…
column500:
>

We woke up at the yoga facility in the small village early in the morning. We said goodbye to the old man who had let us sleep in the garden and we left.
column503:
>

The riding in the morning was not comparable to the days before, it was much worse. Hey but you you cant have the best day everyday.
column504: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column509:
>

Highway shade where we stopped for a rest
column512:
>

The morning was highway and farm roads.
column515:
>

We planned our route so we could skip a large bay, but to do this we had to cross a tunnel that goes under the ocean. A tunnel that you are not allowed to bike in. We heard from other cyclist we met that you can get across in an Ambulance, car, or taxi. They told us they tried to ride across the tunnel and alarms went off as they entered hahaha.
column516: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column521:
>

Waiting by the toll booth at the tunnel
column524:
>

We arrived at the tunnel and asked the man working at the toll booth to call us the ambulance to take us across. Yes, an ambulance lol.
column527:
>

We sat there for an hour then an emergency vehicle took us across, we signed some waivers signing away responsibility in the case of accidents and got a ride in the back of an ambulance through the tunnel.
column528: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column533:
>

Getting a ride through the tunnel
column536:
>

When we got through the tunnel it was about 1pm and we say the signs to Igoumentisa and it stayed 100km, we had already biked 25 LOL. We did not realize how far it was but we were determined to get there.
column539:
>

We just kept biking and biking, it was a crappy highway almost the entire way. There were not TOO many cars but more trucks that I would have liked. We did not have a choice really unless we biked an extra 40km the quieter way. But we wanted to get to Igoumentisa that same day, we were field by the opportunity to have a shower :). Big bike days are fun, its how you get stronger.
column542:
>

When we got closer to Igoumenitsa the road went from crappy to less busy and beautiful!
column545:
>

Ill share pictures I took from the road
column546: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column551: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column556:
>

Eventually I got some nice views again
column557: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column563: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column570:
>

My favourite moment of the ride was at the 105km mark, when I reached the top of the hill, and the next 20km was downhill. I was biking downhill on the highway shoulder probably around 70-80km and hour and had the best view of Igoumentisa when I came out of a tunnel.
column573:
>

I really wish I stopped and took the photo :)
column576:
>

I got to Igoumentisa about 30 minutes before Adam and this was the first time my butt was properly sore from biking so much.
column577: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column584:
>

Igoumentisa is a stunning place, A port town surrounded by a beautiful mountains and a magnificent bay. Just across the bay you can see the lights from Corfu shining at nighttime.
column585: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column590:
>

Adam and Alex chatting with other bike tourists
column593:
>

We met up with Alex and Adam and I followed him to his families apartment building. His aunt lives on the first floor and his mother on third floor.
column594: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column601:
>

Alex mom then made us food and we showered and enjoyed the evening with the great views from their balconies.
column602: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column607: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column612:
>

Food Alex’s mom made us.
column615:
>

Right before bed when I was exhausted I agreed to play Alex in chess. We couldn’t find 3 missing pieces, each side had 3 less pawns but we played anyway.
column618:
>

I got checkmated in 2 moves.
column621:
>

I went to bed right after that - by brain was no longer working
column624:
>

Adam and I slept in Alex’s childhood room.
column627:
>

Here it is. (I have the top bunk)
column628: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column635:
>

I think we will be in Igoumentisa for a while :)
column641:
>

Erik Dahl

column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

I am trying to catch up to present time with these posts. But the app I use to post only allowed posts every 12 hours.
column470:
>

So I will do 2 a day (my time zone 10 hours ahead of Vancouver) until I am caught up.
column473:
>

Here we gooooo. Another day biking north!
column474: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column483: >We woke up in the morning under the cover of the church and walked across the street back to the restaurant of last night.
column488: >They told us to come back in the morning for a coffee.
column493: >We drank coffee and said goodbye and hit the road.
column494: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column503: >Today was the first day that we went on the actual official EuroVelo route. Basically it means that it’s marked as a road good for cycling.
column504: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column512:
>

PS - at this point, seeing hers of sheep on the reads is completely normal. I think we have seen 8 or 9 herds in our trip. It’s pretty easy to pass but you need to be careful with sheep dogs.
column513: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column525: >Wow wow wow the ride was unreal. It was a coastal highway with very low traffic and stunning views of the mountains and ocean.
column526: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column536: >Eventually we stopped on a beach when we entered this stunning bay to cook lunch, swim, and nap in the shade.
column537: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column542:
>

Gravel trail to the beach.
column547: >We left the beach and continued biking.
column548: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column554: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column559:
>

More pictures of the scenery
column562:
>

We biked for a while just cursing to ourselves about how beautiful it all is.
column563: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column571:
>

Probably the most scared I have been on this trip was today…
column574:
>

Bulls. SO MANY bulls just sitting on the road. They have massive horns and we were terrified of them charging us.
column577:
>

Fortunately we always found a way around them. Mainly by walking our biked as far as we could away from them. Terrifying.
column582: >At around 6 pm we pulled over at the side of the road to look on the map to see if we could find a campsite in the next 10-15 kilometres.
column587: >Now right at this exact moment an elderly Greek man pulled out from his farm on his motorcycle, right beside us.
column592: >He both said hello and he asked us what we were looking for. We said a good place to camp and just like that he invited us to camp in his friends garden in his village up the road.
column597: >We followed him on his motorcycle about 5-10 kms - doing our best to keep up with him.
column598: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column603:
>

Following the old man with the motor bike.
column608: >We got to his friends garden. He had fresh cold water and gave us fruit. And we had a garden hose to take a shower.
column609: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column619: >We then walked down to the beach and cooked dinner and watched the sunset.
column620: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column629: >We talked to the man and learned more about his life, but we were tired and went to bed shortly after.
column630: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column640: >A great day with more of the best biking in my life and kind people :)

column1: 9d188247-d985-4fdb-a912-9c1afbccb5c7,#29 - the advantage of biking in a thunderstorm ,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/29-advantage-biking-thunderstorm,June 17th,#29 - the advantage of biking in a thunderstorm ,June 17th,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column426: > #29 - the advantage of biking in a thunderstorm
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column466: >Wow today was an absolutely incredible day.
column467: text-align:left
column471: >And guess what…. We left Patras :)
column472: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column481: >I’m picking up more and more Greek, I mean i talk like a 5 year old baby but I think I pronounce most of the sounds correctly I am able to read and write all the Greek letters. Add I have many basic frases down and I can make simple sentences to be understood.
column486: >Where is the … bathroom, store, super market,
column491: >Can I use the
column501: >Do you like this?
column506: >I can say “I speak a little Greek” or “say nice to meet you” and ask for names.
column511: >Im writing in my journal all the Greek words I learned and I have several pages of Greek words written down.
column516: >Greek is a beautiful language and it’s going to be hard for me to leave Greece and stop learning Greek. Who knows it might be the next language to learn
column526: >We left Patras. We felt eager to move again. Today was simple - just bike north. We didnt look at the map at all for the first 50 or so kilometers since we just knew we need to follow the coast and go north. The ride out of Patras was amazing an it felt wonderful looking out at the Peleponeeses, the massive mountains in the background and knowing that Adam and I had bilked over them.
column527: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column536: >The ride out of Patras had a spectacular view. It’s probably just better to show the pictures.
column537: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column542:
>

Peloponnese in the background
column543: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column556: >We biked and biked, just the usual, I listened to podcasts, music, and thought about life. Eventually, we got hungry and stopped for lunch. I was tired and I took a short nap under an olive tree. Adam had more energy so he continued on and we split up.
column561: >We planned a little route together - somewhere we could maybe camp on a beach another 50 kilometres away.
column566: >We said we would meet there or I would bike faster and catch Adam along the way.
column571: >I napped for about 30-35 minutes and started biking with the afternoon sun alone.
column576: >Adam and I bike a lot together, but it’s also nice to sometimes bike alone. You get to go your own pace and choose your own routes. The are both nice from time to time.
column577: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column586: >Then lighting struck. Out of nowhere it was raining buckets and I was biking on a farm field in a lighting storm. I left the field I was in and bike towards taller trees. The disadvantage was I was biking in trails and getting covered in mud.
column587: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column592:
>

Thunder clouds rolling in
column597: >I think the closest the lightning got was 3 km away. Though I had to bike in the direction of it to make progress to the beach. I remember biking and a giant fork lighting bolt was write ahead of me (3km away from sound delay)
column602: >Eventually the storm went away and the rain stopped. I passed a small tavern and stopped and got some food and wrote yesterdays post and an amazing google review for the bike shop in Patras that helped me upgrade my bike.
column603: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column608:
>

Stopped at the taverna - bike looking coool
column613: >I was there maybe an hour, so I was about an hour and a half behind Adam. I figured I would see him at the beach which was about 30 km away.
column618: >I took a detour through some town and when I got to a gas station I was shocked it see Adam there. He told me he was filling up water and took a wrong turn at one point. It was just a complete fluke that we both had made mistakes on the route in a way that we came together again.
column623: >We biked together for maybe another 7 kilometers when another rain storm hit. This was was heavy heavy rain. We instantly looked for shelter where we could stop.
column628: >We saw an elevated concrete house with cover underneath it and a Greek teenager sitting underneath it. He whistled and waved at us and we decided to go closer.
column633: >i asked him in greek if it was okay if we come here to hide form the rain and he was very happy to have us there. He brought us chairs and offered us water.
column638: >He was 15 years old did not speak English, so we had a very basic conversation and then I would use google translate to ask him questions.
column643: >We sat and talked for while until eventually a truck pulled up to his house.
column653: >His Mother, Father, and older brother got out of the truck and he introduced us.
column658: >After introductions, when they saw the bikes and we were from Canada, they offered us Greek coffee. We said thank you and yes.
column659: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column669: >A few minutes later they set up tables and chairs for us and gave us coffee and this thing called Chocolate Pasta (that’s the Greek direct translation it was like ice cream)
column674: >We sat there over coffee and had a conversation in Basic Greek and English with the help of google translate.
column690: >That’s one word i know in Greek. It means food!
column698: >They were offering us food. We were happy to accept and moments later they brought out Bread olive oils and risotto. We ate the food they brought us and continues our conversation. After we finished they even offered us more but we were so full we couldn’t eat any more.
column699: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column709: >They asked us where we were staying and we showed them the beach. They said it was too far and we can just sleep in the town center of the village. We could sleep under cover there from a church archway and they said everyone in the village would be okay with this.
column717: >We said goodbyes and took a photo.
column718: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column727: >Our Greek teenaged friend then lead us using his motorbike or the spot where we could camp. He was crazy with the motorbike doing wheelies and drifting. We were so shocked haha.
column728: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column733:
>

Following him on the motorbike
column738: >We got to the square and hung out with him and his Greek friends that appeared out of nowhere. It turns out there isn’t much to do for them in the little village so they enjoyed teaching us more Greek swear words. Malaka Malaka (the only Greek swear word you need)
column743: >Once they all theft Adam and I went across the street to buy a beer from a little taverna where old Greek men were sitting outside on the patio. (If I did not already mention thats the hallmark of a great coffee shop, old Greek men smoking outside it with beer and coffee)
column748: >We walked in, saying out Greek, Hello how are you, etc haha. They always look so surprised when you talk in Greek and are obviously not from Greece.
column753: >Right as we entered the taverna the one older gentlemen that could speak basic English was talking to us. He bought us both beers.
column754: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column759:
>

The all day coffee and beer shop across the street
column764: >We sat there taking with him on the patio, then we moved inside for the mosquitoes were attacking us, and we spent several hours in Greek conversations with the owners and workers in the taverna, exchanging English and Greek, and even learning some Albanian. Some of the people in the taverna were Albanian.
column769: >I learned a lot of Greek words and tomorrow morning Adam and I will go back to their shop since they offered us coffee in the morning before we start cycling.
column774: >We left the taverna saying goodnight, everyone parting ways with giant smiles. We then walked across the street to our fancy hotel room under the archway of the church.
column779: >Im gonna sound like a broken record here but people are increíble.
column784: >We got free dinner, dessert and beer. I only wish I could speak Greek better to learn more about all their lives. The waiter in the taverna has 300 goats and the family who made us dinner has about the same amount. Incredible.
column789: >How does this make me feel?
column794: >If I had 1$ for ever time someone told me Greece was dangerous to bike through (many locals say this lol) I’d probably be incredibly rich. Well actually I’d have like $30 or something.
column799: >All I see or receive is kindness from people. I’m still digesting this. But it makes me want to give more to others, pay this kindness forward.
column804: >Wow I wrote a lot today. I wrote this first thing upon entering my tent after leaving the taverna. If you made it this far. bravooooo. I appreciate you for caring enough to read it all. Let me know what you think what happened today. It felt incredibly special and I hope me writing this down helps me to never forget it.
column809: >Here were the night accommodations, in the middle of the village under the church archway.
column810: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column828: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td height=""10"" style=""line-height:1px

column467:
>

June 16th
column472: >I got a text from the Bike ship that the bike part came in! I went left for the shop first thing in the morning.
column473: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column478:
>

Skyros working on the bike
column483: >They installed it and it worked! They thought that it might not work due to the fact that the parts are from different companies and say they are not compatible. But hey, it works. I can now use a way way easier gear which will help with the many future mountains we need to climb.
column491: >Again another outstanding experience with bike shops in Greece!
column495: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column500:
>

Bike with new tiny front gear rings
column505: >I met Adam and Alex back at the study cafe in Patras and we hung out there and had some breakfast.
column506: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column519: >I went back to the apartment we made Greek salad, we ate some of the meat pie and Nikos mom made, and I made this amazing dessert, copied from the restaurant in Ancient Olympia, apple Greek yogurt, honey, and cinnamon.
column522:
>

Here’s the food we made.
column523: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column529: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column535: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column545: >After the food I passed out. and slept for rest of the day on the couch.
column553: >In the evening Nikos Adam and I went out to listen to traditional music. Nikos friends were performing in a little Taverna in the center of town.
column554: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column561:
>

That’s all for the 16th. I was extremely satisfied with the bike upgrade and Im excited to use it to climb steep steep hills in mountain trails
column564:
>

I’ll post again in a few hours to make up. I have them all written until June 20th.

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

I am supposed to write about june 16th but I just did a humungous day on the bike (this was the first really hot day, (it’s a tan not a burn i swear (wow so many nested parentheses))). I don’t have the energy to recollect the past, I want to do June 16th justice. Expect several post tomorrow to make it up.
column470:
>

Instead I will do a little reflection and post it on the internet for everyone to read lol.
column473:
>

Wow. This has been an incredible trip. I had no expectations for I had not even the slightest idea what to expect of such a far away place I knew nothing about - but the trip has already been unforgettable. I am grateful for the luck and privilege I have to be able to come here. I keep meeting people who have never left their village or Greece.
column476:
>

Again and again I am blown away by the kindness of people.
column479:
>

The tomatoes in Greece taste amazing.
column482:
>

Olive oil is the best oil.
column485:
>

Bike touring is the best way to travel. You really earn every stop, every view, every interaction. It’s a great feeling looking back and knowing that you crossed the mountains that stretch out as far as the eyes can see.
column488:
>

Bike touring is not easy, but its not hard. Adam and I are doing big days on the bike, like 12-14 hours of biking. You don’t need to do that to your butt. Today I met a French cyclist who spent SIX MONTHS biking in Greece. He just goes little by little and rests as much as he wants - biking 20 -30 km a day.
column491:
>

I will write more about my opinions on bike touring in the future
column494:
>

Hope you enjoyed my 12:30AM brain dump. I don’t have the energy to write about June 16th right now but I had enough to energy to type some of my reflections.
column497:
>

Until tomorrow where I will give you more posts that you can read.

column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column464:
>

Keeping this one short today.
column467:
>

Another relaxing day in Patras. Here are the quick highlights.
column468: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column476:
>

We ate at this Patras famous “home food” place. I got two plates it was delicious.
column479:
>

After eating the two plates I had a 6 hour nap
column482:
>

When I woke up - i participated with Adam and Alex in a protest for the refugees who were let to die out at sea a few days ago. It was a sad story.
column485:
>

From what I heard, refugees were being smuggled across the Aegean Sea. Then while the Greek police tried to push the boat out of Greek waters they broke the boat, did not rescue them, and let 50 people drown.
column488:
>

The protest was a walk through the streets of Patras.
column489: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column497:
>

after the protest we went to a birthday party of Claire who we met the day before.
column500:
>

Her apartment had a great view. We had a BBQ on their balcony. Great conversations and great cake.
column501: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column507: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column515:
>

Also these posts are a few days behind of real time. What do you think should I post two tomorrow to catch up closer to real time? Reply and let me know.

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

June 14th I had one main goal. Find smaller front gears to make climbing more easily.
column467:
>

I biked around to every bike shop in Patras I could find. The first bike shop I went to said it would be very hard to find the parts I needed for my bike in Patras, but they said I could order a part that would come Friday.
column468: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column476:
>

I said I would look around first and went to three other bike shops nearby. All of them did not have anything that would work with my bike.
column479:
>

At one of the bike shops I asked to weigh my bike out of curiosity. It took me and the mechanical working together to lift it up to the hanging scale. The mechanics face went pale and we had to instantly take it off the scale. He said that the bike was over the weight limit of 40kgs. I guess I will never know how much it weighs - maybe its better that way.
column482:
>

After checking all the other shops with no luck I went back to the original bike shop and ordered the part. They said it would come Friday probably and it may or may not work.
column485:
>

I went for the gamble and ordered the part.
column488:
>

I met up with Adam after who had bought some things from a camping store. He bought a bug net so he could sleep without getting so hot at night if he wanted to and I was helping im find a orientation that would work with the bug net.
column489: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column494:
>

Adam fiddling with a mosquito net
column497:
>

Finally we met Alex at an awesome little garden coffee shop. It was a coffee shop. Restaurant for students or people who want a quite place to work or study. The shop was filled with Greeks studying for exams. It’s exam season here now.
column498: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column506:
>

In the evening when we got back to the apartment Nikos and Pavlos had hosted a birthday party for their friend and we all participated. It was not a normal birthday party it was a dress up and acting performance / competition about a political event that happened in the city years before. It’s really hard to explain, but it was about Anarchist squatting in a building and taking it over - something along these lines. Since it was all in Greek I did not understand anything but the swear words they used haha. Malaka Malaka.
column509:
>

It was still fun to witness.
column510: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column515:
>

They made this poster for the show birthday
column518:
>

When I first got to Patras the day before it felt big, but after a day biking around it actually feels very very small. I guess I was comparing it to the villages from the days before. Anything is big compared to the three home farm village.
column521:
>

So now I am waiting in Patras to at least Friday. Which was yesterday. Keep reading to learn if I will ever leave Patras or if i will get a Greek citizenship and live in Patras forever.
column524:
>

Bye for now,

column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

We woke up on the floor of the restaurant at 6am. The floor was very comfortable and warm all night.
column467:
>

Yesterday I left my bike helment in Kostsos bike shop in Pyrgos. So we need to bike back to his shop then go up to Patras. We used a routing app to find the best route, and we found one we thought we could do from Ancient Olympia to Patras through Pyrgos.
column468: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column473:
>

Big day to Patra from Olympia
column476:
>

We needed to stop in Patras for multiple reasons.
column487: > In Methana about one month ago we ordered electronic keyboard that we could use with our phones to make writing these blog posts easier
column490: > In Patras there are many bike shops and there was a possibility I can get better gearing to make biking up the hills easier. I have a 30 teeth on my smallest front gear and 36 teeth on by biggest back gear. This gives me a ratio of 36:30 of about 1.2. The higher this number for gear the easier climbing hills is. I get more help from the gears. 1.2 is fine if I have no heavy bags, but my bike weighs about 50-60kg with all the bags on it. For reference, Adam had a 1.8 gear ratio and Kai has a 2.2 gear ratio! They can climb up walls with their bikes. A 1.2 ratio makes it way way more taxing on my knees. My goal in Patras was to get a smaller front gear to make the ratio higher. The parts I needed are very hard to find for my bike. I have a front gear system that they do not make anymore - and also three front gears which is less common. We have many more mountains to climb.
column493: > We found out that Alex is in Patras staying with friends! He would help us find a place to stay in city somewhere. We wanted to visit Alex again and catch up. It had been a few weeks since we left him in Methana - too bad Kai did not make it Patras as well.
column496:
>

We left the restaurant in perfect order. Making sure not to leave any mess for George. We wrote a small thank you note and headed out.
column497: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column505:
>

We started the day with a cold brew Greek coffee. It was soo easy to make and we will be doing this again. We didn’t need to boil any water in the morning.
column506: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column514:
>

We had very quiet roads all the way to Pyrgos. We biked the same way we did the day before. Going to Olympia just turned out to be a 40km excursion. It was out of the way but well worth the visit.
column517:
>

We got to Pyrgos again and I went to Kostos bike shop to get my helmet. Of course I told him about how awesome the tires were working and I thanked him.
column520:
>

We left Pyrgos following a small road, on the map it looked like it would take us right to Patras (It was not so easy as it looked). It was not that busy with cars, small amounts of traffic most of the way. We made sure not to take the big national highway.
column521: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column526:
>

Starting on the road to Patra
column529:
>

The road was beautiful once we got in the middle of the Peloponnese. We started to climb slowly and we had great view of lush valleys. This side of the Peloponnese looks so very different from the other side. The best part is its is much more flat. The hills and mountains are much smaller.
column530: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column538:
>

For many hours we biked and biked. Adam got this epic shot on his camera below.
column539: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column547:
>

At one point, the map told us to take a turn onto this gravel road, it looked like it was going to connect to a major car way (not busy but two lanes). All we needed to do was cross a bridge and take a dirt road for a kilometre and we would arrive at the lake for lunch.
column550:
>

But when we arrived there was so much construction, giant trucks and dogs running around.
column553:
>

I asked where the water was to cross, and he pointed me to where to go.
column556:
>

When we arrived we saw this…
column557: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column565:
>

I asked one of the constructions workers where he bridge was in Greek. he replied acting out the motion of swimming and pointed to the flowing river ahead haha….
column568:
>

So we crossed the river carrying our bikes across. It’s a good thing we bike in sandals.
column569: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column577:
>

When we got to the other side, the road we were supposed to take was no more. AKA it was destroyed completely so we had to take a detour around.
column580:
>

It was really fun biking some gravel again. The new big tires are awesomeee.
column581: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column589:
>

Eventually we got to the lake to have lunch and we sat under a tree in the shade for a few hours to cool off. I cooked some pasta with lentels and other beans. Yum
column592:
>

We then started the climb of the trip over the mountain in the picture below.
column593: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column598:
>

We had to go up and around that mountain.
column601:
>

Adam reached the top of the mountain climb first. It was short and steep. Average gradient of around 13 percent for a little more than a kilometre.
column604:
>

When I got to the top I saw Adam stopped and a herd of sheep once again blocking the road. Adam looked all jacked up ‘ he told me when he tried to pass a pack of sheep dogs circled him all barking like crazy. He had to swing his bike at them to get them o back off.
column607:
>

We came up with an idea to get by the sheep. We formed this tank like structure with our bikes and marched through the dogs and sheep and goats. The dogs went crazy but we got through as a pair much more easily.
column608: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column615:
>

Most of the ride after that point was down. So we enjoyed a big decent. It was really cool looking back at the mountain from behind. And we went fast down the decent so I was happy I had gotten my helmet back.
column618:
>

We got to Patras at some food and went to find Alex.
column621:
>

Patras is the third largest city in Greece it felt strange. We quickly got used to the tiny villages where there are more cats than cars. Big city biking is just different.
column622: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column630:
>

We found the apartment and Alex waiting for us. It was fun to see him again! We got to wear clean clothes again and shower (It had been a little more than a week without showering ).
column633:
>

And our keyboards were waiting for us! Now writing blogs is 10x more enjoyable. I can write in a little more detail. I was very happy as you can see below.
column634: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column642:
>

Alex found us a place to stay with his friends of friends Pavlos and Nikos in their apartment. We went there to meet them and all had drinks and chatted on their balcony. It’s amazing that they let us stay with them without ever meeting us or even meeting Alex.
column643: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column648:
>

Meeting Alex’s Friends of Freinds
column651:
>

They were extremely nice and helpful. They told us the best placed to eat and the best bike shops to go to. We also got some live music from Nikos who is an amazing singer and musician. He played traditional Greek music for us and Adam drank his homemade Tsoupuro (I had decided I dont get along with this drink ahah)
column652: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column657:
>

Nikos on the traditional string instrument
column660:
>

They have a really big apartment with a cool view of the streets of Patras. Nikos and Pavlos let us sleep on their couch.
column661: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column668:
>

Again, people are just so kind :). If you get an opportunity you should host a random cyclist tourist in your house haha. It’s always a really awesome experience for the cyclist who are used to camping in dirt.
column669: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column677:
>

The next day I will be looking around Patras bike stores for a smaller front gear system. 🙂 Check back tomorrow to see if I found it.
column680:
>

Nights accommodations for the next few nights.
column681: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column688:
>

(Don’t worry mom I cleaned up my stuff after this photo)
column691:
>

Have a great day,

column426: > #24 - When a meal turns into a place to sleep.
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

Thanks for all the replies in the last post. Yes i get all the emails! It’s great to read what you think. Please reply as frequent as you like. Iif you read something and it gives you thoughts you feel like sharing - let me know.
column465: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: >
column472:
>

We woke up on the incredible beach as usual. Beaches make the best campsites as I have mentioned. The night before it was another one of those mosquitoes nights. Each time I would kill three mosquitoes on my leg four more would instantly come to replace them. Thankfully in the morning all the mosquitoes were gone.
column473: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column484:
>

Here are some shower thoughts about Greece before recount the 12th
column495: > Greek men say “Of course” a lot. Anytime you ask them a question they say it. This sounds kinda funny like they expect you to already know it as it sooo obvious that they know how to spear fish. Of course!
column498: > Olives and beer go really good together. Eat an olive and take a sip. Repeat.
column501: > There are soooo many dogs. They pop out all the time at us while biking its like a video game.
column504: > Lots of people smoke in Greece and I found this contradiction below in a restaurant. A no smoke sign and an ash tray beside each other as everyone in the cafe was smoking except us
column509:
>

No smoking but theres an ash tray
column515:
>

Okay on with the day.
column518:
>

Our only mission for the day was to get my bike tire fixed. We needed to bike about 35 km to do it. My bike tire and tube only needed to last that far - then I needed to find a bike shop in the city (Google helped with this) and find tires that would fit on my bike. (I would take what I could find).
column521:
>

The first part of the bike ride was a little annoying. We chose to take quiet roads instead of the highway but those quiet roads quickly turned into gravel roads. As I mentioned yesterday my rear tire had an air leak - and while it was slowly leaking, the gravel road’s impacts quickly pushed out more and more air.
column524:
>

Every 10 minutes on the way to the bike shop I had to stop and put air in my rear while with my hand pump. I think I burned more calories that morning with the hand pump than actually biking.
column527:
>

Basically all morning it was frustrating gravel roads with a flat tire.
column528: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column536:
>

We finally got to the city and found the bike shop. Back to biking in Greek cities its much harder. I think Adam and I are now comfortable in the hectic driving and I have made some strategies for not getting too lost in the maze- like streets.
column537: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column545:
>

The bike shop was great. It was called Kostos bikes and it was a small shop. The owner of the shop only spoke Greek and he was the only staff there. When we entered the shops I showed him the tire he instantly got to work.
column546: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column554:
>

In Vancouver, you have to wait forever for service and its expensive. In Greece it was instant. He did everything we could to help me.
column557:
>

He went to see what tires he said would work and I had two options - a smaller tire and a bigger tire for more trails (30mm was the small and 38mm was the big).
column560:
>

With the big tire we knew it would not fit with the fenders (the things that block dirt spray on the bike that go above the tire) and we also did not know if it would fit without the fenders on.
column563:
>

Even so I said lets go with the big ones since it would make the many gravel and dirt roads so much more enjoyable.
column566:
>

The tires fit just barely. They turned out to be the largest size that my bike could functionally support- wooo hoooo. I had to ditch my old fenders, but well worth it (I would just get more dirty in the rain and mud).
column569:
>

While Kosto was working on the bike we met his friend Emiliano, who spoke English very well who was also in the shop. He was a bike racer from Pyrgos (The city we were in) and shared with us all the bike routes he would do in the city. He also convinced us that we NEED to go see the nearby (20 km away) Ancient Olympia - where lies the ruins of the temple of Zeus and where they hosted all the Olympic Games in the name of Zeus.
column572:
>

Unfortunately it was in the opposite direction of where we wanted to go (it would be like going backwards) but we decided to take an extra day and see it - or at least go for a quick visit and bike back to Pyrgos afterwards.
column575:
>

After the bike was finished Emiliano showed us the best cheap Giros near by to eat for lunch. Giros are pita and the meet from the spinning meat cooker thing.
column578:
>

I left the bike shop very happy and I got the best and most helpful service from a bike shop ever. He cleaned my bike, lubed the chain and checked many little things on the bike.
column579: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column584:
>

new tires on bike (after riding trails later)
column587:
>

I bought some tools and bike lube that I was missing, got new tires and tubes, got a full service - all for 100 euros. This would be much more expensive in Canada.
column590:
>

We left Pyrgos and soon hit the trails and farm roads that would take us to Ancient Olympia
column593:
>

My life was changed with the new tires. It was the best feeling ever riding on the gravel roads. It was like playing the video game on hard and switching to easy mode. It was like treading water with weights and taking them off afterwards. I could not wipe the smile off my face and stop telling Adam how much better gravel riding felt.
column596:
>

I had grip on the road and on the trails, everything became easier (expect climbing on road hills due to more frictions, this became much much harder haha)
column599:
>

After some of the most peaceful and fun gravel roads we got to Ancient Olympia.
column602:
>

We went to all three of the archeological sites, the two museums and the ancient city where they had the games, the Tempe of Zeus, and more things. here are some pictures I took.
column603: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column608: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column614: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column619:
>

Many Greek gods - told temple roof relief.
column620: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column628:
>

While at the Temple of Zeus, there was a flash thunderstorm and heavy rain. Fitting for the god with a lighting bolt. We all hid under the entrance of the Archaeological site packed like sardines with 30 other tourist dodging the rain. I wrote one of these blog posts while I was sitting in a puddle there. Free shower.
column631:
>

Once it started raining we decided we would not go bike back to the coast to camp but instead stay in Ancient Olympia - we just did not know
column634:
>

where. Of course, right as I get rid of my fenders it started to rain. Murphy’s law.
column637:
>

At around 8 pm we showed up at a nearby campsite. The rain had died down. When we talked to the owner he said all the campsites where flooded and no tents could be pitched there. So we negotiated a sleeping spot on the floor near the registration for a few less euros.
column640:
>

We left the campsite to go for diner, we just biked back to the village. Plan was drink some beers and eat some Musaka (Really yummy Greek food that is like Shepard’s pie.)
column643:
>

We went from restaurant to restaurant trying to find the best price. On one of the restaurants I looked at a menu and a Greek man came up to me and giving me his pitch for why his restaurant is the best.
column646:
>

I tried to negotiate the Musaka price down by one euro to match other restaurants - he came back for reasons why his restaurant was the best, free pita bread, desert, and salad.
column649:
>

He convinced me and Adam and we chose his restaurant.
column652:
>

We ordered the Musaka and had a delicious 3 course meal for 10 euros. He did as he promised and we got the delicious pita with hummus and feta, a sweet salad, the Musaka, and a brilliant dessert combination of Greek yogurt, honey, cinnamon, and apple. This is a recipient I will be recreating later on the bike tour.
column653: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column658:
>

couldnt wait to take the photo - we had to eat it first.
column661:
>

At the end of the meal the Greek man, George. Who say our bikes from the beginning asks us where we are from why we have bikes with so much stuff. We told him and chatted for a while.
column664:
>

Then he asked us where we were staying, we said a campsite, and he offered us a place to sleep in the restaurant for free. We would sleep on the floor of the restaurant with our sleeping bags and be protected from rain and we dont need to set up our tents.
column667:
>

So we said yes! And spent the evening in his restaurant, they gave us discounts on beer and wine while we took it easy until the restaurant closed for the night.
column668: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column673:
>

Chillin in the restaurant till closing
column676:
>

The rest of the night went like this.
column687: > Adam and I left the restaurant to go to the washroom the the back alley.
column690: > In route Adam and I met a class of students from Spain.
column693: > We talked for a while and went for drinks in the little town. They were all so surprised to find two Canadians sleeping in a restaurant that both happen to speak Spanish
column696: > Now we have friends in Northern Spain :). I hope we get to go there.
column699:
>

Yet again I was surprised by the kindness of people. It was amazing that George saw us and offered us a place to sleep for free. He said next time we come and we can stay in his tree house he is building. I guess we will have to come back to Ancient Olympia one day.
column702:
>

Here was the accommodations for the night.
column703: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column708:
>

sleeping in the restaurant floor.
column726: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td height=""10"" style=""line-height:1px

column1: f82e7fb8-7493-4bbc-bf05-af1f5836a192,#21 - the day where everything goes wrong,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/21-day-everything-goes-wrong,June 9th,#21 - the day were everything goes wrong,June 9th,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column426: > #21 - the day where everything goes wrong
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

I’m writing this at the temple of Zeus in Ancient Olympia. Currently there is a thunderstorm going and 20 people are all huddled under the only shelter from rain in the archway of the entrance to the archeological site. I guess Zeus is angry.
column465: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: >
column472:
>

Back to writing about the day where everything went really good - then really bad.
column473: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column480:
>

We woke up early so that we would to be first one at the cave, mainly to bike before it gets hot. When we arrived at the ticket booth at 8, there were already Germans waiting there with theirs RVs (this did not surprise me at all). We had to wait 2 hours before the caves would actually open up to let people in.
column481: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column489:
>

We entered the caves and it was absolutely incredible. It was a 2km cave network and the take you on a small (and very tippy) boat through it. The driver has a stick that he uses to push the boat inside the rocks. The cave at times is only wide enough for the boat to just fit - and I many times had to duck to dodge rocks .
column490: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column498:
>

Inside the cave was interesting. There were 1 million year old limestone rocks that shimmered with the lights of the cave and rocks that looked like icicles.
column501:
>

They also had names for all the cave rooms such as red apartment, white apartment (which did not make any sense to me), Hercules’ rocks, and water 30 metres deep at some points.
column504:
>

I felt like a real tourist wearing the silly life jackets.
column505: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column513:
>

When we finished in the cave, it was an hour later,l than when we planned to leave. we had to start biking in the middle of the day. We biking in the heat until aerepoli where we went to a taverna that was recommended to use by the chef of the cafe we visited on the other side of Mani.
column516:
>

When we arrived, it was closed, we were told to come back in 3 hours. I explained that we had received a recommendation for her restaurant and we bike there to eat specifically there. We showed her the name in Greek for what food we were told to try there. After that she changed her mind and opened the kitchen early just for us. It was sooo delicious.
column517: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column522:
>

Adam after sitting down
column523: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column531:
>

At the end she brought us a free dessert too 😋
column534:
>

In the afternoon, after getting started again leaving Areopoli. Things started to go wrong.
column537:
>

We were biking down the first hill out of the city, and on a sharp turn while leaning my bike, my tires slipped out and I slid a few feet with my bike on the concrete.
column540:
>

I was okay. I got up and only had scrapped elbow and a bruised leg. We chilled for a while on the side of the road and cleaned up my scrapes and continued on.
column543:
>

My eggs I was carrying didn’t crack! And only one of my two tomatoes was smushed.
column546:
>

Reflecting on the fall, I leaned my bike too much for slow speed I was going at - and combined that with a lack of focus caused me to slip out. I got lucky that some scrapes is all I had and I’m going to be much more careful (more on this later)
column549:
>

Next thing that went wrong was while we were going downhill on another street climb, Adam olive oil he was carrying on the front rack of his bike exploded all over him and his breaks! He suddenly found it way harder to break. We were fortunately able to stop but we then spent an hour cleaning olive oil off the rims of his bike and his break pads - that stuff is difficult to get off when it gets everywhere 😂.
column552:
>

Here was the view while we did that.
column553: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column561:
>

The rest of the day was very pleasant- minus the scrapes, bruises and olive oil.
column562: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column570:
>

We got to a small port side town and followed a British cyclist through a bike path through one city then following the road right at the base of a big climb (saving it for the next morning).
column571: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column576:
>

Sea side road view
column590: > It’s way way to hot during the day to climb mountains
column593: > Out average day here is insanely hard - like biking up seymour, grouse and cypress (Local mountains in Vancouver, Canada) every day. It’s really really hilly. Up and down.
column596: > We get baffled looks biking through the tourist areas 😂- and in tourist areas we always get smiles, waves, and “yaaaa” (which means hello)
column599:
>

Things go wrong in bike tours - and more things have gone wrong since this day im writing about haha. you will have to wait and see what. The only spoiler I’ll give is that we always find solutions.
column600: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

Adam and I are really enjoying camping beach to beach. It’s completely free and we have the ocean to do dishes and go to the washroom 😂 (don’t worry we do both of those at different times).
column467:
>

It’s also great to have a shower in the ocean as well - it really sucks going to bed covered in sweat.
column470:
>

Now on to the longest day so far with the tour.
column471: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column476:
>

we really wanted to be on a beach again.
column479:
>

Anyway, we woke up at 6 AM, to get a Headstart on the day and to skip biking in the crazy heat. And our plan was to get to the big city, Kalamata well before 4 o’clock, when they would be a bus that takes us from Kalamata to Patras. it was supposed to be a short and easy day, just 30 km, but with only one big morning climb, 400m elevation, over 14 kilometres.
column480: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column488:
>

We made our way up to climb slowly, it was a great idea to start earlier made the climb way easier.
column489: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column497:
>

We got to Kalamata around 11:30, and while we were eating Souvlaki for lunch, we decided to not take the bus but instead biked Patras - our map said it was only about 250 kilometres.
column500:
>

So we kept on biking - we planned to do the 250 km over the next couple days. The only challenge was that to get to a good spot on the beach, we need to bike another 70 km, with another 1000 metres of climbing.
column503:
>

The ride was fantastic,
column504: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column511:
>

We biked through Kalamata, it felt a lot like biking through Athens, busy and crazy everywhere (this time we found a bike path for most of the city).
column514:
>

Once we left the city, we had lots of flat gravel farm roads, completely empty of cars.
column515: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column522:
>

At one point a lady yelled at us to stop from her house. She told us that the road ahead was dangerous and that we should bike on the busy highway instead.
column525:
>

We asked her why
column531:
>

As several normal looking people came out from the road we wanted to go on. We asked that makes them dangerous out of curiosity - and she couldn’t tell me what made them dangourous.
column534:
>

Anyway, we wanted to be respectful so we listened to her. But when she couldn’t see us anymore, we took the next turn off and continued on the “dangourous road”.
column537:
>

The road was actually amazing. It was one of the best gravel roads I have ever biked on. The “Gypsies” were about the equivalent of the homeless people in Vancouver, but they were all smiles and waving as we biked by.
column540:
>

The highway we would have to take was really busy and full of cars and trucks - so we took the risk and went with the Gypsies.
column543:
>

One time during the ride we found a “short cut” that left the road and cut off a few kilometres.
column544: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column549:
>

We had some serious trails haha
column552:
>

Turns out it was a super steep and difficult rocky trail / and road and it took us an extra two hours 😂 - we even got lost temporarily and accidentally biked through someone’s olive tree farm.
column555:
>

The trail biking was amazing. When you bike trails you are so focused on weaving through rocks that you forget the pain from the climbing. On the road all you feel during the climbs is the pain 😂. Also my bike is not made for trails at all - it’s really uncomfortable haha. I wish I had bigger tires.
column556: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column564:
>

100 kilometres later and we arrived to the sea with a beautiful sunset. We were properly tired - the stopped at the first beach we found - and the first thing I did was get off my bike and jump in the ocean.
column565: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column572:
>

We cooked a big dinner and set up tents and went to sleep. Over the next two days we will bike about 160 kilometres and arrive in Patras🥳.
column573: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column1: 5af7be60-fce8-4003-af0f-e2ffbaeb19a7,#20 - that was almost baaaaaaaaad,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/20-almost-baaaaaaaaad,June 8th,#20 - that was almost baaaaaaaaad,June 8th,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column465: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: >
column472:
>

We woke up at the gate of Hades from loud sheep noises. A herd of sheep had arrived and walked through our campsite on the beach. They had a few friendly sheep dogs, they were absolutely adorable.
column473: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column481:
>

Greece has a lot of dogs, wild ones too. Usually the dogs are owned by someone but the owner just leave them outside always in a roam around. All the dogs love to bark at bikes.
column484:
>

If you were ever in a situation where a dog is chasing you on the bike - Adam and I have learned the best thing to do is to stop, get off the bike, and yell or whistle loudly.
column487:
>

This has work for us every single time - the only time the dogs go crazy is if we continue riding.
column490:
>

Anyway, june 8th was the turnaround point - now we go north! We started biking up the moni peninsula.
column491: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column499:
>

The first stop was the tiny town of Vathia. We were told to visit Vathia for it’s beautiful castle houses. Originally thought that it would be an actual town, but it just seemed to be abandoned - except for the peacock that we found in one of the homes…
column500: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column508:
>

Anyway, it was still very beautiful. In the town, an Italian doctor from Milano and I started chatting about Italy. Since I could speak Italian, we became best friends. He told me where to go in Italy - he said the town of Lecce was amazing, if you’ve been there, let me know - is a great?
column509: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column517:
>

We had heard from many people during this trip of a incredible cave network - that for €10 people take you on a boat to explore it. We wanted to see the cave - but wall we had was a 10km radius circled for us on a paper map from a German couple we met at the lighthouse the day before.
column520:
>

We continued biking, listening to podcasts - enjoying the views from the seaside road. After a few hours when I next checked the map, I realized we we had gone way past where we thought the cave was. We were disappointed but since we had heard mix reviews about it we just kept biking. We said au revoir to the cave idea.
column523:
>

I use a mapping app called Osmand Maps. By using the app, I found another cave marked by other travellers as a point of interest. We decided to go check that out instead - thinking we could check it out and continue biking.
column526:
>

When we got to the cave, we realized that this was actually the cave everyone was talking about. The road went down and only lead to the cave and a small rocky beach through a trail.
column527: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column532:
>

From the road down to the cave
column535:
>

And when we tried to bike down to the beach beside the cave - a Greek men yelled at from a ticket booth to stop and told us that the cave was closed.
column538:
>

The Greek man didn’t really speak English - so our conversation was went like this in Greek
column541:
>

Me: “Etho Ine kalá” (here is good)
column544:
>

Him: “σκυμτπσνυξρπδβ τξδξφ το της” (Greek I don’t understand)
column547:
>

Me: “Ne ne” yea yea
column550:
>

Me : “ine kala” (it is good)
column553:
>

(repeats like this for 5-10 minutes)
column556:
>

Eventually I pulled out google translate and explained that we want to see the cave - we understand it’s closed - and asking if we can camp here to see it in the morning.
column557: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column565:
>

With some persistance, We eventually convinced him to let us pass and camp there as long as we were quiet and out of sight 😂
column568:
>

It was an absolutely beautiful campsite - we had to hike our bikes on the top of a small cliff area.
column569: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column576:
>

We then set up for the night and enjoyed a beautiful sunset on the beach right beside the cliff.
column577: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

Quick highlights from a few days ago
column467:
>

We continued south trying to get to the bottom of moni.
column470:
>

Our day started with en extraordinarily steep climb. 400 metres of elevation over a 1 kilometres. Average grade of about 14% 😅
column471: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column479:
>

Every time we stopped in a village, a mani local would talk to us - tell us their life story and tell us all about the history of Moni
column490: > they were the toughest Greeks
column493: > They were never slaves to the turcs while the rest of Greece was conquered
column496: > The Spartans often came to Mani to recruit strong fighters
column499: > There are extremely deadly snakes here. If you get bit by the medium sized brown one - you have one hour. I did not ask what happens after one hour 😅
column502: > Originally the people here were pirates.
column505:
>

Moni has a very interesting history :)
column508:
>

While biking through one small town on the east coast of the peninsula Adam and I heard a shout from the only cafe in the town.
column514:
>

it was the French couple we met from Methana! They invited us they invited us to join them and bought us food. We shared stories from our travels to find that we had gone to similar places along the way.
column515: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column523:
>

An hour later, right as we’re about to leave the cafe, another traveller we met before rode in on his motorbike (the German who gave us the paper map in leonidio). We sat for coffee with him and also chatted for a while.
column524: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column531:
>

At the same time we met Julia from Switzerland. She had just finished sailing around Greece, and was sitting at the cafe too and we invited her to join us for coffee.
column534:
>

We stayed and all chatted for a while before Adam and I left and went to the lighthouse.
column535: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column540:
>

On the way to the lighthouse
column543:
>

Julia drive to the lighthouse in the car and we met her there.
column544: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column549:
>

Julia at the lighthouse
column552:
>

Adam and I spent some time looking for a great spot to camp and we found the best possible spot. The beach right infront of the gate of the Greek God of the underworld, Hates.
column553: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column561:
>

We all hung out together and cooked dinner on the beach in the evening.
column562: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

Short one today - today I’m exhausted, it’s 11pm and we just had another big day riding :)
column470:
>

Here we go 🎉🥳
column471: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column476:
>

going down the coast in Moni
column482:
>

We arrived at Mani (Μανης) mi, omicron, ni, eita, sigma (now I know all my Greek letters math class is gonna be a breezeee)
column483: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column491:
>

We finally arrived at the top of the mani peninsula. We heard so much about it and we were excited to check it out.
column492: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column500:
>

We first entered Gythio - an awesome waterfront town.
column501: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column508:
>

We found a beach about 25 km into the ride and took naps in the midday sun. It’s really starting to be terrible biking between 11am-3pm.
column509: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column514:
>

View from roads around Moni
column517:
>

Mani has incredible views from the roads along the coast.
column518: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column523:
>

We stopped at a cafe and I ate this delicious Greek salad
column524: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column532:
>

When it got dark we found a private beach with an incredible view of the the ocean - our day ended sleeping a few feet from the water.
column533: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column555:
>

Erik
