column1: a00dd6b9-a956-404c-9806-a78cf7c25728,#17 - The never ending climb ,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/17-never-ending-climb,June 5th,#17 - The never ending climb ,June 5th,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

First things first I am getting hungry. Please mail me food if you can.
column470:
>

Yesterday ate 1 kilogram of peanuts and 1 kilogram of Greek yogurt 😂
column471: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column481: >We left Leonidio. We almost stayed another day to climb but changed out minds and wanted to get back on the bike.
column486: >We said our final goodbye to Kai and left for the mountains.
column491: >I bought an awesome bandana in town- now I look like a real professional bike tourist
column492: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column500:
>

Adam and I left Leonidio heading for a bike route that would take us about 90km and 2000 metres of elevation to the top of the famous moni 💰peninsula in the Peloponnese - where we heard all the houses look like castles.
column503:
>

It was going to be a long day with the longest climb either Adam or I had ever done - the ride only had one climb that was 44 kilometres long and about 1600m of climbing. Through a giant rocky valley and over some mountains.
column504: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column514: >it was an incredible climb through a canon. It was really hard but very rewarding. The views kept getting better and better every 10 minutes.
column515: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column520:
>

On the way up - wow
column525: >We found a another cliff side Monastery with incredible views - this one had actual monks in it which gave us free honey candy.
column526: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column533:
>

We got cold water in the monastery and continued. Even though the climb was really painful - it was still way easier that the last mountain crossing on gravel and dirt roads - and the views always made it worth it.
column534: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column539:
>

a small section of the climb
column542:
>

I keep saying this but Greece is probably the best place for biking on roads - great views, friendly drivers, and not that many cars. 80% of the cars are RVs with Germans on vacation and they always give lots of encouragement, food and water. They also drive very carefully in the narrow roads.
column545:
>

After biking for around 4 hours we made it to the top - which happened to be a mountain village. We had great Greek salad and espresso and relaxed for a bit.
column547: >My life is forever changed, I will be eating so much Greek salad for the rest of my life.
column550:
>

We started the decent down the mountain and Wowow. It was the longest climb I have ever done and also one of the longest decent. 35 kilometres down the mountain.
column553:
>

The first big downhill was insane - serpentine switchbacks for what felt like hours.
column554: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column562:
>

One section of the decent we noticed some boxes off to the left of the road, behind some trees.
column565:
>

Then we also noticed thousands of bees flying everywhere all around us. It was a bee farm.
column568:
>

Part of the decent was a bee farm which stretched on for 1 or 2 kilometres. We were going at 70km /hour down this mountain while the bees were flying towards us and bouncing off our chest and face. Each bee felt like a paintball. I would dodge and weave with my head and curl into a little ball to minimize the chance to get hit by bees - I was sure to keep my mouth closed (one bee bounced right off my lip).
column571:
>

Near the tail end of the decent we approached yet another obstacle. I was trailing behind a van and it started to slow down and I heard very loud noises.
column574:
>

There were 200 goats walking down the road. I stopped and stared for a while completely baffled. I have never seen a goat crossing before. There was a van from Austria beside us and we were all laughing in disbelief about the goats.
column575: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column583:
>

Adam caught up a minute later and we pushed through the goats thanks to Adams ability to whistle very loudly.
column586:
>

At the very end the sheep dog chased us down the mountain 😂
column589:
>

Other than those two moments, when my mouth was stuck closed from bees and stuck open in disbelief about goats -
column591: >I was screaming in joy about the how fun the way down was.
column601: >We moved to the next town, Geraki to see a castle - it was a Greek holiday, so we could not visit.- the castle was also on a massive hill so I was secretly glad to have the excuse not to climb up it.
column602: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column607:
>

The castle was up there 😅
column610:
>

We continued the ride down, arriving at the next town and finally we
column612: > found a beach to camp on. We made an epic dinner feast - Adam made Indian food I made pasta.
column613: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column618:
>

Cooking pasta with fresh tomato sauce
column619: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column624:
>

We had a guard dog all night protecting us
column627:
>

And finally, the nights accommodations
column628: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

Yesterday we did not leave Leonidio - or Kai. We stayed out too late drinking, woke up at 12, and then made the incredibly difficult decision to sleep in the beach chairs rather than bike into the mountains to cross over to the next peninsula of the Peloponnese.
column470:
>

We once again laid in the beach chairs and slept and read.
column473:
>

Most of the day was spent like that - relaxing. Then in the evening we walked down the beach back to the restaurant we had drinks at and had the actual last supper together
column474: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column479:
>

Walking around the dock area
column482:
>

The food was great. We bought Musaka, some veal and potatoes, beer and meatballs - and of course Greek salad.
column485:
>

The restaurant food almost tastes as good as our own cooking 🧑‍🍳
column486: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column496: >Nothing else happened yesterday and we all just went to bed really early.
column504: >Oh yea one more thing. This retired German Interpol agent gave us a paper map - Adam and I used it to plan out our course to Albania. I think it’s my first time actually using a paper map to plan a route. Epic.

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

you stil reading this stuff? If you are, thank you and I hope you are enjoying my public version of a diary.
column470:
>

Also feel free to email me back by hitting reply on this email. I would love to see if anyone is actually reading this 😂. For example, tell me where you think we should go (or how many spelling mistakes I make). I love recommendations or hearing if anyone has had similar experiences while travelling.
column473:
>

Back to being a dumb tourist.
column474: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column481:
>

When we got to the camp site last night at 9:30 pm we thought only things about 3 things.
column484:
>

Dinner, ocean, sleep.
column487:
>

So we did not pay any attention to where we set up our tents or anything else we did.
column490:
>

When we woke up in the morning the Greek owner of the pool bar we had camped beside was upset we had camped near his bar - fortunately they are not open yet and today was their first day setting things up for the season. We said sorry and he forgave us - but a good lesson for us to be more careful where we set up our tents at night 😅.
column491: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column499:
>

After yesterday we were very tired and decided to just take a slow easy day on the bike. We slowly drifted down the coast on our bikes - stopping under some trees in the shade to dodge the afternoon heat.
column500: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column508:
>

On the beach I just practiced my Greek and Italian, went for a swim and sat in the shade. We were so tired from yesterday and my leg was still sore from the fall the day before so we thought about going beach to beach all day biking only small amounts in the evening when the temperature cooled down.
column509: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column514:
>

Sitting on the beach for hours
column517:
>

Eventually at around 4pm, we decided to keep biking. I got on my bike and started to pedal and for the first 10 metres I felt like i was biking really slow. I quickly realized that my rear tire was flat. We stopped and looked at the tire and found that the tire was not punctured but rather the entire side of the outside tire ripped open. My rear tire had completely failed, there was no tread left to grip the road and the sides were splitting.
column520:
>

This must have been from the heavy weight on the rear of the bike (the bike with gear is about 50-60kg and I weight 94kg), and the fact that the tires were old that it was word down quickly.
column523:
>

The lack of tread on the tire could have also accounted for me slipping out on the curve the day before - i learned that it is very important to always check tire tread. I should have bought new tires before the trip
column526:
>

Fortunately the rear tire could hold air so I could keep riding slowly. I do not carry extra tires in my bags, just inner tubes (what actually holds the air in most bike tires) but there was no point in changing the tube since it would be exposed with a high risk of being punctured again because the outer protective layer of the tire was splitting in half.
column529:
>

Our goal changed from rest day to… “lets find a bike shop”. Unfortunately, the closest bike shop was about 60km away in the city of Pyrgos and it was already too late to bike all the way there - so we just biked as close as we could, taking the the highway. I had to stop ever 20 mins to refill the air in my leaky tire.
column530: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column535:
>

biking on the highway - not too bad
column538:
>

When the sun started setting, we pulled off a road we found on the map and found a beach to camp on for the night. When we got to the campsite this was our view of the sunset. Que bonito.
column539: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column546:
>

If you made it this far reply to this email and say hi 😉

column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

Today was a do nothing day. I sat on the beach in the sun from morning till the afternoon looking at this as a view, switching between reading, swimming, studying Italian, and writing these posts
column465: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: >
column470:
>

Life is hard here - hard to get out of this beach chair
column473:
>

We found out climbing gear rental was 50 euros per day per person so Adam and I said no thank you. I was also tired and thoroughly enjoyed doing absolutely nothing on the beach.
column476:
>

We decided we would leave Leonidio the next day - and at long last - leave kai behind. Kai is meeting a friend in the mountain ranges and will bike with them soon. Eventually, he will venture off on his own probably high in the mountains in Greece.
column479:
>

Adam and I really enjoyed biking with Kai. I think we will be meeting again on this bike trip. There’s talk of a reunion in the Alps or Dolomites for my birthday in July- we will see what happens.
column482:
>

When we first met Kai I had no idea I would be biking with him. We have spent over two weeks all together and it’s flown by.
column485:
>

Anyway, we made a big feast together to celebrate the two weeks we travelled together.
column486: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column494:
>

We went out for drinks after to celebrate - reminisce in the memories, the good old days in Methana, the skulls in the little cave, or just biking up mountains with ease while I’m dying from my horrible gear ratio. (try your best to hold back your tears, it’s okay.)
column497:
>

After drinking in the little habour we moved over to the little beach side club and danced with some Dutch people who had sailed there. The club was empty until 2 am - that’s when all the Greek people started to show up. Greek clubing usually doesn’t start till 2-3 am 😅 - in Vancouver that’s when I like to be in bed by.
column500:
>

The club stays open to 11 am, we didn’t last that long.
column501: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column509:
>

When I finally reached the tent at 5 am I could still hear the clubs music 600 metres away.
column512:
>

We have a big biking day up a mountain

column419: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td align=""center"" valign=""top""><h1 style=""text-align:left
column426: > #14 - The place where climbers go.
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

June 2nd we woke up on the beach and all the mosquitoes were gone. So i was safely able to leave my tent 😂.
column467:
>

Our destination for the day was 50km away, Leonidio.
column468: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column478:
>

A week earlier in Methena we heard of Leonidio - we were told it was a major destination for climbers for the giant cliff faces that encircle the town. Adam was really excited to climb here, we may be renting gear in the town.
column481:
>

We all left the beach campsite and found a spot to make coffee and breakfast at a nearby harbour
column484:
>

In the water in-front of us what a small shark that was swimming in the harbour. It was doing circles for maybe 5-10 minutes before one of the local Greek fisherman set out to try to spear it with a trident.
column485: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column490:
>

A Greek man trying to trident a shark
column493:
>

The shark swam away and the Greek man was left without a shark.
column496:
>

We all left the habour at different times, Kai first, Adam second and me third, spaced out about 30 minutes apart.
column499:
>

Today we all road alone for much of the costal road. Eventually I passed Kai - we stopped for lunch together. Then I sped off to catch Adam.
column502:
>

After a few “easier” days on the bike I was feeling fresh and enjoyed trying to bike as fast as possible on the costal highway.
column505:
>

The road stayed along the coast going all the way to Leonideo, going up and down like a roller coaster.
column508:
>

It was so much fun to bike on.
column509: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column517:
>

All the Greek drivers were very polite and would slow down and give lots of room for me biking.
column520:
>

One couple from Britain that we had met at Epidaurus theatre two days earlier passed me driving on the highway and pulled over to chat and they gave me a delicious apple. Thanks again if you read this. ❤️
column521: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column529:
>

Normally when a car honks at bikers in Vancouver, Canada it means they are upset you are biking so slow and they want to pass - in Greece all the cars do friendly honks of support and wave with big smiles - I love it.
column532:
>

Did I mention the amazing coastal roads yet? I don’t even know how to describe how much fun they are to bike on - I hope I keep getting roads like this.
column533: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column541:
>

We arrived in the city to see a amazing giant cliff faces. We understood why this is a place for rock climbers right way. It was over 250 official rock climbing routes. When we arrived in the city it we were all like “wow” - these are some big cliffs.
column542: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column548: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column553:
>

View of some of the cliffs
column556:
>

We biked around the small town. It was much quieter than we expected. Many shops were closed. We quickly found out from talking with locals that mainly climbing season is in the winter since the rocks are too hot in the summer. Also renting gear was 50 euro per day so we decided not to try climbing.
column557: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column565:
>

We went to a campsite tonight - lots of Germans in travel vans. I’d say 80% of every campsite we go to is German.
column568:
>

Anyway, we decided to buy groceries relax at the campsite and cook great food.
column569: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column1: 97fc274f-5665-485c-86fd-989efaa0153d,#13 A German Surprise.,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/13-german-surprise,June 1st,#13 A German Surprise.,June 1st,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""start"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column466: >Writing this during a rest day in Leonidio, we will talk about that tomorrow.
column467: text-align:start
column471: >I am taking an easy today and I’ll catch up on the last few days, currently sitting in the sun on the beach
column483: > by the founder of Nike. I got this quote from the book, that he got from some philosopher guy.
column488: >I’m too lazy on this beach chair to look up the quote again haha. I’ll paraphrase
column493: >“The person who moves mountains first starts by carrying away the small stones”
column498: >Anyway I liked it a lot so I thought I would share it. We have not biked that far yet, maybe 500-600 kilometres. But I feel as we have seen so much already. I’m excited for the coming weeks. Little by little we are making some progress.
column503: >okay, on with June 1st…
column504: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column513: >The night before June 1st we camped at a campsite right underneath the Acropolis in Mikinis.
column518: >We woke up in the morning at the campsite. The place was owned and run by an elderly Greek couple and they made us tea in the morning which was very nice. We then left the campsite.
column523: >We headed up the hill to another amazing ruins. I believe it was called the Ancient Mycenae Palace. I don’t know much about the history of this place but it was a Bronze Age castle. It was a very very old. When Socrates was alive in Greece it was already 1000 years old and ruins.
column524: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column529:
>

View from the top of the palace
column534: >We saw all the rocks there and they were… well rocks. I enjoyed the view from the top of the hill and the walking around the castle but I think I lacked the imagination to think of how this place looked a few thousand years before.
column535: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column545: >Oh yes, this ruin also had Europes oldest relief! A relief is a carving into a rock? Not sure, i briefly heard someone say what when we I asked what a relief was.
column546: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column551:
>

The oldest relief in Europe
column556: >We had biked here to see it, adding an extra day of biking and I was unsure if it was worth the visit, UNTIL we saw the tomb of some really important guy (I am terrible with these Greek names)
column561: >We approached the door and heard weird chanting songs coming from within the door.
column562: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column572: >When we entered the tomb we found a German school choir singing. It seems like they were just having fun singing and we got a free private show in the tomb for 20 mins. This was by far my favourite part of visiting the ruins.
column573: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column581:
>

The singing sounded wonderful inside the tomb. The reverberations echoed from the singing making beautiful harmonies. Perfect! I could not understand a word of the German songs but all three of us clapped loudly between songs.
column586: >I left that tomb feeling very alive.
column591: >We left the ruins, making some friends as we ate lunch. We had many people give us recomendaciones of places to visit in other parts of Europe.
column596: >We then set out on bike heading down a wonderful coastal road. This is one of the most beautiful coastal highways I have every biked on, we road on it for the last two days and I will talk more about it tomorrow.
column597: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column607: >After a day of riding we got to Astros, a small beach next to a lagoon. We set up our tents on the beach. Beach camping is amazing, free and quite. The only downside was the insane amounts of mosquitoes. In the 10 minutes I was setting up my tent. I got bitten maybe 10 times by mosquitoes - they would even follow me into the ocean. After I set up my tent I went inside and didn’t dare leave for any reason until the morning.
column613: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column466: >Hope all is well.
column467: text-align:left
column471: >I’m writing about today, tonight. Looks at me on top of things a little bit. Turns out you get a lot of free time on a bike tour.
column472: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column481: >Today I was super tired and sore from the giant day in the mountains. So I wanted to take it easy.
column486: >We had lots of riding to do I just went slow and took our time the whole way.
column491: > I told myself in the morning.
column496: >“No gravel, just easy roads”
column501: >And of course the first thing I hear from Kai is.
column506: >“We should take this gravel shortcut”
column516: >I just said yes let’s do it since it turns out it really was a shortcut to get to this Ancient Greek theatre. Usually Kai’s shortcuts are twice as long and twice as hard through trails.
column521: >So we went on the gravel road. It wasn’t nearly as hard as the day before, and I was happy to dodge the mountain highways a little.
column526: >The gravel road was taking us to the ancient theatre. But on the way, as usual, we stumbled upon another archeological site, completely empty of people. We climbed a small fence and walked around this ancient sanctuary that was supposed a place of healing for thousands of people long ago. Lots of cool ruins here. I always wonder when I see the ruins… what did the think look like before? It would be amazing to see.
column527: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column532:
>

Part of the ruins we found
column533: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column543: >We left this one and continued to the main event.
column551: >The super special Greek theatre - (Epidaurus Ancient Theatre if you want to google it)
column552: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column557:
>

From the top of the theatre
column565: >The acoustics were amazing.
column573: >We continued on, eventually the roads just became downhill FOREVER. We had maybe 20Km of nice and easy downhill, and some fast roads too. We finally got to enjoy all the fruits of our labour from the previous days climbing.
column574: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column584: >We ended our ride some kilometres later at a campsite in Mykines. We are going to look at another famous ruin temple thing tomorrow.
column589: >Here were tonight’s accommodations - a campsite this time.
column590: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column642: >All cooked in a camping stove.
column647: >I cold slacked the lentils in my water bottle during the days ride so they cook easier.
column660: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td height=""10"" style=""line-height:1px
column665: >

column1: c29372a3-80b1-477e-be14-e9c355fc6a05,#11 - The mountain’s secret,confirmed,All free subscribers,"",https://erikdahl.beehiiv.com/p/11-mountains-secret,May 30th ,#11 - The mountain’s secret,May 30th ,"<!DOCTYPE html><html lang=""en"" xmlns=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"" xmlns:v=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:vml"" xmlns:o=""urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"" style=""font-size:16px

column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column464:
>

Yesterday was action packed. It was a really tough ride.
column467:
>

See this picture?
column468: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column473:
>

Notice the mountains in the background
column476:
>

We had to go over that mountain and the three other ones behind it.
column477: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column482:
>

Don’t be fooled by the short distance :)
column485:
>

Our day started out on gravel roads, we woke up under the arches of the church and head out early. We got water from an Austrian family with an RV on a beach close by, since there’s were no other places to get water between our previous and was on gravel roads all day.
column488:
>

We had seen a road on the map going over the mountains, it was supposed to be a shortcut to avoid the highway, or so we thought.
column491:
>

It was only about 20-25 km road but it was all gravel. And over several different mountains 😂😂😂.
column494:
>

I think Kai and Adam were fine but my bike does not have the correct gearing, nor tire width for steep gravel climbs up mountains, especially with 60lbs of gear on my bike.
column495: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column500:
>

Mountain roads - sometimes it was paved
column503:
>

It was extremely hard work form beginning to go over the mountain roads. I had to give max effort on many segments to be able to ride on my skills tyres.
column506:
>

But wow the views were stunning the entire way. As we moved over the mountains the scenery became more and more lush. We got views of several different large green valleys. Although it was one of the most challenging gravel roads i have ever done, it was also surely the most beautiful gravel road.
column507: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column512:
>

Adam painfully struggling up the mountain
column515:
>

We climbed up walls of gravel with our bikes. Sometimes it was so steep I had to push. Or I would hit a large rock and it would stop me from biking.
column518:
>

Several hours into the mountains we realized we had taking a much bigger challenge than we thought. It was really hot, we were in the middle of nowhere , and we had less water and food than we would have liked to have. We each carried about 2L at the beginning but that quickly was drunk as the climb carried on.
column521:
>

And of course is started to rain - we got quite muddy
column522: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column527:
>

The moment it started to rain
column530:
>

We were not too worried about water, since we had fruit and stuff, but we were looking for the next water source.
column533:
>

Then while biking along the valley ridge we noticed a monastery in the distance, built into a cliff face.
column536:
>

Now that’s not something I see biking around gravel roads at home.
column539:
>

It was far away, but eventually we got closer. We decided to go down and see if there was a water source, but also to check out what the hell this thing was.
column542:
>

First of all, it stopped raining.
column545:
>

Secondly- oh my God, it was stunning.
column546: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column551:
>

The lush valley and monastery
column554:
>

There were two buildings, built into a cliff, with a view overlooking a lush valley.
column557:
>

We all screamed and whistles into the valley and and the valley answered with a never ending perfect ecco.
column560:
>

And it had water! They had a rainwater collection system, so we filled up out bottles and filtered the water for contamination.
column563:
>

No one was at the monastery at all, but place looked great, so we assumed someone comes to maintain the place.
column566:
>

The buildings had doors to them. So of course we tried opening the doors to the first building, both of which were locked.
column569:
>

Then we looked for keys under rocks nearby with no luck.
column575:
>

We then try the second farther way building. This was the one that looks much older, it was taller too which an epic roof high up on the cliff.
column576: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column581:
>

the monastery up close
column584:
>

I tried door one. Locked. No keys under rocks nearby.
column587:
>

I tried door two…
column591: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column599:
>

We were very surprised the door was open but we had to go inside to see what is up.
column602:
>

We found small monk rooms.
column603: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column611:
>

An old church with beautiful art.
column612: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column617:
>

The monk prayer area
column620:
>

Lots of olive oil.
column621: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column628:
>

Then we made our way to the roof and we’re completely shocked.
column631:
>

One by the view…
column632: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column639:
>

But mainly since there was a small hidden cave in the cliff which we climbed into.
column642:
>

There was no light in this cave and it was only a few feet wide and we had to crawl.
column645:
>

But we came to an opening and in the ceiling of the cave way up, when we shone our lights we saw 6 human skulls lined up. (No pictures out of respect)
column646: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column651:
>

Art in the small cave
column657:
>

Yeah wow. I can’t saw i have found human skulls in a secret monk cave on a gravel ride before.
column660:
>

We sat on the roof a while and soaked in the view and the warm sun.
column663:
>

I also gave the giant monk bell a ring. It was incredible as it boomed through the valley below.
column666:
>

We left the monastery untouched and closed the door behind us. We continued on the gravel roads.
column669:
>

Hold on. This days not over yet.
column672:
>

My fingers are getting tired haha.
column675:
>

We then biked down an epic decent, some gravel, and some nice paved roads. (if only I had a GoPro)
column678:
>

We stopped for delicious food at a restaurant along the highway. Lamb, bread, lasagna pasta. In the massive restaurant of 100 tables, we were the only people. A little concerning for Adam. But hey - the food was great.
column681:
>

I sat there a while and read. Then we continued biking on the highway until dark. Eventually pulling off the highway at a random spot and finding a nice place to set up our tents just off a dirt trail.
column687:
>

Here was the night’s accommodations. Completely free.
column688: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column693:
>

wild camping - the goats were loud.
column699:
>

Erik

column58: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column64:
>

Writing this one on the road. Right now we are in the middle of a mountain, biking on a gravel service road, dodging the afternoon sun under a small tree.
column65: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column70:
>

yesterdays ride - screenshot from Adams Strava.
column73:
>

Yesterday, we woke up on the beach in Poros. The birds were defining. They were actually so loud I had trouble sleeping. I think it had to do with the rocks around, creating an eco.
column76:
>

We biked around the sea walls of Poros and saw massive boats. Many people come to Poros for boating, lots of chartered catamarans and sailboats. And this one massive 80 foot catamaran from Italy.
column77: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column82:
>

80 foot catamaran on the left
column85:
>

We left Poros and biked along the coast stopping for lunch in the beach. Adam and I split up temporarily from Kai early in the ride since Kai wanted to bike some hiking trails.
column86: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column94:
>

After we split up we biked through small towns, eventually reaching the ferry terminal to the Island of Hydra. Adam and I decided to forgo taking the ferry across to Hydra and continue on. We biked more along the coast till the next town, stocked up on food. Then went over a hilly gravel road to get to our camping spot for the night.
column95: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column103:
>

Hours later, just before sunset it started to rain. Adam found a little spot on google maps to camp for the night on a beach and we told Kai to meet us there.
column106:
>

We arrived and it was still raining, and what we thought was a beach of google maps was actually all giant rocks.
column109:
>

But by good luck there was an old abandoned church near by and we camped under the cover of the church. The archway of the church protected us from rain as we cooked our dinner.
column112:
>

And the views of the ocean were not that bad :)
column113: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column119: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column127:
>

It’s not raining on the above picture since I took the photo in the morning 😉
column130:
>

Until tomorrow, time for me to continue biking.

column465: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467: >
column470:
>

Hiking up the volcano
column473:
>

We woke up yesterday late. Just enjoying the villa and Greek life as usual. We have been eating very very well on Methana. Every day delicious Greek salad. Alex showed us how to prepare the best salads. The secret is to use insane amount of feta cheese, and olive oil. They have a saying here in Greece . “A kilo of feta a day keeps the devil away”. We also made more Italian bread from scratch .
column476:
>

In the afternoon, we called Elias, since he said Saturday, he would take us to a volcano. He picked us up in his truck and drove us to the trail head, which was at his house.
column477: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column484:
>

Elias (Ελιας) drove us in his truck. It’s much easier to climb the mountain in Elias truck than to bike up.
column487:
>

The volcano trail was amazing. We got to the top of the volcano. We all did the hiking sandals. It’s my first time doing a hike and sandals, and I loved it.
column488: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column496:
>

Also, we sat and watch the sunset at the top of the volcano.
column497: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column502:
>

reaching the top of the volcano
column505:
>

After the hike Elias made us all pasta at his house and gave us great recommendations for where to go in the Peloponnese mountains.
column508:
>

So we have a list of places we will try and visit over the next several days.
column509: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column514:
>

A 1000 year old church
column517:
>

On the way up I’m Elias’s truck we stopped to water some of Elias’s trees and check out an ancient Byzantine era church with some beautiful art inside.
column518: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column524: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column529:
>

Elias cat. My favourite of his cats
column530: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column538:
>

Elias if you read this thank you so much for having us in your home and making us delicious food. I really enjoyed hearing about the island. Hope we meet again

column462: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467:
>

Just chillin
column473:
>

Yesterday was an easy on to write about. Pretty much did nothing all day. We got back at 4 am the night before form the hot spring. So I then woke up at 2 pm, ate, and studied Greek and Italian, then took a 4 hour nap. I also spent time writing and thinking on all the things Elias said about Methena. I am still processing everything.
column476:
>

The others went on a little trip while I napped to the beach to recover Kai’s underwear he left there a few days earlier after swimming.
column479:
>

I cant make bread, but I did make some delicious pasta for everyone. Pesto pasta.
column480: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column488:
>

Taking it super super easy. I think we are ready to get back on the road soon.
column491:
>

Tomorrow we will be leaving Methena. We dont know exactly where to yet. That will be fun to see :)

column467:
>

It was time to leave Methana.
column473:
>

To celebrate our parting from the island. Alex made us a delicious Greek style pie. Adam says it was in the top five things he’s ever eaten. It was pretty damn good .
column474: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column480: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column488:
>

I really enjoyed Methana. It’s definitely a very special place, with a lot of unique history. I’m very happy we spent five days here. We met some amazing people. People are really kind :)
column491:
>

Yesterday we got lots of recommendations from Elias. he told us all the amazing spots to visit in the Peloponnese.
column492: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column497:
>

Leaving Alex and Lotus land
column500:
>

So we left around 6 PM to the first 30 km away called Poros.
column501: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column506:
>

Poros view from the mainland
column509:
>

Poros it’s a beautiful small island, with little shops, and many many boats docked or acred.
column510: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column515:
>

Small 1 euro ferry to Poros
column518:
>

Elias told us about a quiet beach in the corner of the island to camp on.
column519: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column527:
>

Today we are off to the next stop :)

column426: > #6 - Elias: The Man on the Mountain
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px
column460: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467: word-break:break-word
column468:
>

I finally caught up with these posts. I am now writing about yesterday rather than several days in the past. Yesterday was another remarkable day. We have a running joke that I keep saying “This is the most incredible thing I have ever seen” almost every single day.
column474:
>

Yesterday I said it again 😂
column475: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column480:
>

To the mountain man, and to the hot springs again.
column483:
>

This was our third day in Methena, we are still here and I think we will be staying till Sunday. We will enjoy our last day here and maybe finally climb up to the summit of one of these volcanos. We have only ever gotten near the summit thus far and it would be great to be able to go to the very top.
column486:
>

We woke up yet again and took it easy all morning. Just passing the hours writing, reading, thinking, and eating. We all spent quite a bit of time asking Alex about the Greek language and practicing phrases we can use in the shops when we go to buy things.
column489:
>

We also spent the day before heading out backing delicious Italian bread from scratch.
column490: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column495:
>

Making Italian bread from scratch
column498:
>

Making the bread took a while, and I cannot take credit for the bread in the slightest except that I helped carry the ingredients up the mountain from the grocery store to the villa 😂 .
column501:
>

We did not eat the bread right after, and I will explain why in a minute.
column504:
>

Remember yesterday when we were biking back to the villa from groceries and we met Elias, the man who made the hot spring useable, and was driving the truck? Well, during this conversation he invited us to his home to have a BBQ.
column507:
>

So we decided we would bring the bread we made, and a 3 euro bottle of wine up to his home for the BBQ.
column510:
>

We left to go to his home just before sunset. We wanted to be there around 7 pm
column511: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column516:
>

More of Methena’s amazing roads.
column519:
>

We took the beautiful roads and climbed even higher to get to his home. Elias lives in a village of 9 people about 350 metres up the volcano. So we biked with the bread and wine up to his home for the BBQ.
column520: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column525:
>

the small village of 9 people
column528:
>

We arrived to the village and I Kai and I practiced our Greek asking if they where where Elias lives.
column531:
>

We tried to say “Pu ine ho Elias, parikalo?” Which means Where is Elias, please? And what actually came out what “Pu ine ho Elios, parikalo” which actually means “Where is the sun” haha. Coincidentally the sun and Elias’s home happened to be in the exact same place. So we ended up finding his home.
column534:
>

Elias’s home was the home at the very highest point of the village. We all had to push up our bikes to make it to his home
column535: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column540:
>

Pushing up bikes to his house
column543:
>

Listening to Elias speak to us about his home felt sort of like watching a show the the History TV channel. As it turns out Elias and Methena starred in a famous Greek Documentry. There is a lot of forgotten history here.
column546:
>

Elias was excited to share everything with us. There was a lot to see and explain. His home was filled with unique history that unlike anything I have seen before.
column549:
>

Here are some of the things he mentioned, I dont think I can get them all.
column550: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column555:
>

200 year old home - the last original home on Methena.
column566: > He lived in a home that was 200 years old and the last home on Methena in the traditional style. All the other homes on Methena in this style has become ruins and rebuilt in other villages. No one else lived in these styles of homes still.
column569: > He and the house is fully self sufficient. He has a thrasher (something to ground wheat or barley?), barley, olive trees, fruit farms, chicken coup, wood working shop, makes his own tsipuro (Greek hard liquor, definitely spelt wrong), he collects his own rain water. He stores bout 50 tons of water. Methena has no natural water and uses 100% rain water.
column572: > He restored his ancient home, and is building a new home at the same time. He is self taught through Youtube (a Canadian youtube channel 😼 ).
column575: > So many cats, All the village cats come to his home.
column578: > Incredible view of the village, valley, and ocean below. Breathtaking spot and he had a great patio to sit and have a beer.
column581: > Elias is a man happy with the place he found for himself. He felt as thought it was fate that brought him to find this house and that the house was made for him. He found out afterwards that the previous owner of the house died the very same month that he was born. A new beginning?
column584: > He knows everything about the island. The locals, the tradition. Sad about the fact that the island and its culture is dying. He is 40 years old and he is the youngest person living on the island. In some years there will be no locals left.
column587: > He has a beautiful wood shop with collectors tools all these Stanly brand planes. I dont know what those are but he was really excited about them.
column590: > George Batis - a famous Greek musician was born in his house. This was in the 30s and all the village back then would come gather in his house for concerts. Back then the village has around 300-400 people and was much bigger than the current nine people who lived there.
column593: > Elias is an brilliant photographer and showed us a photo book with all the history of the village. He had photos of all the elder locals doing traditional town tasks such as plowing fields with mules, or washing all the village clothes in a watching. I’ll add one of the photos below.
column598: >Elias made us a delicious all you can eat BBQ. We ate pork, Greek salad with fresh feta made from the village goats and tomates picked from his very garden. We drank his tsiporo made by him and our 3 euro wine and talked about old island stories.
column603: >After listening and learning about Methena from Elias we all felt like we learned something special about Methana. We were all left a little sad about the fact that the islands original culture is slowly being lost.
column604: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column614: >After the BBQ we biked down the mountain to go to the hot spring. We enjoyed the hot spring until late in the night.
column615: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column620:
>

Adam happy as can be harvesting Barley
column625: >Adam was really excited to chop up some Barley and held Elias with his harvest. I got to give it a try as well. He told us that this weekend we will use the Barley to make beer.
column626: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column631:
>

turn the phone sideways to see :)
column634:
>

This was one of the photos I loved. This is one of the ladies in the village using the last donkey on Methena to carry sticks. She carries a really lovely smile in the photo. According to Elias, many of the locals on Methena NEVER have left the island, some have never even left their small villages.
column635: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column640:
>

The view from Elias mountain village home
column645: >This was the view from the balcony on his house that is under construction. Elias lives in a remarkable place with a breathtaking view.
column646: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column651:
>

Elias’s new home in construction
column656: >He loved the home we was building. We were all so shocked that he learned how to build his home on YouTube.
column657: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column665:
>

I only got probably about half written down here of that Elias had in his house and shared with us. He had many more historical stories about his home such as showing us where the town mayor used to make his wine, or where the villagers washed their clothes on the washing stones.
column668:
>

That’s all for today.
column671:
>

I slept in the same villa bed as before. And here is a picture of all of Elias’s cats if you are curious.
column672: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column680:
>

See you tomorrow.

column427: it is hard to leave Methena
column434: > Wednesday 24th
column435: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column461: data-open-tracking=""true""> {{OPEN_TRACKING_PIXEL}}
column462: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""left"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467: word-break:break-word
column468:
>

We woke up on the island and we decided that we do not want to leave Methena just yet. We are still staying with Alex in the villa.
column469: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column474:
>

Going to the store and beach chilling.
column477:
>

It’s really nice here and there is so much to see on the island.
column480:
>

We just spent most of the day relaxing. We biked to lo stores on the island and bought food.
column483:
>

We made some pizza from scratch, making the dough from flour and yeast. We bought cheese to make our own Saganaki, which is Greek Cheese.
column486:
>

It’s really hard to leave here. There is so much to see on the island. The road biking here is amazing. There is no traffic and all the hills coastal roads have fasts descents, and great views. Im seriously contemplating biking laps around the island.
column487: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column492:
>

Greek coffee with a view
column495:
>

I have been spending some time learning the Greek alphabet and saying some basic phrases in Greek, the language is actually very similar to Spanish and Italiano in some ways. The language sounds very beautiful.
column496: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column504:
>

The bakery we needed to buy the special ingredients for the pizza was closed so we biked to the beach to kill time. Basically just laying on the sand for an hour and taking it easy.
column505: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column510:
>

can not beat the biking in Methena
column514: >The hot spring man
column517:
>

On the ride back from the Groceries Alex yeld something in Greek to a passing truck driver. The truck driver got out of the car and came to talk to us. Turns it out it was the maker of the hot springs we stayed at. He had moved to the island after falling in love it on a bike trip 15 years earlier and now lives on the island. He built the tub we sat in, and he also built the pump that pumps the heated water to the tub.
column520:
>

His name was Elias. It was great chatting to him about some of the history of the island. He told us about 2000 year old churches or massive oak tries hidden in the volcano hills.
column523:
>

We left it there with Elias and continues back to the house.
column524: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column529:
>

watched the sunset on the windmill
column532:
>

Nearby the villa there is an run down mill, we climbed up on the ruins to watch the sunset. Very nice.
column533: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column541:
>

When we got back from the store we made a pizza and went to sleep early.
column544:
>

Probably going to stay in Methena for a bit longer.

column426: > #4 - The Island of The Lotus Eaters

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""start"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column467:
>

Welcome to post #4. Someone needs to keep track of the days for me. I’m quickly losing them.
column470:
>

Things just keep getting more and more unpredictable. In this post. hoped I captured at least half the wonderful things that happened on the 23rd.
column471: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column481: >I woke up by the hot spring and I went for a snorkel, Adam and Kai picked up snorkel in tin Athens for 10 euros. There were so many fish since they all flock to the heated thermal vents. If I had a speargun I think I could eat fish for a month without much difficulty.
column486: >I sat in the hot springs for a while before we started to pack up the tents.
column491: >A few French people came down to the hot springs while we were leaving. I had my first conversation with someone from France in person. It was awesome, understanding and being understood, in French. They ended up inviting us to stay in their garden if we go to Bordeaux, France. They were doing a bike tour in Greece with e-bikes and a van. They would drive around Europe with a van and have their e bikes in the back. They said it was the funnest way to travel.
column496: >The night before, I got the WhatsApp of the Alex, the Greek professional Chess player. He had invited us to his villa in the mountains the night before so we would not have to camp at the hot-springs but we refused since we were already set up and it would have been difficult to pack up and leave. But the next day we decided to take him up on the offer and go for some Greek food. We took our time leaving the hot springs.
column501: >Alex is really amazing at chess. Together we would discuss moves from previous games he had played and we would recite me the moves of the whole game. here are some interesting things about Alex
column514: >Started chess at age 5
column519: >At 10 ish joined a chess club
column524: >At 14 he was the teacher of the club
column529: >He tough refugees chess and ran his own chess club from 14 to 24 with hundred of kids in his club.
column534: >He is only 25 now
column539: >If you know chess ratings he is 2300 lichees and 1800 official tournaments.
column544: >He kicked my ass fairly easily in chess.
column549: >He studies advanced Math in the Math university in Greece.
column554: >We got to his home in this village. There are maybe 35 people who live there. All of them are elderly and only speak Greek.
column555: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column560:
>

Us following Alex to the villa
column565: >The villa is stunning, and has 5 small rooms for all of us. We each got our own room and Alex cooked us some traditional Greek food.
column570: >We sat in the Villa out looking at the Ocean and mountains from the view from his villa patio for the rest of the evening. We just sat there relaxing with the view for hours. All of us dumbfounded for how we ended up here.
column571: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column581: >Time just melts away. Even though we are doing literally nothing, sitting on the patio with the view makes you somehow feel busy. Like nothing else matters but standing out at the ocean. I think I could just sit on the porch for the next two months and be really happy. Life in this little town is really really quiet. All you hear is cats fighting in the street and the buzzing of the massive bees.
column582: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column587:
>

A bird eye view of the villa
column592: >While sitting out this porch these are some interesting things I learned about Greece and Greek culture.
column605: >They all make their own in-village olive oil. And they have way way too much of it. More than they know what to do with. The use olive oil as fire starter since they have too much. They fill giant coke bottles of olive oil. Alex said he had about 10 litres of olive oil in the villa.
column610: >High-schools all across Greece have a yearly tradition where the students lock the school during weeks, they lock the windows, and basically bars are themselves in the school. When Alex was in high school, he was the one that organize them in his village. He said he once locked the school for 2 months. The students create demands for the teachers for improvements in the school. One year, one of his demands was to change the shape of the cheese cake in the cafeteria from square to circle. Another was fixing a broken section of roof. This tradition blew my mind and puts North American grad pranks is to shame. The students all band together to close the school for 1 - 6 weeks, created a list of demands, and the students even sleep in the school to make sure the teachers can’t break back into the school. Usually one of two things happen. First, the teacher agree to the demands and fix the issues that the students are protesting to get solved. Second, the teachers get pissed off and call the police to come open the school. Sometimes both happen. Alex explained to me that students in Greece are very political which came after a massacre in a university during the Greece dictator ship in the 60s and 70s. I don’t know much more than then but if you are interested check it out and let me know the full story.
column615: >Greek food tastes great. I have always hated eating olives, Greek salad, but now I cant get enough of it. its amazing to go from village to village and they give you the olive oil they make in their backyard, or use the olives made a few kms away. It makes enjoy olives a lot more.
column620: >Careful when you drink the water bottles. They fill the water bottles with Tsipuro (Greek hard liquor 60% alcohol, made from island grapes), and we almost made our morning coffee with it since it was in a normal bottle. I give each bottle a sniff before I drink from it 😂
column625: >Greek coffee! To make Greek style coffee you just throw coffee grounds in a little pot filled with water and boil it. It’s very easy to make and I will now be making it each day of this trip. After you drink the coffee inside the cup there’s a bunch of leftover coffee grounds, since we never used a filter for the coffee. Apparently what many Greek people do is the flip the cup upside after the coffee is drunk and the grounds is all that remains. You wait 5 or so minutes, and the coffee grounds forms into drawings on the rim of the small Greek coffee cups and these drawings predict your future. Mine said I would meet a girl in a volcano. I’ll let you know if that happens haha.
column626: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column631:
>

waiting to see what the future holds
column632: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column637:
>

reading the future from the cup
column642: >I am starting to learn Greek now too, I have been inspired, the language is beautiful and the characters as well. Let’s see how far I can get in the next couple weeks. Communicating with locals is really hard without Greek, especially away from the city.
column646: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column651:
>

Best Greek salad I’ve ever had
column656: >After passing hours sitting and staring at the view, and all you can eat Greek food, prepared for us by Alex, we decided to hike/ bike up the volcano mountain that we were staying on. We tried to catch the sunset from the top of the mountain.
column661: >We prepared our bikes and started to bike up the same really steep mountain as yesterday (a different road than last time however). And biked up about 400 meters in elevation of 20% gradient switchbacks to the trail head. We then tried to hike to the top of a volcano.
column662: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column667:
>

view from near the top of the switchbacks
column672: >The trail was wonderful, we got to enjoy the mountain valleys and see the city glow of Athens from a far. We missed the sunset since the hike was longer than we thought and begun hiking in the dark. I got to see the type of trails Kai had braved on his bike the day before, while Adam and I stayed to the road, and was really happy we stayed on the road in the previous mountain trek.
column677: >The sun fell and we hiked back down to the trailhead in the dark. Thank god for offline GPS and maps! It was straightforward to make our way back. We then descended the switchbacks of doom by bike in the dark. That was so much fun. The narrow roads, the lights from the four of us biking down, and the lights from the little villages on the neighbouring island. Chefs kiss.
column678: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column688: >We then got back to the villa, and cooked up the rest of the groceries we had bought the day before, drank some beer and talked with Alex and exchanged stories over some beers. Back on that same villa patio where anyone can just sit for hours.
column693: >Her is where I slept in the villa. Every time I open the door to this room there are the two same lizards crawling on the wall ☺️.
column694: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column701:
>

So why Island of Lotus eaters?
column704:
>

Here is the rundown from Wikipedia

column734: font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, Segoe UI, Roboto, Inter, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column736: >, a plant whose botanical identity is uncertain. The lotus fruits and flowers were the primary food of the island and were a narcotic
column737: font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, Segoe UI, Roboto, Inter, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif
column739: >, causing the inhabitants to sleep in peaceful apathy
column740: font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, Segoe UI, Roboto, Inter, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif

column748: >From what we have seen. That’s Methena. We might be here a little while :)

column467:
>

Welcome to post #3
column470:
>

You can check out the either two here.
column471: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column481: >We left Agistri in the morning on the ferry. We decided in the morning to head to Methena, another island further south west. With the idea to eventually head to the Peloponnese mountain ranges. I initially thought I wouldn’t be biking in really difficult mountains until the Alps but I was very wrong. These mountain ranges are just as hilly.
column485: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column490:
>

View of the Methena port
column495: >When we arrived by ferry to Methena , we stocked up on food and decided to take the long way around the island up over the volcano ridge to the other side where there is a natural hot spring. Kai had heard about the hot spring from another biker a week earlier so we decided to go check it out. It’s on google maps only in Greek, not many people find or go to this place except for locals from Methena.
column499: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column504:
>

Coasal road around the island, just before the climbing starts
column509: >Methena is absolutely stunning. It’s a very small island not many tourists go here. There’s not many people. Other than the port town, the island has only a few shops and 14 small villages, each which has under 60 people. We then bikes over the mountain and around the west side of the island. Very challenging mountain climbed but insanely beautiful. In terms of road cycling it does NOT get any better than Methena. Coastal roads with no traffic. I could spend weeks biking these roads over and over again and not get bored.
column514: >After the end of the first big climb, half way up the volcano, we arrived at a restaurant in the mountains and we stopped for some water. After chatting with the owner a bit they ended up making us fried Greek cheese.
column515: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column520:
>

The restaurant on the volcano
column525: >While we sat in the volcano restaurant, it started raining heavily, so we camped out the rain stopping there and chatting with the owner of the restaurant, learning about the history of the island and talking about how Methena has changed over the past 50 years, he said it has not changed much, things move really slow here.
column526: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column536: >There was nobody else at the restaurant but us, once the rain ended, we continued on to bike to the most beautiful ascent and decent by bike I have ever seen. Every 200 metres I wanted to stop to soak in the views (also an excuse to stop and rest).
column540: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column545:
>

On the way up, the views kept getting better
column550: >We crossed over Methena’s highest volcano after descending the mountains we got back to the seaside and the natural hot spring.
column555: >Biking down the mountain was like riding a roller coaster. The road had twists and turns and perfect views the whole way down.
column558:
>

Many times we had the option to leave the road and go down mountain trails. Adam and I always stuck to the road and Kai braved the trails. We road on the roads while we would hear Kia shouting screams of joy in the valley trails below.
column559: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column569: >When we first got to the hot spring, there was no water in the tub, and the gate to the little hut by the tub was locked. We believed that all the biking we did to arrive at hot spring was for nothing. All the signage was in Greek, and I cant read Greek (yet). In that moment we went from really happy to terribly sad, it appeared that we would not be able to use the hot spring… But then, we found this little green button on the side of the house, after pressing it a few times hot water started to gush out of the pump. Oh man that was amazing. After the 40km mountain bike over the volcano, it felt amazing to swim in some water heated by that very same volcano.
column574: >A little side note, just today while biking around the island, we met the owner of the Hot Spring. Well not the owner, but the person who made it. He explained is that the water is heated by volcanic gases and he built a pump to move this hot water through the pipes to the beach side tub. He also built the beach side tub to sit in from stone.
column579: >Now back to the tub.
column584: >We enjoyed this beach side bath tub for many hours, we enjoyed the same view we had up in the mountains, but this time right at sea level. The sun was setting. This place was so awesome we did not want to leave and we then set up our tents right beside the Hot Spring. I love camping.
column585: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column595: >We set up our tents above the stairs to the hot spring around 10pm. While we set up our tents, we noticed someone coming in on their bike to use the hot spring. We started a conversation with him. I don’t remember how the conversation went, but somehow the fact surfaced that this Greek man played chess. Now I also play Chess, I love chess. I started the chess club at my high school and I would often play and study for hours at a time. So of course. I asked him if he wants to play chess. The Greek Man replied,
column603: >“Oh yes, lets play chess. I always love to play chess. Do you need to use a board?”
column611: >I realized right away that I didn’t stand a chance. I need to see a board to play chess while this man, and this man could just play chess in his head without a physical board.
column616: >Turns out the Greek man was currently trying to become a professional chess player, playing in international tournaments.
column621: >We left it there and decide we would play chess with a board later after he had finished in the hot spring baths.
column626: >20 minutes later we got an introduction to the man, his name was Alex, we shared stories and played chess. And of course he crushed me two games in a row, and then replayed the whole game for me and told me all my mistakes.
column631: >After chatting with Alex, and sharing some Greek desserts we had bought in super markets on the other side of the volcano, he invited us to stay in his village home so we did not have to camp. It was quite late, dark and we had all of our things unpacked so we told him no.
column636: >We said goodnight and parted ways.
column641: >We slept that night under the stars, with the ocean waves lapping.
column646: >here is where we slept that night.
column647: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column652:
>

Camping right above the hot spring
column657: >You won’t be able to guess what happens next.
