column462: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column467:
>

Luck brining us to the most beautiful place I have ever been.
column473:
>

I am still catching up on these posts. I want to have something written for each day. I am currently writing this post listening to Suzanne Leonard Cohen, sitting on the balcony of a Greek Villa in a tiny mountain village. I'
column474: m still currently on Methana.
column478: m getting ahead of myself here...
column481:
>

Let’s get back to the hostel in Athens.
column484:
>

Sunday the 21st was the day after my “Night out” in Athens. I went to bed at 6 am and woke up at 10am. It was the checkout day from the hostel. Yes, I was tired.
column487:
>

Exactly on the theme of the trip. We had no plans where we were going to go. An hour before checkout, we looked at our map and found a campsite 85 kilometres outside of Athens in some mountain ranges to the left.
column490:
>

We started to pack up our bikes and then Adam and I bumped into Kai.
column493:
>

Kai was a fellow bike touring cyclist we met the day before at the hostel when we were drinking beers in the backyard of the hostel.
column496:
>

He had been travelling around Greece for three weeks. First impression of Kai was this man has been places and seen things. Getting to know him after the past few days has been eye-opening. He spent over a year and a half biking in South America, Columbia, Peru, Chile, Argentina. He also let me use his amazing folding keyboard to type this post. :) I think that I could write an entire book on Kai and still have a lot more to say.
column499:
>

Here are some interesting things about Kai.
column510: > He can whistle two different tones at once
column513: > Literally nothing bothers him. Most easy going person I have ever met.
column516: > He has a surprising story about just about everything.
column519:
>

Anyway, Adam and I standing there in the backyard of the hostel invited Kai to join us in bike touring since he seemed super interesting, and had some amazing ideas of where to bike in Greece.
column522:
>

Kai is from Minnesota, USA.
column525:
>

Kai joined Adam and I, and we quickly abandoned our previous campsite plan. Kai ended up leading us out of the city.
column528:
>

Adam and I biking through Athens'
column529: maze of streets two days before took two hours to go from the coast to the hostel. Following Kai, we got out of Athens in 20 mins to the port where the dozens of ferries take people from Athens to the various islands.
column532:
>

Biking out of the city with Kai and Adam was SOOO much easier. And also beautiful. We biked through completely different neighborhoods in Greece. All on a protected bike path. Which is much, much nicer than busy roads without bike lanes.
column533: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column538:
>

following Kai onto the ferry.
column541:
>

We got to the port side to see massive yachts and beautiful buildings. We headed along the portside roads all the way to the ferry terminal. Stopping for some Souvlaki (Greek pita style food) in transit.
column544:
>

We arrived at the ferry terminal without knowing where we were going and just got on the next ferry that came into port.
column547:
>

The ferry ride leaving Athens was amazing. I spent the whole time on the upper deck enjoying the sea breeze and working on my sunburn. The Athens harbor was filled with giant ships, and yachts. Various Greek islands in the backdrop. Packs of Seagels would fly with the ship which looked amazing.
column548: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column553:
>

Adam writing in is journal
column556:
>

After about 30 minutes on the Ferry, we arrived at the island of Aigina. Kai, Adam and I were lining up to get off the ferry when we decided to stay on the ferry to try and travel with these two Lesbian Spanish Flamenco Musicians who were going to the next stop on the ferry. The next stop was the much smaller, much quieter island of Agistri. Kai, Adam, and I are all three gringos that speak Spanish so we were very happy to chat with two Spanish musicians. We wanted to hear them play the guitar and practice Spanish. They also seemed like cool people.
column559:
>

We had tickets for the first island but no one really cared that we stayed on the ferry to the next stop, this small island. 95% of the people on the ferry got off at the first stop.
column562:
>

The next stop, Agistri, is mainly beach restaurants, a few small hotels, forests, and little villages.
column565:
>

The island was STUNNING, and the air was fresher outside of the big city.
column566: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column571:
>

Asking an Irish e-biker to take our photo.
column574:
>

We biked along the seashore, every few minutes I would say “This is the most beautiful place I have ever been”. Endless sea roads, with empty beaches and clear blue water contrasting with white Greek island houses.
column577:
>

The Spanish Musicians, ended up doing something different, they had a hotel and we were camping so we never actually got to hear them play music. It was a shame but none of cared in the slightest because it lead us to this mini paradise.
column578: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column586:
>

Exploring the island roads, we ended up at an unbelievable campsite just a few kilometres away from the ferry terminal on the island. Even though it was only 8 kilometres, this completely removed the campsite from the rest of the island. And we had a quiet and peaceful camping spot on the beach.
column587: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column592:
>

Dirt road down to the beach
column595:
>

This was my second time camping completely on my own and cooking my own camping food. I feel as though I lucked out big time with the beautiful spot we had.
column600: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column605: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column612:
>

After setting up shop, we just started to camp out. And enjoyed a peaceful night on a Greek Island. The first night of many to come.
column615:
>

Talk to you tomorrow.

column426: > #1 - Biking from Greece to Morroco
column433: > Erik’s cross continent bike trip.
column434: class=""dd""><table class=""mob-block"" role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td aling=""center"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""right"" class=""socialShare mob-stack""><tr><td align=""left"" valign=""middle""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""left"" style=""width:140px

column461: ><table role=""none"" width=""100%"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" align=""center""><tr><td class=""dd"" align=""start"" style=""padding:0px 15px
column466: >The Why and The What - Biking across Europe
column467: text-align:start
column477: >Family, friends or anyone else who’s found this blog. I will be documenting my bike tour from Greece to Morocco.
column481: >Why am I doing this?
column486: >Two years ago during a small overnight bike trip to cultus lake, British Columbia. I became obsessed with the idea to bike across Europe. The original plan was Portugal to Russia. But obviously that quickly became impossible with the war in Ukraine.
column491: >Regarding bike touring, I had been inspired by seeing Adam who I am travelling with, bike across the United States during a two month period. And Taiga, someone I met at university, and Adams best friend, bike all over Japan and Europe for 10 euros a day.
column496: >The plan slowly developed over the last two years for me and Adam to start in Athens, Greece and adventure off the beaten path biking west to Morocco, with no exact route in mind and being open to changing plans on a whim.
column501: >I say “the plan” but the reality is we do not have one. I also say Greece to Morocco but during the first six days of this trip so far everything has been so unpredictable it’s just as likely I end up in Iceland as Morocco. I realize I could easily spend the next three months biking around Greece alone. I will repeat myself a lot but it’s out-of-this-world beautiful.
column506: >And finally for the rational of why travelling by bicycle. Biking is an interesting way to travel. You are vulnerable to everything. Cars, Dogs, weather. it takes a while to get anywhere when you’re carrying 50kg of gear and equipment on your bike. But the best part is the sense of freedom on the bike is unmatched. I am carrying everything I need to survive (tent, credit card, stove, lots of water, etc) with me at all times. And I can go anywhere anytime I want. I just stop biking and set up my tent And so anything. It’s amazing and it’s ridiculously cheap. (Camping so far has been completely free)
column511: >Secondly, I think that to become a better person we always need to try and get out of our comfort zone to grow and learn. I have never camped alone. I have never cooked myself food camping, the longest trip I have done on a bike is one night. And here I am living on the road with my bike for three months. I will climb mountains, I will bike in the rain, I will bike in the blazing heat, I will be uncomfortable. But here I am.
column516: >Biking from Greece to Morocco sound impossible to me. And I just want see if I can do it.
column520: >Why am I now writing this?
column525: >I never would have thought I would be writing about this trip for others. I am not a writer all, i find it difficult, and I wanted to keep this trip private. I felt no need to share this with anyone whiles its happening, and instead just tell stories afterwards to friends and family. Then Greece happened. My first five days in Greece have completely shocked me. I am in love with Greece and bike touring. Each day so far I have told myself. “This is the most beautiful place I have ever been”. Or “These are the most beautiful women I have ever seen” haha. It just keeps getting better day after day.
column530: >I have come to the conclusion that I want friends and family to share this experience and “come with me” on this tour. Hopefully what I will write will be interesting, entertaining, or inspiring to someone. We can all share the struggles and the really awesome things that will come in the next three and a half months on the road.
column535: >Each day I’ll try and post a blog a photo of things that are happening where I’m going to a meeting. I’ve been in Greece for five days now, and I’ve decided I want to share this with friends and family. Greece is just a magical place. And I’m very excited to share all my experiences with anyone reading this. This blog won’t be pretty, It won’t be perfect, I’m a pretty mediocre writer. But I hope you enjoy following along with me.
column540: >I’m starting this blog five days into my journey so here’s the first two days so far. I’ll be a bit behind on writing these but I’ll try and catch up.😉
column547: >(We lost a day in timezone changes)
column548: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column553:
>

Athens airport to Vari to Athens along the coast
column558: >I was flying from Vancouver through London to Athens in Greece. To be honest, I didn’t plan anything of this trip and I didn’t really know anything of Athens. I had no idea what Greece looks like. What Athens looks like. I found out what the Acropolis is in a conversation on the flight to London (If you don’t know it’s a really important Greek ruin). Before a few days ago I could not tell you anything about Greece or Greek history except that I don’t like Greek salad. And I had no idea where I was going from the Athens airport, or to a place to sleep when I arrived. Sounds fun, right? The first day was been travelling. In Vancouver, I packed my bike into a box. Put about 1000 layers of bubble wrap around my bike. I check my bike into my British Airways flight. My friend Dominic helped me a lot getting the bike in the box. (Thanks bro 😎
column565: >I was terrified of flying with my bike. I really common problem is that a bike gets damaged in transit. That wouldn’t be a good way to start my trip.
column570: >14 hours later, I arrived in Athens airport Greece at 3 am. I feel so much excitement on the plane ride, that I couldn’t sleep, even so I landed at 3 AM with so much energy. Adam and I have decided on the flight that the first time as us we wouldn’t sleep at all.
column575: >Arriving in Athens was awesome, the Greek letters looks so cool. I was taking pictures of every sign. Just cause I love the Greek letters so much.
column580: >We go to the baggage claim, will be about 10 minutes then we saw our bikes. Thankfully nothing was damaged!
column585: >At 3 am Greek time, We reassembled our bikes together. By 5 AM our bikes were successful assembled, and we hit the road!
column586: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column596: >And of course we left 30° C in Vancouver for 20° and raining and when we landed in Athens.
column601: >Our first destination was this little town outside of Athens, called Vari. We just randomly selected on the map because it had a beach. And we wanted a post plane shower.
column606: >The bike ride from the airport to Vari was about 35 km. The roads were terrible. Not the actual roads themselves but the giant trucks and narrow road shoulders. We were taking the highway. I was pleasantly surprised as the level of driving. Mostly was really kind to us and passing us in their cars slowly rather than speeding by.
column611: >At one point we peeled off the highway to take a quieter smaller road. Only to be met by hundreds of guard dogs, lucky the owners had fences, expect for the pick of sheep dogs we met on the road. They all looked like they want to eat our bicycles.
column612: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column617:
>

we saw many dogs who wanted us for breakfast
column622: >Eventually we landed in Vari, and both took her first plunge into the Mediterranean Sea. The waters only slightly warmer than Vancouver right now 🥹
column624: >. But it was great going for a swim.
column629: >We then proceeded along the coast to Athens, the main city, biking, along to Seaside Highway. With a stunning view of houses and buildings built into the Mountainside, and massive yachts in the marina.
column634: >During the plane ride, we reserved a hostel in the centre of Athens. Zorbas hostel, 11 euros per night. About 2 km from the centre of Athens. Biking to the hospital from Vari, was not so easy. Adam got two flat tires, and biking in the city of Athens is completely mayhem. The highways are filled with truck, drivers fast cars with no bike lanes. And the small side streets are like mazes. I had to check the map every two street to not get lost. The last 3 km of our trip to the hostel, took an hour of biking (or rather an hour of making wrong turns on one way streets).
column635: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column640:
>

Vari Village and a swim in the Mediterranean
column645: >When we finally arrived at Zorbas Hostal. I was pretty sure I had minor heatstroke since the previous rain had turned in 27 degrees and sunny. For 11 euros a night the hostel was awesome. The first thing I did was head to the bed and take a short nap.
column650: >After waking up it was about 5 pm and we walked around Greece, towards to city center. Here are some of my first im professions of Athens.
column669: >All the building and streets have amazing and unique architecture. They also have flowers all over the place. It also seems like every two blocks the style of all the building changes.
column674: >The Athenians are kind, however the level of English for people over the age of 35 is very low, and you could tell also some Greek people we met were fed up with tourists. Usually saying “efharisto” (Thank you in greek) a million times was enough to make even the coldest Athenian smile.
column679: >Still reading? A lot happened this day. Instead of sleeping in the morning we were biking.
column684: >On the post nap walk we took the metro in Greece, even the subways system looked so different then what I was used it. It took a while to figure out how to get the ticket for the metro.
column689: >We then went to a view point in Athens. The Acropolis! This is some really important historial thing in Greece. It cost us 10 euro to get in. Lots of call columns and impressive engineering. I couldn’t help but wonder what this looked like back in the day.
column693: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column698:
>

These are some big columns
column703: >It was also here that I realized just how big Athens is. I then understood why it took so long to get from the coast to the hostel, from the view point the city seemed like an endless sea of houses and building. Adam and I looked it up and Athens has a population density triple of Vancouver and 5 million people.
column708: >After acropolis we got a beer then wet back to the hostel and got an early nights sleep.
column718: >We spent day two walking around the streets of Athens. We talked to the front desk guy in the hostel. He circled four neighbours on a purple map and we walked to each one.
column723: >Walking through Athens was a much more peaceful experience than biking through Athens. All the roads, packed with cars we biked on, has great sidewalks. Here are some interesting things about walking in Athens
column736: >The crosswalks - in Vancouver you have so much time to walk across the road. It’s designed so that even the slowest snail can cross the street in time. In Athens they are FAST. We basically to get across the road. They are built for speed. They start the count not telling you how it’s much time you you have to cross. But rather a countdown for then the pedestrian needs to start sprinting across the street.
column741: >Ancient Ruins are nestled into the town. Shops and Ancient Greek libraries are side by side.
column746: >There are so many tall marble columns. I have seen enough columns that I could probably build one now.
column751: >There are no traffic laws. okay maybe there are some - but we saw motorbikes driving through seating areas of restaurants, and cars parked on meridian road dividers and no one would even bat an eye.
column756: >Saw where the first Olympic Games was held. That was neat.
column757: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column767: >After the city walk and chilling on some rocks and listening to music which a view of the city and Parthenon. We went back to the hostel, went to an afghani restaurant and eat all you could eat Afghan food for 6 euro. And started drinking.
column772: >Had a fun night out in Athens downtown with some other travellers from the Hostel. Bars in Athens don’t close till 5 am :). Great night out, and some great conversations with great people. Great great great.
column780: >There’s the first two days. I wrote this on day six so tomorrow I’ll post again my travels from day 3 and 4.
column796: >Every single day so far has been absolutely incredible and I can’t wait to share more.
column797: "" class=""dd""><table role=""none"" border=""0"" cellspacing=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" style=""margin:0 auto 0 auto
column802:
>

beach side hot springs and our campsite last night
column807: >I am currently writing this inside of a natural hot spring, heated by a 700m high volcano, on the Greek island of Methena, a small island with 1000 people living on it. The hot spring is located right beside the ocean with an incredible view of some other Greek islands and the Peloponnese mountain ranges (which we will be headed to shortly). There is no one else but us, and we camped here last night. But this post is getting really long so I’ll leave day 4 and 5 for tomorrow.
column810:
>

Hope you enjoyed post 1.
column815: >Let the adventures begin.
